CommentCitings.Title: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever and Headaches
HIV Acute Retroviral Syndrome and Headaches
Shingles and Head or Facial Pain
Dental and Jaw Problems and Headaches
Subdural or Epidural Hematoma and Headache
Paget Disease of Bone and Headaches
The Difference Between the Flu and a Common Cold

Comments.Name: Scleritis is inflammation of the sclera, the white part of the eye. It is a rare condition that can be caused by an infection, chemical injury, or autoimmune disease. About 50% of people with scleritis also have an autoimmune disease, which means their immune system attacks healthy tissues in their body.

Most people develop detectable antibodies to HIV within a month after infection. But it can take up to 3 months. If the first antibody test shows HIV antibodies, a second test is needed to confirm the diagnosis. Most infections in the US are caused by HIV-1. HIV-2 is more common outside the US, and requires different antibody tests.

Carbon monoxide poisoning is treated with 100% oxygen until symptoms are gone. This usually takes 4 to 5 hours. Some people may need hyperbaric oxygen therapy. This includes people with a high carbon monoxide blood level (usually more than 25%), people over age 35, and those with evidence of a heart problem, metabolic problems, unconsciousness, or nervous system damage. Hyperbaric oxygen is also recommended for pregnant women, even if the poisoning is less severe.

Emotional symptoms, such as depression and anxiety, can be treated with medication from a doctor. Headaches and joint pain can often be treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin).
An AVM is a mass of abnormal vessels that connects arteries and veins in the brain. People with AVMs are usually born with them. Symptoms may begin in childhood or well into adulthood.

Symptoms of acute retroviral syndrome develop within several weeks after a person is infected with HIV and may last for 2 weeks or longer. They include a sore throat, fever, a rash over the torso and arms, and swollen lymph nodes in the head, neck, armpit, or groin. The liver or spleen may also be swollen.

Giant cell arteritis, also called temporal arteritis, is inflammation of the medium and large arteries in the body. It usually affects the carotid artery in the neck or the temporal artery on the side of the head, but can involve any artery. It rarely occurs in people under age 50. The cause is unknown, but genes and things in a person's environment are thought to play a role.
Anaplasmosis is treated with the antibiotic doxycycline. It should be started as soon as the infection is suspected.

The diagnosis of nummular headache is usually suspected based on a person's symptoms and physical exam. Doctors can order tests to rule out an infection, a tumor in the bones of the skull, and other possible causes of the headache. Testing may include an MRI or CT scan of the head, as well as blood tests.

Celiac disease is a digestive disorder caused by an abnormal immune system response to gluten, a protein in wheat. Similar proteins found in rye and barley can also cause celiac disease. The disease damages the lining of the small intestine and results in poor absorption of nutrients. Genes, environment, and immune system factors all play a role in this disease.
People with sinusitis may have face pain or pressure. The area over their sinuses may be tender when touched.

A cough headache occurs within seconds of coughing, sneezing, straining, or a similar action. The headache is usually severe. People sometimes describe them as bursting, splitting, or explosive. This kind of headache usually affects both sides of the head and lasts from a few seconds to 30 minutes. Sometimes the early pain is followed by a dull ache that lasts for hours.

Acromegaly is suspected when high levels of insulin-like growth factor (IGF-I) are found in a person's blood. The diagnosis is confirmed if growth hormone levels remain elevated after the person drinks a sugar water solution. Imaging tests or other blood tests may be needed to find the source of the excess hormones and to guide treatment. This may include MRI, CT scan, or measurement of growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) in the blood.

People with POTS often feel faint and lightheaded, but don't lose consciousness. This can happen when their brain is not getting enough oxygen. It often occurs when they stand up or are standing. Less often, people with POTS have episodes of fainting.

People with this condition can have nervous system problems, called focal neurological findings. They may have weakness or loss of sensation in areas of the head or body. They can also have trouble with speech, writing, or other brain activities. These signs can be subtle and go unnoticed without a careful examination by a doctor.

Cervical artery dissection can limit blood flow to the brain, causing a TIA or stroke. This can cause problems with coordination or balance, double vision, face numbness, and problems with speaking or swallowing.

People with angle-closure glaucoma often have nausea and vomiting along with the eye pain or vision problem. Nausea and vomiting may be the only symptoms in some people, particularly the elderly. These symptoms are sometimes misdiagnosed as a gastrointestinal problem.

A cluster headache develops rapidly on one side of the head, usually behind or above the eye or at the temple. The pain may also affect other areas of the head and face, such as the forehead, jaw, cheek, and teeth. The neck and shoulders may also be painful. The pain is severe. It is sometimes described as boring, piercing, tearing, or like a hot poker in the eye. Cluster headaches are among the most painful medical conditions.
People with hyperviscosity syndrome may have bleeding of the mucous membranes, such as their gums or inside their nose.
Psittacosis is usually treated with oral antibiotics for 2 weeks or longer. People who are very ill may need to be treated in the hospital with intravenous (IV) antibiotics and breathing support.

Cervical artery dissection can affect the nerves that lead from the brain to the face and eye, on the same side as the dissection. This can cause the eyelid to droop (ptosis) and cause the pupil to stay small (miosis) on the same side. Together, these signs are called Horner syndrome. About 60% of people with carotid artery dissection have this problem.

If toxic shock syndrome is caused by streptococcal bacteria, the diagnosis can be confirmed by a group-A streptococcus culture. This test tells doctors if the bacteria is present. This is done using blood or other body fluids, such as those from the vagina, joints, lungs, or spine. Bacteria are not usually found in the blood when toxic shock syndrome is caused by staphylococcal bacteria. But doctors can check for it in wounds or other infected tissue.
Most people with symptoms from a brainstem malformation have headaches that are worse with straining, coughing, or exertion. These headaches are usually felt in the back of the head.

A cough headache is brought on by actions such as coughing, sneezing, blowing, crying, singing, straining with a bowel movement, or lifting a heavy object. Any activity that involves forced effort against a closed airway can trigger this type of headache.

Signs of a blood vessel disorder in the brain depend on where the problem is and how big it is. Symptoms can include changes in mental state, seizures, or problems with attention, thinking, and memory. Several eye conditions can occur including abnormal eye movements, bulging eyes, and swelling of the optic disk, called papilledema.

Hypercapnia is an abnormally high level of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the blood. It is usually caused by conditions that interfere with breathing. These can be lung conditions, brain disease, or conditions that affect muscles used in breathing. Hypercapnia can also be caused by airway obstruction and some toxic drugs.

The diagnosis of a headache associated with whiplash is usually made on the basis of history and physical exam. Because whiplash often accompanies some trauma to the head or neck, imaging tests are often done to rule out other conditions that may be causing the headache.

People usually develop a fever, headaches, a cough, and muscle aches within 1 to 3 weeks of a chigger bite. They may also have nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. People often develop a rash on the torso and swollen lymph nodes.

Symptoms can be caused by pressure on the brain from the mass, or by swelling or irritation around the mass. This can lead to pressure inside the skull, because the skull cannot expand. To narrow down causes of the mass, doctors look at how quickly symptoms developed and which brain functions are affected.
Many substances are associated with headaches. It is important to inform your doctor about all substances that you use.
Headaches are a common early symptom of toxic shock syndrome. They may occur along with other flu-like symptoms which may last 2 to 3 days before TSS progresses to a life-threatening illness.

A headache is the most common symptom of altitude sickness. It usually develops within 24 hours of ascending to a higher altitude. It usually affects both sides of the head. It can be mild to severe in intensity and may feel like a dull or throbbing ache. It is often made worse by moving, straining, coughing, or bending.

People may have an eschar (black scab) at the site of the mite bite. People with scrub typhus often have trouble with thinking or concentration. They can also develop more severe problems, such as delirium and coma. The liver and spleen may become enlarged.
Most people who have a whiplash injury have headaches afterward, as well as neck pain and stiffness.

People with severe, repeat, or chronic sinus infections or complications may need intravenous (IV) antibiotics, or surgery. Surgery may include removing tissue, mucus, or other debris from the sinuses to open them and relieve pressure.

Common symptoms of neurosyphilis include headaches, vision or hearing problems, and trouble walking. Some people have numbness or tingling in their hands and feet, loss of pain sensation, or loss of bladder control. Men may have erection problems. People often have emotional, behavioral, or thinking problems. Some have hallucinations or delusions (lasting false beliefs). Neurosyphilis can also lead to seizures, garbled speech, or a stroke-like syndrome.

When giant cell arteritis affects the temporal artery, the main symptom is often a new headache or pain in a specific part of the head. Pain may occur on one or both sides of the head. About 50% of people have pain in their temple area. The pain usually develops gradually, over the course of a few hours, but sometimes it starts suddenly and severely.

Several kinds of headache are linked with underwater diving to a depth greater than 30 feet. A high level of carbon dioxide in the blood is one cause. This can happen with shallow breathing or holding the breath. Other causes include physical effort or tight-fitting goggles or mask. Carbon monoxide contamination of an air tank can also be a cause, but this is rare. Diving can trigger existing headache disorders, such as migraines or tension-type headaches.

The diagnosis of cysticercosis is considered based on a person's medical and travel history, along with a physical exam. The diagnosis is confirmed if the parasite is seen on a biopsy, or on a brain imaging test, such as an MRI or CT scan. It may also be seen in the eye with an ophthalmoscope. But often, it cannot be found with any of these tests.

A lumbar puncture is needed to confirm the diagnosis of neurosyphilis. A sample of spine fluid is taken by passing a thin needle between the bones of the lower back into the space around the spinal cord. People with neurosyphilis usually have a high level of protein and white blood cells in their spine fluid. The spine fluid is also tested for antibodies to Treponema pallidum bacteria.

People who have severe or frequent migraines may take medications to prevent them. These include some heart medications, antidepressants, seizure medications, and the herbal supplement butterbur, among others. Avoiding headache triggers (such as caffeine and alcohol), getting regular exercise and sleep, and reducing stress may also help.
Diet-related headache is based on a person's physical exam and medical history.

Hypnic headaches are more common in older adults. Many people with this condition have a history of other headache disorders, such as migraines or tension headaches. Rarely, these headaches are caused by a medical disorder, such as obstructive sleep apnea. But most people with hypnic headaches have no related medical condition.

The pain is usually described as dull and gnawing, rather than throbbing. Some people have episodes of stabbing pain. They may also have constant, dull background pain. The pain is felt outside the skull. It is usually worse at night and may get worse in cold temperatures.
Heavy chemical exposure may cause more serious symptoms, such as breathing problems, coughing, wheezing, fainting, seizures, or death.

About 50% of people with brucellosis have muscle or joint symptoms. Low back, hip, and knee pain are common. Joint infection, called septic arthritis, may affect one or more joints. The joints most often infected are the shoulder, the knee, hip, sacroiliac joints in the low back, or the joint that attaches the breastbone to the collar bone in the upper chest. Septic arthritis may develop slowly. Bone infection, called osteomyelitis, may also occur.

A diagnosis of hypnic headache is based on a person's medical history and a physical exam. Other possible causes of the symptoms should be ruled out. Testing to rule out other causes may include 24-hour blood pressure monitoring, sleep studies, and brain a MRI.

Flu-like symptoms develop about a week after an infected tick bite. The fever can reach 102F. Other symptoms include severe headaches, muscle aches, nausea, vomiting, and loss of appetite. About 85% of people develop a rash. People can have more serious problems if the disease is not treated. These include low blood pressure, irregular heart rhythms, bloody bowel movements, anemia, and brain inflammation (encephalitis).

Papilledema is the swelling of the optic disc on the retina of the eye. It is a sign of increased pressure inside the skull. The increase in pressure can be caused by many things, including a brain tumor or other intracranial mass.

Intracranial masses are masses in the skull. They can be caused by a brain tumor, an infection, bleeding, or inflammation. Cancer that spreads from another part of the body to the brain may cause symptoms of an intracranial mass, even before the cancer has been diagnosed in another area. Strokes, aneurysms, and head injuries also cause symptoms of an intracranial mass.

An intracranial mass often causes headaches, but most headaches have other causes. Certain headaches may be caused by pressure inside the skull and should be reported to a doctor. These include headaches that wake a person from sleep, are worse in the morning, are worse when lying down, are brought on by coughing, sneezing, or straining, or headaches that gradually get more frequent or intense.

The risk for cerebral venous thrombosis is higher in people who have increased blood clotting. Conditions that increase clotting include cancer, blood disorders, and other conditions, such as Behcet's disease, inflammatory bowel disease, and pregnancy. Other risk factors include ear, sinus, or mouth infections. Women who are overweight and take birth control pills also have a higher risk.

Shingles is usually diagnosed based on a person's medical history and physical exam. Lab tests are available, but are rarely needed. Skin blisters can be sampled and viewed with a test called the Tzanck smear. This confirms the diagnosis 75% of the time. Other tests that may be used include a viral culture, a viral DNA test, and blood tests that check for antibodies to the herpes virus.

Other symptoms of Takayasu arteritis include dizziness, fainting, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Narrowing of the arteries can cause high blood pressure, heart failure, heart attacks, strokes, vision changes, and transient ischemic attacks (TIAs).

The diagnosis of SUNA is based on a person's medical history. Other causes of headaches can have similar features. The presence of facial, eye, or nose symptoms distinguish SUNA from other brief stabbing headaches. Some people develop symptoms of SUNA due to another condition. An imaging test, such as an MRI scan, is often done to rule out these conditions.

The cavernous sinuses are spaces behind the eyes and below the brain. They contain veins that send blood back to the heart from the eyes, face, and brain. If a blood clot forms in this area, it is called a cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST). Due to advances in antibiotic treatment, CSTs are rare. But if they occur, they are usually due to a sinus infection. A CST can be a life-threatening emergency and needs immediate medical attention.
A transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a brief interruption in the blood supply to part of the brain. TIAs usually cause symptoms that last only a few minutes. This is also called a mini-stroke.

Blood vessel disorders in the brain include malformations and fistulas. These problems are not common and may cause no symptoms for many years. But they can block blood flow or cause bleeding in the brain, which can be life-threatening. Blood flow to any part of the brain can be affected. Two of the more common blood vessel disorders are arteriovenous malformations (AVM) and dural arteriovenous fistulas (DAVF).

Takayasu arteritis is suspected based on a person's medical history and physical exam. The diagnosis is usually confirmed with an imaging test called an angiogram. An angiogram gives doctors a detailed view of the arteries. It involves injecting contrast dye through a tube into different blood vessels. To diagnose Takayasu arteritis, doctors look for narrowing of the aorta or large arteries in the arms or legs.

People may have fever, fatigue, or a racing heartbeat. They may also lose weight or faint. When the nervous system is affected, people may have headaches, memory loss, a shorter attention span, or irritability. About 25% of people develop bone or muscle pain, osteoporosis, or fractures. Doctors may find anemia, swollen lymph nodes, or a swollen spleen. Histamine levels may be high in the urine or blood.

SUNA (short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic symptoms) is a rare headache disorder. It causes many brief episodes a day of a severe, stabbing headache on one side of the head. People usually have involuntary responses of the nervous system on the same side as the headache. These can include a watery eye, constricted pupil, or a runny or stuffy nose.
People with this infection often have a dry cough that does not produce any mucus. This usually occurs late in the infection.
Up to 90% of people with Rocky Mountain spotted fever have headaches, which are usually severe.

People with syphilis have a higher risk of getting HIV if they are exposed to it, compared to people without syphilis. This is because having a sore or break in the skin from an STD like syphilis allows the HIV virus to enter the body more easily. Also, the same behaviors that raise a person's risk of syphilis also raise their risk of HIV. In some parts of the country, nearly 50% of people with syphilis also have HIV.

Neurosyphilis is suspected when a person has nerve symptoms and syphilis antibodies in their blood. Syphilis antibody tests include RPR or VDRL tests. If these tests show antibodies, a different antibody test (treponemal) is often used to confirm syphilis. Late syphilis may not show up in RPR or VDRL tests, but it can be confirmed with the treponemal test.

West Nile virus infection may cause fatigue, weakness, trouble concentrating, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Some people develop a skin rash consisting of discolored and raised spots, called a maculopapular rash.

Hypnic headaches usually occur without other symptoms. Some people have involuntary nervous system responses, such as watery eyes or a runny nose. Nausea, or unusual sensitivity to light or sound also occur, but these symptoms are rare.

Hormone changes during pregnancy can cause or worsen headaches in some women, especially migraines or tension headaches. Headaches often lessen after the first trimester. When they persist, it is important to watch for high blood pressure and pre-eclampsia. These are serious complications of pregnancy that can also cause headaches.

Mastocytosis occurs when certain immune cells, called mast cells, attack organs and tissues. Mast cells release histamine and other chemicals in the body that cause inflammation. There are two forms of the disease: cutaneous and systemic. The cutaneous form only affects the skin. The systemic form can also affect the intestines, brain, lymph nodes, liver, spleen, and other tissues.
Tension-type headaches can range from mild and occasional to daily and disabling. They can last from 30 minutes to a week at a time.

Anyone can be poisoned by carbon monoxide, but babies, young children, and the elderly are particularly at risk. People with heart disease or breathing problems like asthma and pregnant women are also in more danger from poisoning effects.
Women who are pregnant have a higher risk for thrombosis for up to 3 weeks following childbirth.

A cluster headache attack usually lasts from 15 to 180 minutes. Most people have one or two attacks a day, but some people have as many as 8 a day. These attacks sometimes happen at the same time of the day or night.

Exercise headache is brought on by strenuous physical activity. It can happen during or after exercise. The headache is usually a throbbing pain on both sides of the head. It may last from 5 minutes to 48 hours. When it occurs simply because of activity, it is called primary exercise headache. Primary exercise headache is more likely to occur in hot weather or at high altitude. Primary exercise headache usually stops occurring on its own after 3 to 6 months.
Even low levels of lead can cause a person's blood pressure to rise slightly. People with moderate-to-severe poisoning are at risk for heart disease due to high blood pressure.

Lead poisoning can cause nervous system problems. Some people may have a weak hand, wrist, ankle, or foot. They may also have numbness or tingling in these areas. Rarely, weakness can be severe enough to cause foot or wrist drop. This makes it hard for a person to lift their foot or hand.

An exercise headache that is due to another medical condition may feel explosive, rather than throbbing. These headaches can be caused by other medical conditions such as a sinus infection, a mass in the skull, bleeding in the brain, lack of blood flow to the heart, or other vascular problems. These may require immediate medical attention.

CSTs are diagnosed with an MRI or CT scan of the brain. A contrast dye is often injected into a vein before the scan is done to help brain structures show up better. Sometimes, a test called a cerebral angiogram is done. This involves inserting a thin tube into an artery and guiding it to the brain, and then taking an x-ray.
Many people with a subarachnoid hemorrhage have neck pain and stiffness. It may take several hours to appear.

The diagnosis of essential thrombocythemia is based on a person's medical history, physical exam, and chronic high-platelet count. Large platelets visible on a blood smear and findings from a bone marrow biopsy can support the diagnosis. Other causes of high-platelet production must be ruled out.

Hematocrit is the part of the blood that is made up of red blood cells. Hemoglobin is the part of a red blood cell that carries oxygen. Both measurements are high in people with polycythemia. Men with primary polycythemia usually have a hematocrit over 60% or a hemoglobin level over 17 g/dL. Women with the condition usually have a hematocrit over 55% or a hemoglobin level over 15 g/dL.

There are no tests for altitude sickness. The disorder is confirmed based on the person's history of high altitude exposure and symptoms and the relief from symptoms within 24 hours of returning to a lower altitude.

Most people get HIV by having sex with someone who has the virus. Most HIV infections in the US occur in men who have had sex with men. But everyone who is sexually active is at some risk. Sharing needles is another way HIV is spread from person to person.

Many drugs can cause headaches. These include cardiovascular medications, such as calcium channel blockers, digoxin, nitrates, and hydralazine. Estrogen, an ingredient in oral contraceptives and hormone replacement therapy, has been linked to headaches. Other drugs include phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors (such as Viagra), interferons, and fluoroquinolone antibiotics. Weight loss supplements and energy drinks and supplements can also cause headaches.

People who spend time in wooded areas are at highest risk for tick bites. Many people with Rocky Mountain spotted fever don't recall a tick-bite, but may report having been outdoors where ticks live, like wooded or recreational areas where there is uncut grass or low brush. Recent activities that raise a person's risk of tick bites include camping, hiking, fishing, hunting, gardening, or golfing or occupational activities, such as forestry work, farming, or landscaping.

New daily persistent headache is a diagnosis used when a person suddenly starts having daily headaches without an apparent cause. There is a clearly remembered time of onset. In most people, the headache is continuous with little or no headache-free time.

Brucellosis is treated with a combination of antibiotics for 6 weeks. This usually includes doxycycline (for example, Monodox, Vibramycin) and rifampin (Rifadin), or doxycycline and intramuscular streptomycin. Children and pregnant women may be given sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim (Bactrim, Septra).

Many people with sarcoidosis have changes in their skin. Along with red nodules under their skin, people may have a rash on their cheeks and nose, called lupus pernio, which occurs in people who have had sarcoidosis for a long time. Other skin rashes may occur, including lighter or darker patches. People may also develop skin lesions on their scars or tattoos.
Headaches are common in people with West Nile fever. Headaches can also be a symptom of meningitis or encephalitis caused by West Nile virus infection.

Depression can be caused by a medical problem, substance abuse, sleep disorder, or grief. Many people with major depression also have another mental health problem at the same time. All of these causes should be considered before choosing a treatment plan.

The attack of symptoms begins suddenly and usually affects only one eye. Some people have repeat attacks that last minutes to hours. The eye may appear normal between attacks. Attacks are often triggered when the pupils get bigger (dilate) due to dim lighting or certain medications.

West Nile virus affects birds and can be spread to humans by mosquitoes. It is found throughout the US. People can have flu-like symptoms, including fever, headaches, and joint and muscle pain. In a small number of people, the infection spreads to the brain, causing meningitis or encephalitis.

Sarcoidosis causes weight loss, fever, and general discomfort in about 33% of people with the condition. Sarcoidosis may affect the heart, causing heart rhythm problems or heart failure. If it affects the brain, it may cause headaches, weakness, seizures, or trouble with walking or thinking. If the sinuses or nasal passages are affected, people may have nasal congestion, nasal crusting, nosebleeds, or loss of sense of smell. Sarcoidosis may also cause poor liver function.

Many people with giant cell arteritis have some visual symptoms. This can be one of the first signs of the disease, and may include partial or complete vision loss in one or both eyes, visual field problems, or double vision.

A nummular headache is a rare type of headache that causes pain in a small, coin-sized area of the scalp, on one side of the head. The cause is not known. These headaches can last for less than an hour or up to several days. They may be continuous or come and go. Some people have unusual sensations in the area of the headache, such as numbness or tingling. Activities, such as hair brushing, can make the pain worse.
This consultation was primarily designed for adults, and a separate one exists for children. For children 13 and under, please take the Headache in Children Consultation.

The diagnosis of hypercapnia is confirmed by testing a sample of blood from an artery. The blood can be drawn from an artery in the wrist. In people with hypercapnia, the carbon dioxide level is elevated. The oxygen level can range from normal to very low.
The diagnosis of cluster-type headache is largely based on the features of the headache. Other headache causes and other types of headache should be ruled out.

Hypertensive emergency is diagnosed based on an elevated blood pressure level above 180/120. Additional diagnostic tests are performed to determine the likely cause, once the blood pressure has been stabilized.

The diagnosis of anemia is based on the level of hemoglobin in the blood. Hemoglobin is the red pigment of blood cells that carries oxygen. The World Health Organization defines anemia as a hemoglobin level of less than 13g/dL in men or less than 12g/dL in women. Sometimes, the hematocrit is used to diagnose anemia. The hematocrit is the percentage of whole blood made up of red cells. Initial testing for anemia should include a complete blood count and a reticulocyte count.

Headaches and dizziness are often the first symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning. Headache severity does not always match the amount of exposure. Headaches that clear up when the person leaves an area of possible exposure suggests carbon monoxide exposure.

Symptoms can be triggered by food, alcohol, or stress. Even a sudden change in temperature may be a trigger. Exercise, insect bites, infections, and certain medications may cause symptoms in some people. Severe symptoms have sometimes occurred after bee stings or after taking aspirin. Life-threatening allergic reactions (anaphylaxis) occur in 30% to 40% of adults with mastocytosis.
Sarcoidosis affects the lungs in over 90% of people with the condition. The most common symptoms are a lasting cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain.

A CBC counts blood cells, including red and white cells and platelets. It reports the hemoglobin level and the hematocrit. A CBC also provides information on the size of the red cells (the MCV) and how much hemoglobin they contain (MCH and MCHC). These can be used to categorize type of anemia and provide important clues as to its cause.
Reticulocytes are recently produced red blood cells. A low reticulocyte count suggests a problem in making more red blood cells. This can occur when a person has an iron deficiency.

The symptoms of anemia depend on how much the tissues are deprived of oxygen. Headaches can occur if the brain does not get enough oxygen. They may be the main symptom when hemoglobin drops below 10 g/dL.

To be diagnosed with chronic fatigue, people must also have 4 or more other symptoms. These include memory or concentration problems, not feeling refreshed after sleep, muscle or joint pain, tender lymph nodes, sore throat, and headaches. These symptoms must be ongoing or come and go for at least 6 months in a row. They must not start before the fatigue starts.
People with anemia often have fatigue and can't do physical exercises. Anemia may also cause headaches, dizziness, fainting, and muscle cramps.

The diagnosis of African trypanosomiasis is confirmed by identifying the parasites in blood or other body tissues using a microscope. The East African type of the disease is caused by Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense. The West African type is caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense.

Lead poisoning can cause digestive symptoms. Abdominal pain and discomfort can occur. People with moderate lead poisoning may have severe abdominal cramps and a rigid (stiff) abdominal wall. Other symptoms may include loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, and constipation. A few people may also have diarrhea.

People with pre-existing high blood pressure are at higher risk of a hypertensive crisis, particularly if they don't take their blood pressure medicine regularly or if they suddenly stop taking it. Other conditions that raise the risk of a hypertensive emergency are cigarette smoking, cocaine or other substance abuse, oral contraceptive use, and pregnancy. Women who are pregnant are also more likely to experience organ damage from high blood pressure than nonpregnant women.

A subarachnoid hemorrhage is bleeding in the space between the brain and the membrane that covers it. It is usually caused by a ruptured aneurysm, which is a weak area in the wall of an artery in the brain. The second most common cause is a head injury. A subarachnoid hemorrhage is a medical emergency that can cause brain damage and death.
--- Family or internal medicine provider
The eye pain may occur before the eye movement problems. The pain may feel like gnawing or boring in the eye.

People with hypercapnia can have a headache that affects just the front or back of the head. But it can also be widespread, affecting the whole head. It can be persistent, aching, and severe. Some people have a headache at night.

The diagnosis of primary stabbing headache is largely based on a person's signs and symptoms. Normal results on a neurological (nerve) physical exam and imaging tests, such as an MRI, are needed to rule out other causes and types of headaches.

POTS can cause heart palpitations, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, and fatigue. People may have trembling, nausea, vision problems, and concentration problems. People with POTS become tired easily when exercising.
--- Ophthalmologist (eye)
People with CST may also have symptoms of an infection, including fever, chills, nausea, and vomiting.
About 50% of people with polycythemia have itching all over their body. Contact with water can make the itching worse.

Blood samples are often taken and examined under a microscope over several days. This is because parasite levels in the blood vary from day to day. Certain stains and types of smears make it easier to see the parasites in samples.
Some people may need tests to rule out a heart or vascular problem, such as coronary artery disease or a torn artery.
Most people with symptoms from a brainstem malformation have headaches that are worse with straining, coughing, or exertion. These headaches are usually felt in the back of the head.
Scleritis causes eye pain that can be so severe it can wake people from sleep. It is often described as a deep or boring pain.
Some people have vision problems, such as partial vision loss, double vision, or weakness in the muscles that move the eyes.

The sphenoid sinus is a hollow pocket in the skull, behind the nasal passages. Inflammation in this sinus is called sphenoid sinusitis. It often occurs along with inflammation in the nasal passages and other sinuses. Sphenoid sinus infections are rare, but they can be serious because they are close to the brain, its blood vessels, and the optic nerves. The sphenoid sinus isn't fully formed until about age 9 to 12. Most people with this condition develop it after this age.

Osteomyelitis is treated with antibiotics, usually for at least 6 weeks. Some people may need surgery to remove dead or damaged bone, or to drain pus and debris. People with lasting infections may need other treatments, such as hyperbaric oxygen therapy or special wound dressings.

The pain of a nummular headache occurs in a small, coin-sized spot on the scalp. It is almost always in the same spot. The pain is usually dull and aching, but sharp stabs of pain may occur in addition to the ongoing pain.

Drinking even moderate amounts of wine (even a single glass) can cause headaches in some people. This could be due to the alcohol in wine. But some people react to other substances in red wine only. People who react to red wine often react to chocolate as well.

Shingles (herpes zoster) is an infection caused by the chickenpox virus (varicella zoster). After a person has chickenpox, the virus stays in their brain or spinal cord in an inactive state. It can become active later, causing pain and a painful skin rash. Shingles can occur on any part of the body that lies along the path of the affected nerve.

Mastocytosis is diagnosed by finding dense patches of mast cells in skin or bone marrow biopsies. Biopsies may help doctors determine if a person has the cutaneous or systemic form of the disease. A diagnosis of systemic disease can also be supported by high blood levels of an enzyme called tryptase.

The diagnosis of new daily persistent headache is largely based on the features of the headache. Other headache causes and other types of headache should be ruled out, especially high or low cerebrospinal pressure and cerebral venous sinus thrombosis.

Medication overuse can cause or contribute to a persistent or daily headache. Medication overuse headache is most common in people with migraine, cluster, or tension headaches who are using medications that are ineffective or inadequately dosed. The location, character, and severity of medication overuse headache vary from person to person. But most often, the headaches occur daily upon awakening.

For most people, the aim of flu treatment is to manage symptoms while the infection runs its course. Stay at home, rest, and drink plenty of fluids. Over-the-counter medications can help relieve pain, coughing, fever, and congestion. If you develop serious symptoms like shortness of breath, chest pain, or seizures, call your doctor or go to the emergency room.

Major risk factors for stroke include having had a stroke, TIA, or heart attack. Other risks include a family history of stroke, high blood pressure, atrial fibrillation, a narrowed carotid artery, high cholesterol, diabetes, and smoking. Just being older also increases risk of a stroke or TIA. The risk doubles each decade after age 55.
Almost everyone with scrub typhus has headaches. These are one of the first symptoms of the disease and can be severe.

An HIV RNA test can usually show signs of infection before HIV antibodies can be found in the blood. HIV RNA can often be found as soon as 8 days after infection. For more accurate results, some tests check for both HIV RNA and p-24 antigen. HIV RNA and p-24 tests should be confirmed with antibody tests.

People with this condition can have brain or nervous system problems due to pressure on their brain or spine. They may have weakness or loss of sensation in areas of the head or body. They can also have trouble with speech, writing, or other brain activities. These signs can be subtle and go unnoticed without a careful examination by a doctor.

Glaucoma is diagnosed by finding high pressure inside the eye. This is done with an instrument called an ocular tonometer. Finding out if glaucoma is due to acute angle closure requires special equipment and prompt treatment by an eye surgeon.
Polysomnography, a sleep study, will show any respiratory events such as apneas or hypopneas or other sleep disturbances.

Encephalitis can also be caused by an immune reaction. This type of encephalitis is called autoimmune encephalitis. It occurs when antibodies attack healthy cells in the brain. This often happens weeks after an infection in the brain or other part of the body. Some people with encephalitis have cancer. Nervous system symptoms of encephalitis may start weeks to months before the tumor is found. Encephalitis can also be related to an autoimmune problem in the thyroid gland.

People who are at high risk for complications, such as pneumonia, sometimes need to take an antiviral drug. People at risk include adults who are 65 and older, pregnant women, people with conditions that weaken their immune systems, and those with diabetes, cancer, or lung disease. Others may take an antiviral drug to make the flu shorter and milder. The drugs work best when they are started within 48 hours after the symptoms began.

People with major depression are usually treated with medication, psychotherapy, or both. Cognitive behavioral therapy and interpersonal therapy are helpful for many people with depression. Lifestyle changes may also be helpful for mild or moderate levels of depression. These include regular exercise or yoga, and avoiding alcohol and tobacco. Treating sleep problems may also ease symptoms of depression.

Osteomyelitis is a serious and often destructive bone infection that usually occurs in older adults and people with weakened immune systems, particularly diabetics. This infection may involve the temporal or frontal bones of the skull having spread from the ear, sinus, tooth, or eye. It can also follow head surgery or a head injury. The condition can worsen rapidly.

Scrub typhus is a bacterial infection common in some parts of the world outside the US. People become infected when they are bitten by a chigger (a young mite) that carries the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi. The mites are often found in scrub vegetation in Asia, Australia, and the South Pacific.

Cocaine often causes a headache that develops immediately or within an hour of use. The headache lasts 3 days or less. Cocaine-related headaches may affect both sides of the head in the front or temples. They may have a pulsing quality and can be made worse by physical activity.
People get West Nile virus from the bite of a mosquito. The virus is common throughout the continental US.

A variety of antidepressants have been shown to reduce depression symptoms. These drugs target brain chemicals that play a role in depression. Some antidepressants cause side effects, so people may need to try several before they find one that works. Common antidepressants are venlafaxine (Effexor), citalopram (Celexa), escitalopram (Lexapro), and sertraline (Zoloft).
Other signs and symptoms of sinusitis may include a fever, cough, or headache.

Pre-eclampsia and eclampsia are pregnancy-related conditions that cause high blood pressure and protein in the urine. Eclampsia is a severe form of pre-eclampsia that also causes seizures. These conditions can occur any time after 20 weeks of pregnancy and up to 6 weeks after giving birth. Pre-eclampsia affects up to 6% of pregnant women and eclampsia up to 2%. The cause is unknown.

A mild headache can be caused by a prolonged or wearing visual task or by inappropriate glasses or contact lenses. It can also be caused by an eye problem, such as farsightedness, astigmatism, or strabismus. The headache may be a dull aching at the brow or front of the head. It is usually linked with eye fatigue, straining, or discomfort. The headache lets up when the eyes are closed or rested, or the appropriate corrective lenses are used. This type of headache is rare.

Signs of TTP vary, depending on which organs are involved and how severe it is. People may first have a fever or flu-like illness. Digestive symptoms can include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. When the heart and lungs are involved, people may have shortness of breath, chest pain, abnormal heart rhythms, fainting, a heart attack, or heart failure.

Most people with celiac disease have diarrhea. It sometimes comes and goes, but for some people, diarrhea is a constant problem. Diarrhea most often occurs after meals, at night, or in the early morning. Stools may be greasy or fatty and may float or be hard to flush. They may be pale in color due to high fat content, and they sometimes smell foul.

People with symptoms of vertebrobasilar insufficiency without a stroke are usually treated for the medical problem causing the decreased blood flow. This may involve medications to improve blood pressure, lower cholesterol, or lower the risk of clotting or bleeding in the blood vessels.

A cardiac headache is a rare type of headache caused by an insufficient blood supply to the heart. The headache, along with other symptoms, usually develops during physical exertion. But it sometimes occurs at rest or without other symptoms. The headache is usually moderate to severe and may resemble a migraine.
Among the most common and first signs of an intracranial mass are changes in behavior, mood, thinking, personality, or alertness.
Headaches related to pre-eclampsia and eclampsia may be severe. They are usually throbbing headaches on both sides of the head.

Doctors may also suggest lifestyle changes that can lower the risk of stroke, such as quitting smoking, exercising, and eating a healthy diet. When lifestyle changes and drugs do not manage the symptoms, vascular surgery may help.
The diagnosis of a cough headache is based on a person's medical history and an MRI of the brain. An MRI is the best imaging method to identify any condition causing the cough headache.

Lyme disease is spread by Ixodes ticks. They are small and their bite is usually painless. People are not always aware that they have been bitten. A tick must be attached and feeding for at least 24 hours to spread Lyme disease to a person.

People with cluster headache often have eye redness or watering or a runny nose on the same side as the headache. Some people have a drooping eyelid or a constricted pupil on the same side. Other symptoms include nasal congestion, eyelid swelling, and facial sweating or flushing.
A cluster attack may be triggered or made worse by alcohol, histamine, nitroglycerin, or odors, especially solvents, varnishes, and perfumes.
Encephalitis can cause seizures. They may affect just one part of the brain or be more widespread.

People can develop high fevers if Trichinella infect the bloodstream. People may have muscle pain and swelling, swelling around the eyes, swallowing problems, a cough, hoarseness, shortness of breath, chest pain, headaches, or a rash.

The treatment of anemia depends on its cause. Doctors first try to find and stop any source of bleeding. People with nutritional deficiencies, such as a lack of iron or vitamin B12, may need to make dietary changes or take supplements. Medications, such as epoetin alfa, may be prescribed to help the body make more blood cells. Some people need blood transfusions, a bone marrow transplant, or surgery to remove the spleen.
Anemia is sometimes caused by long-term health conditions or certain medications. Treating the condition or changing to a different drug sometimes corrects anemia.

Paget's disease is usually treated with medications that slow the breakdown of bone tissue. These drugs include bisphosphonates, such as alendronate (Fosamax) and zoledronic acid (Reclast). Bisphosphonates can be given by mouth or injected into a vein. People who can't take bisphosphonates may be given another medication, such as calcitonin (Miacalcin).

Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease that causes pockets of immune system cells, called granulomas, to form in various organs in the body. This can cause the organs to function poorly. They are usually found in the lungs, but can also be found in the lymph nodes, eyes, nervous system, heart, liver, kidneys, joints, and skin. About 50% of people with this condition have 2 or more affected organs when they are diagnosed.

Some people with Paget's disease may need surgery to treat fractures, correct deformed bones, or relieve pressure on nerves. Surgery can be challenging, because bones may be weak and prone to bleeding.
Shingles can cause fatigue and fever, numbness, and muscle weakness.

The first fever episode, which lasts from 4 to 10 days, is usually followed by a reaction that can involve excessive sweating, low body temperature, low blood pressure, slowed heartbeat, muscle weakness, and exhaustion. This phase is called Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction.

About 90% of people with a pheochromocytoma have high blood pressure that may spike during symptom episodes. Some people have alternating periods of high and low blood pressure. Pheochromocytomas are rare, but are sometimes the cause of high blood pressure that is hard to treat or that occurs in a younger person.

The symptoms of pre-eclampsia and eclampsia vary, and some women have few. The features are high blood pressure, swelling, and protein in the urine of more than 0.3 grams per 24 hours. Proteinuria is often a late sign.

A cerebellar stroke can be confirmed with a CT or MRI scan of the brain. Contrast dye can be injected to show the blood vessels more clearly on the scan. An arteriogram can also be done by injecting dye directly into the arteries, but this procedure has more risks.
Cluster headaches almost always affect just one side of the head. It is usually the same side of the head for all the headaches in a particular cluster.
--- Infectious disease specialist

Primary central nervous system (CNS) angiitis is a rare inflammation of blood vessels in the brain or spinal cord. Its cause is unknown. The signs and symptoms of primary CNS angiitis can develop and progress rapidly. They may last for weeks or months and may come and go during that time.

People with TTP have red or purplish spots on their skin caused by bleeding under the skin. This is often a sign of a low blood platelet count (thrombocytopenia). Tiny spots are called petechiae. Larger bruise-like spots are called purpura.
Heat exhaustion and heat stroke are diagnosed based on a person's medical history and physical exam. There is no single test to confirm the disorder.

Scrub typhus is treated with antibiotics, such as doxycycline (for example, Monodox, Vibramycin), azithromycin (Zithromax), or chloramphenicol. Because it can take a few weeks to get the test results, people may need to start treatment before the diagnosis is confirmed.

A whiplash injury can also cause dizziness, hearing loss, ringing in the ears, nausea, swallowing problems, and blurred or double vision. People with more severe injuries may have muscle weakness or a loss of sensation.
Many people with celiac disease have abdominal bloating along with foul-smelling gas.

Sinusitis usually occurs after a viral upper respiratory infection. But anything that stops mucus from draining out of the sinuses can lead to sinusitis. This includes allergies and some diseases, such as cystic fibrosis. Activities that involve air pressure changes, such as deep sea diving and air travel, also raise the risk of sinusitis.

If a medication has been overused, stopping it usually helps relieve an overuse headache. A person's headache pattern and frequency often return to previous levels within 2 months. But this does not always happen. After stopping medication, some people go through a period when their headaches are worse. They may also have drug withdrawal symptoms.

People who are depressed usually feel sad and listless. They often have changes in mood, activity level, thinking or memory, and bodily functions, such as sleep, sexual desire, or appetite. They may feel guilty without a good reason. It is also fairly common to have thoughts of death or suicide.

Hypercapnia can cause mental changes, including attention problems, drowsiness, mental slowness, confusion, forgetfulness, disorientation, light-headedness, lethargy, and stupor. These symptoms are sometimes subtle, and they may come and go.
Trichinella larvae can spread into muscles and other organs. This may cause headaches.

Many medications may be used to relieve Behcet's disease symptoms and prevent complications. To treat sores, doctors may prescribe corticosteroids or other medications. These may be given as an ointment or mouthwash. The anti-inflammatory drug colchicine (Colcrys) may be used to control arthritis. It can also reduce the size and number of sores.
Both strokes and vertebrobasilar insufficiency are more likely to occur in older adults with cardiovascular risk factors, like high blood pressure, smoking, or high levels of lipids in their blood.

MRI is the best way to diagnose brainstem malformations. MRI will outline the size and shape of the abnormality, as well as its effect on nearby tissues. Effects on the flow of blood in spinal fluid can also be seen.

It is common for people with somatic symptom disorder to have many diagnostic tests and even surgeries as they try to find the cause of their symptoms. They also tend to visit their doctors often, especially when they feel stressed. But tests, surgery, and frequent doctor visits often don't help. People should talk with their doctor about limiting the number and length of their doctor visits, as well as how to manage stress and expectations about diagnosis and treatments.

Polycythemia is diagnosed based on blood tests that show a high number of red blood cells. In people with this condition, a complete blood count will show an increase in hemoglobin, hematocrit, and red blood cells. Doctors may also measure levels of the blood-producing hormone erythropoietin, to determine if the condition is primary or secondary.

People who've had the disease for some time may have headaches, personality changes, and trouble concentrating. These symptoms may become worse and lead to continual sleepiness. Without treatment, the disease can result in seizures, coma, and death.

Trigeminal neuralgia is a problem of the trigeminal nerve, which provides sensation for the face. People with trigeminal neuralgia have recurring, brief episodes of facial pain. Some people have a headache on one side of the head. Trigeminal neuralgia may be caused by a breakdown of the outer sheath of the trigeminal nerve.

In people with trigeminal neuralgia, attacks of facial pain can be triggered by touch or talking, smiling, chewing, or brushing the teeth. Even a puff of cool air can sometimes trigger an episode. Some people have a trigger zone, a small, sensitive area around the nose or mouth. Touching this area even lightly can trigger an attack. A trigger zone strongly suggests trigeminal neuralgia.

The diagnosis of trigeminal neuralgia is based on a person's symptoms. Facial pain attacks that last longer than 2 minutes suggest a diagnosis other than trigeminal neuralgia. Other causes of facial pain must be ruled out. An MRI scan can help determine other causes. Pain relief with the medication carbamazepine supports the diagnosis of trigeminal neuralgia.

Sexual activity can trigger a headache in some people. Pain is usually felt on both sides of the head, and may feel pulsing or throbbing. The headache may get worse with sexual excitement and orgasm. Some people have sudden, explosive and severe pain right before or at orgasm. Pain may be severe and last from 1 second to 24 hours, or it may be mild and last for up to 72 hours.

A cervicogenic headache is caused by a medical problem in the cervical (upper) spine or nerves. It can be triggered by some head or neck positions or movements, or by coughing or straining. The pain is usually a lasting, dull ache.

The pain of occipital neuralgia usually begins at the base of the skull or upper neck. It may then spread upward to the back of the head or behind the ears. It usually affects just one side of the head. The pain occurs in brief episodes that last for a few seconds or minutes. Pain is sometimes brought on by turning the head or over-extending the neck (tipping the head back).

People with more serious disease, including eye problems, may also need oral corticosteroids or other immune-suppressing drugs. Immune-suppressing drugs include thalidomide (Thalomid), methotrexate (Trexall), cyclosporine (Sandimmune), and azathioprine (Azasan). Interferon alpha and TNF inhibitors, such as infliximab (Remicade), may also be used.

Treatment for an intracranial mass depends on the cause. A tumor may be treated with a combination of surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy. Masses caused by an infection may be drained with surgery and treated with antibiotics. If the mass is caused by bleeding, surgery may be needed to remove the blood and relieve pressure on the brain.
Up to 70% of people with primary CNS angiitis have headaches. They are usually severe and throbbing. They can affect one area of the head or be more widespread.

A cerebral angiogram is abnormal in about 75% of people with primary CNS angiitis. This test is done by injecting a contrast dye into the arteries that supply the brain. It provides detailed x-ray pictures of the blood vessels. It can show narrowing of medium-sized vessels, but this pattern is sometimes seen in people with other conditions.

Depending on the cause of the intracranial mass, people may also receive glucocorticoids or diuretics to reduce swelling in the brain. Anticonvulsant drugs may be prescribed to prevent or treat seizures.

The main treatment for celiac disease is a gluten-free diet. This means taking wheat, rye, and barley products out of the diet. Most digestive symptoms get better quickly, but symptoms return if these foods are eaten again. People with celiac disease may need to take nutritional supplements, such as iron, folic acid, B12, or calcium. Sometimes, corticosteroids or other drugs that suppress the immune system are prescribed for severe or ongoing celiac disease.

Headaches are the most common symptom of low CSF pressure or volume. The headache is usually worse when standing up. Some people have headaches that are worse when they lie down, but this is rare. People may have a headache every day. The headache can start suddenly and become very severe. Some develop during the second half of the day.

A stabbing headache is a brief, severe headache that lasts from 1 to 10 seconds. It causes one or more sharp stabs of pain, usually around the eye or forehead. It can also affect the face or the top or back of the head. It usually involves one side of the head only. People can have from one to a few headaches a day. The stabs usually move around from one headache to the next. There are no other common symptoms. This is also referred to as an ice pick headache.

An external head compression headache is caused by pressure on the head, such as from a tight hat, headband, goggles, or other head gear. The headache is not pulsating. It develops at the site of the pressure and is most painful where the pressure is the greatest. It lets up when the pressure is removed. It is not associated with other symptoms. A migraine-like headache may develop if external compression is prolonged.

A cold-stimulus headache (or "ice-cream headache") is one that starts suddenly with exposure to cold, such as cold air or water. It can also begin after eating or drinking a cold food or liquid. The pain is intense and stabbing, but only lasts for about 20 seconds to up to 5 minutes. The headache should go away completely within 30 minutes of removal of cold exposure. Headaches that occur after eating or drinking something cold are usually located in the front of the head.
Spinal fluid can be examined for parasites if people have symptoms of nervous system problems.
Most species of Borrelia spirochetes that cause relapsing fever can be identified by polymerase chain reaction.

Angle-closure glaucoma is a buildup of fluid pressure in the eye. It is caused by narrowing of the angle where the cornea and iris meet. Most people have a sudden attack of severe eye symptoms. This is often an emergency that needs prompt treatment to prevent permanent vision loss.

Early Lyme disease is treated with antibiotics to reduce symptoms and fight the infection. Some people may be given these drugs after a tick bite to prevent Lyme disease. People with meningitis, nervous system problems, or heart problems, may need to receive intravenous (IV) antibiotics at the hospital. If the infection continues, a second round of antibiotics may be needed.
People with mastocytosis may have repeat headaches.
Nausea is common with a cardiac headache. Other normal migraine symptoms, including sensitivity to light and sound, rarely occur with a cardiac headache.

People with Lyme disease may have a rash, often followed by fever and flu-like symptoms. They also have muscle and joint pain. Unless they are treated with antibiotics, many people develop arthritis, heart problems, or nervous system problems.

People who spend time in wooded areas have the highest risk of tick bites. Many people with this infection do not recall a tick bite, but they may remember being in outdoor areas where ticks live, such as wooded or recreational areas with uncut grass or low brush. People with weak immune systems and people over age 40 seem to have the highest risk of this infection.

Trichinellosis is an infection with a parasite, a roundworm called Trichinella. Eating undercooked meat is usually the cause of the infection. Symptoms in the digestive tract start within a week with a fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, or vomiting. The parasites can also travel through the bloodstream to other parts of the body. This can cause other symptoms months later. These symptoms depend on which parts of the body are infected.

A stroke is a brain injury caused by a lack of blood supply. It may be caused by a ruptured artery or by the blockage of an artery due to disease or a blood clot. A stroke may affect any part of the brain or the brain stem, which connects the brain to the spinal cord. Cerebellar or brainstem strokes affect people differently than strokes affecting the rest of the brain. The symptoms usually come on suddenly and depend on where they occur and how much of the brain is injured.

People with AVM may have nervous system problems, called focal neurological findings. About 10% of people with an unruptured AVM have one or more of these signs. They may have weakness or loss of feeling in parts of their head or body. They can also have trouble with speech, writing, or other brain activities. These signs can be subtle and go unnoticed without a careful exam by a doctor.
Some people with acute retroviral syndrome have headaches as part of a flu-like syndrome. The headaches are usually felt as pain behind the eyes.

Many people also need procedures to help improve their blood flow and prevent other medical problems, such as strokes or heart attacks. Procedures may include bypass surgery or angioplasty. During angioplasty, a tube with a small balloon on the end is used to open narrowed arteries.

A spinal tap (lumbar puncture) causes a headache in about one-third of people. The headache usually develops immediately upon sitting up after the procedure. In some people the headache may be delayed and occurs within 5 days of the procedure. The headache is usually dull or throbbing. It may feel better when lying down.
Lead in the blood can reduce sex drive and cause fertility problems. Anemia and kidney problems can also occur.

Marijuana may cause a mild frontal headache. Marijuana use may also cause narrowing of arteries in the brain, called cerebrovascular constriction. This can cause sudden and severe headaches. Some people have even had a stroke while using marijuana. Users who start young or have used marijuana for a long time were more likely to get headaches.

When circulation in a major blood vessel in the brain is interrupted, brain function is also interrupted in the affected area of the brain. Loss of brain function leads to different symptoms, depending on the location of the stroke. These problems can be permanent, but many people make at least a partial recovery.
--- Cardiologist (heart specialist)

The blood vessels in the back of the brain that supply the cerebellum and brainstem are called the vertebrobasilar system. When the blood supply to these vessels is reduced but not completely blocked, a person may have some of the symptoms of cerebellar stroke. But these symptoms tend to come and go. This condition is called vertebrobasilar insufficiency.

Two home tests have been approved by the FDA and are available. One test involves mailing a finger-prick blood sample to a licensed lab. Anonymous test results are available as early as 1 day later. The other test involves a swab of saliva that is tested with an at-home kit. Follow-up testing is recommended. False negatives are more common with home tests.

People with Lyme disease may have flu-like symptoms including fatigue, headache, fever and chills, enlarged lymph nodes, and a general achiness. These are the first symptoms of infection in almost 20% of people.

People with mastocytosis often have digestive symptoms. These include lower abdomen pain, diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting. Excess digestive juices can cause peptic ulcer disease. As mastocytosis gets worse, some people lose their ability to absorb nutrients from food.

Essential thrombocythemia can cause burning pain in the hands or feet due to poor circulation in the small blood vessels. The skin may be red and warm. Heat or exercise can make it worse. Applying cold or elevating the hand or foot may bring relief.
Osteomyelitis of the skull that arises from an infection of the outer ear can cause ear pain, hearing loss, and drainage from the affected ear.

West Nile virus infection is suspected based on a person's medical history and physical exam. It can be can be confirmed by measuring antibodies to the virus in the blood or spinal fluid. Follow-up testing is often needed to confirm that a positive antibody test was due to West Nile virus and not a related flavivirus.
Trichinella organisms can sometimes be seen in muscle tissue under a microscope. Biopsies are best done on muscles that appear swollen or inflamed.

Sarcoidosis usually affects people between the ages of 10 and 40. About 50% of people improve within 2 years, but the disease can become worse. The cause is unknown. Some experts think being exposed to toxic substances, such as heavy metals, may play a role. A person's genes or family history may also raise their risk for this condition.
Widespread redness and warmth on the skin, called flushing, is common in people with mastocytosis. It is caused by the release of histamines or other chemicals made by mast cells.

If the diagnosis is still unclear after brain imaging tests, antibody tests may be done. Tests are available in some labs to measure antibodies in the blood or spinal fluid. Antibody tests are more likely to be positive when there are several cysts. Antibody titers can stay high for a long time after the parasites die. Positive results are harder to interpret for people from regions where the parasite is common.

The person should rest in a cool, shaded place and remove clothing. A common cooling method is to spray water on the person's skin and put them under a fan. Applying ice packs to the groin, armpits, and neck can also help. Depending on the type of complications that occur, people with heat stroke may also need intravenous (IV) fluids and other emergency treatments in the hospital.

About 90% of people with sarcoidosis have swollen lymph nodes in their chest, which can be seen with an x-ray. About 30% of people notice swollen lymph nodes in other parts of their body, especially their neck, groin, armpits, or arms.

People with viral encephalitis may have one or more nervous system problems, called focal neurological findings. They may have weakness or loss of sensation in areas of the head or body. They can also have trouble with speech, writing, or other brain activities. These signs can be subtle and go unnoticed without a careful examination by a doctor.
--- Vascular surgeon (blood vessels)

Most people with mastocytosis have reddish-brown spots or spidery patches on their skin, called urticaria pigmentosa. These occur on the thighs, back, or sides. They may occur in clusters or as widespread patches of mottled skin. If rubbed gently, these areas swell and turn red (Darier sign). People may have a few spots or spots on most of their body. About 60% of people have repeat itching.

Risk factors for an intracranial aneurysm include high blood pressure, smoking, polycystic kidney disease, connective tissue diseases, cocaine use, and a family history of intracerebral aneurysm or subarachnoid hemorrhage.

The risk of pre-eclampsia is higher for first pregnancies. It is also higher for women who have had pre-eclampsia or eclampsia in the past, or who have a family history of either one. Pregnant women over age 35 have a higher risk. Other medical conditions can also increase the risk. These include high blood pressure, autoimmune diseases, kidney disease, diabetes, obesity, being pregnant with more than one baby, and abnormal tissue growth in the uterus.

The Roos test detects the pressure on the nerve or blood vessel in the thoracic outlet. This test is also called the elevated arm stress test. The Roos test is sometimes positive even when there is no nerve or blood vessel compression. Imaging tests, such as an x-ray or CT scan, can help explain physical exam findings.

The immediate-type headache occurs within 3 hours of drinking alcohol. People who have migraine headaches are more at risk for this type of headache. Certain types of alcohol, such as red wine, are also more likely to cause an immediate headache.

Blood tests are used to confirm the diagnosis of scrub typhus. Antibodies may not be detectable during the first few days of illness. Repeat antibody testing is often done in a week or two. An increase in the antibody level confirms recent or active infection. PCR (polymerase chain reaction) is used to detect DNA from O tsutsugamushi bacteria. PCR can be done using blood, skin, or lymph node samples.

There is no specific treatment for West Nile virus infection. In most people, the infection clears up on its own in a few weeks. People with mild symptoms do not need any treatment. People who develop meningitis or encephalitis need to be closely monitored by a doctor. They may also need pain medicine to relieve headaches and fluids to treat dehydration.
--- Toxicologist (poison specialist)
Migraines are a common type of recurring headache. This means they come and go. They are usually throbbing and on one side of the head. The cause is not well understood.

Diet-related headaches are triggered by specific foods or drinks. Some foods and drinks contain chemicals that are more likely than others to trigger headaches. These include caffeine, tyramine, sulfites, monosodium glutamate (MSG), and nitrites. Foods like onions, aged chesses, chocolate, and citrus fruits and drinks are triggers for some people. Because diet-related headaches may take up to 72 hours to develop, it can be difficult to link them to a specific trigger.

The diagnosis of cervicogenic headache is controversial. There are no signs or symptoms that doctors can use to clearly identify it. A probable (likely) diagnosis can be made based on a person's medical history and physical exam, including a nervous system assessment. If signs of neurologic (nerve, spine, or brain) problems are seen, imaging tests, such as an MRI, are usually done to find the cause.
--- Thoracic surgeon (heart, chest, and vascular system)

Small DAVFs are usually removed with surgery. For larger fistulas, doctors use a treatment called endovascular embolization. This involves making a small cut in the skin and inserting a thin tube with a camera into the blood vessel. The fistula is then packed with a soft coil or mesh to seal it off and stop it from tearing.
Cardiac headaches are more common in older adults and those with risk factors for heart disease.
--- Surgeon

The artificial sweetener aspartame has sometimes been thought to cause headaches. There is some evidence that the artificial sweetener sucralose can trigger a migraine headache in people who have migraines.

One common aura, scintillating scotoma, is often described as a crescent of multicolored shimmering lights with jagged borders. This starts near the center of vision and expands slowly to cover a large part of the visual field. Other descriptions include TV interference or snow, a pool of water, or a haze. Scintillating scotoma can occur on its own without a headache. This is called ocular migraine, ophthalmic migraine, or silent migraine. It is common in older people.
Some recreational drugs can cause headaches during withdrawal from short-term or long-term use. These drugs include stimulants (such as amphetamines or cocaine), barbiturates, sedatives, and opiates.
A hangover headache is the more common alcohol-induced headache. About two-thirds of people with a hangover have a headache. Symptoms develop after the blood alcohol level returns to normal.
A headache caused by alcohol is usually a throbbing pain felt on both sides of the head. It is often made worse by physical activity.
Serotonin reuptake inhibitors, a class of medications that have been used to treat chronic pain, do not appear to be effective for people with chronic tension-type headaches.

People who have had a cerebellar or brainstem stroke have a sudden feeling of vertigo or dizziness, usually with vomiting and other nervous system symptoms. A headache may occur with a cerebellar stroke. It is usually sudden, severe, and persistent. Some people faint. People may have severe balance problems and feel unstable. They may be unable to sit or stand without help.
80% to 90% of people with migraines also have nausea during an attack. Sensitivity to light or sound causes many people to find a dark, quiet place to lie down during attacks. Drowsiness is common.

Heat-related illnesses include heat exhaustion and heat stroke. Heat exhaustion may occur in response to high temperature or high humidity. People have severe weakness, along with muscle cramps, dizziness, or fainting. It can lead to heat stroke, which is a medical emergency. During heat stroke, people stop sweating and their body temperature rises to over 104F. This can affect brain function and may cause death.

Up to 25% of people with acute onset sarcoidosis have erythema nodosum. This is a skin condition that causes red lumps or nodules under the skin. They are usually found on the shins and may be tender to the touch. The nodules of erythema nodosum slowly disappear within 1 to 2 months.

Altitude sickness is treated based on the severity of the symptoms. For mild to moderate symptoms, moving to a lower altitude (even 1300 to 1600 feet down) may be enough. If available, oxygen can help people recover more quickly. The drug acetazolamide is sometimes given to help people adjust to altitude. Dexamethasone is effective for moderate symptoms, but symptoms may return when the drug is stopped.

A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), such as naproxen or indomethacin, taken twice a day during the 5 to 7 days surrounding the menstrual window may decrease or eliminate the menstrual migraine. Any migraine is also apt to be less severe and more responsive to treatment with a triptan.
Paroxysmal hemicrania can cause many eye, nose, and facial symptoms. Symptoms occur during the headache, usually on the same side of the head.
Headaches may be treated with over the counter pain relievers such as aspirin, acetaminophen (Tylenol), or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin).
People with meningitis usually have a fever. Older people and those with weak immune systems may have only a mild fever or no fever at all.

People with a history of altitude sickness or who must move quickly to a high altitude are often treated with acetazolamide. This is usually done one day before ascending, and for 2 to 3 days afterward. Dexamethasone may also be used.

An elevated level of carboxyhemoglobin in the blood confirms the diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning. The level decreases when exposure stops, so it is not a good indicator of the severity of the poisoning.
--- Pulmonologist (lung specialist)

Cysticercosis is an infection caused by the larvae of the pig tapeworm, called Taenia solium. Tapeworm eggs usually get into the body through water or food that is contaminated with feces. This is more common in places where sanitation and water quality are poor. When a person swallows tapeworm eggs, the larvae hatch in their intestines and travel to their brain, where they form cysts. Larvae may also form cysts in other parts of the body, such as muscles or skin.
Lyme disease is diagnosed with blood tests to check for Borrelia antibodies. If people have a bull's-eye rash and other clear signs of Lyme disease, a blood test may not be needed.
African sleeping sickness is caused by trypanosome parasites. People get them from the bite of an infected tsetse fly. African sleeping sickness is fatal if it isn't treated.

People with acromegaly often develop a large, protruding jawbone. They may also have large, fleshy lips and nose, a bulging forehead, a wide space between their bottom front teeth, and an enlarged tongue. Facial changes may be more obvious in photographs taken over time. In children, the excess in growth hormone leads to a condition called gigantism, causing unusually tall and often obese children.

Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain. It is usually caused by a virus, but fungi, bacteria, parasites, or protozoa can also cause it. Hundreds of different viruses can cause encephalitis. Clues to the specific virus may include the time of year, geographical location, travel history, and whether or not a person has been exposed to animal bites, rodents, or ticks. Symptoms depend on the specific cause.

Treatment decisions for unruptured AVMs are made by weighing the risk of future bleeding against the risk of invasive treatment. For people with a low bleeding risk, treatment may include being monitored by a doctor, managing symptoms (such as headaches and seizures) and treating conditions (such as diabetes or high blood pressure). People with a higher bleeding risk usually need more invasive treatment. This may include surgery, endovascular treatment, or radiotherapy.

Lyme disease can cause numbness, tingling, or shooting pains in the arms or legs. Some people have muscle spasms or weakness, problems with walking, eye inflammation, facial paralysis, or problems with memory, mood, or sleep. They can also have heart problems.

A stroke is a life-threatening emergency that needs immediate medical care. Treatment works best if started within a few hours. If the stroke is caused by a blocked artery, a drug called alteplase (Activase) may be used to dissolve the blood clot. People who cannot take alteplase may be given aspirin. If the stroke is caused by a ruptured artery, surgery may be needed to remove blood from around the brain. Starting rehabilitation soon after a stroke can improve recovery.

African sleeping sickness is widespread in some parts of Africa. People who live in these areas and travelers there are at risk for the disease. In Central and West Africa, the disease mostly affects the rural populations and rarely affects tourists. In East Africa, sleeping sickness affects workers and tourists in the large game parks and national parks.
--- Sleep medicine specialist

Thoracic outlet syndrome can cause pain in the neck or face, the shoulder, shoulder blade area, or upper chest. Symptoms may come and go. They are sometimes brought on by specific arm positions such as reaching out or up. Symptoms may occur during the activity or later.
