The strongest sign of a cervicogenic headache is neck pain that is triggered by movement, which then spreads to the head. Neck movement may be limited. Some people who are diagnosed with this condition have head pain only, without neck pain.

Meningitis often causes problems with alertness and thinking. These problems include drowsiness, lethargy, memory loss, poor attention, disorientation, and personality changes. These types of symptoms are much more common with meningitis caused by bacteria than by a virus.

In adults, Cluster headaches are treated with 100% oxygen. Oxygen is given using a mask for 15 to 20 minutes, at the start of a headache. This may prevent a headache from becoming a cluster attack. Doctors may also prescribe medications called triptans, given as an injection or nasal spray.

In East Africa, most cases of sleeping sickness occur in Tanzania, Uganda, Malawi, and Zambia. In West Africa, most cases occur in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Angola, Sudan, Central African Republic, Republic of Congo, Chad, and northern Uganda.

Even low levels of lead exposure can cause nervous system problems. Early symptoms may include headache, dizziness, fatigue, insomnia, and irritability. Some people have problems with memory, concentration, thinking, or learning. Mood and personality changes, such as depression, anxiety, or mood swings, may occur. Loss of consciousness, convulsions, and brain damage can occur with high levels of lead.
Thoracic outlet syndrome can cause arm numbness, tingling, or pain. An entire arm may go to sleep when doing overhead work or while sleeping.
--- Pain management specialist
Joint pain is a common symptom of lead poisoning. People can also have muscle aches and pains.

Toxic shock syndrome is caused by toxins made by certain bacteria. The bacteria are most often strains of staphylococci or streptococci. Clostridium sordelli causes toxic shock syndrome in a small number of women after a medical abortion. Toxic shock syndrome can quickly become a severe illness with low blood pressure, kidney failure, or death.

Lead pipes, faucets, and lead-based paint may also put people at risk. Paint in homes built before 1950 and pipes in buildings built before the mid-1980s may contain lead. Children are especially at risk from these sources. Other common sources of lead include old ceramic or metal cooking or dinnerware, imported or antique toys, herbal remedies (such as Ayurvedic medicines), and some cosmetics and dyes.

People born with a cervical rib have a higher risk for thoracic outlet syndrome. Thoracic outlet syndrome sometimes develops after an injury to the neck, back, or shoulder. Activities or jobs that involve repeated motions of the arm, hand, or wrist can also lead to thoracic outlet syndrome, such as weight lifting or baseball pitching. People who are older, obese, or women with large breasts also have a higher risk.
--- Mental health specialist or psychiatrist

The headaches may be mild, moderate, or severe. They can be pressing, tightening, or pulsing. The headaches usually affect both sides of the head. They can affect the whole head or just certain regions, such as the back or sides, or the area behind the eyes.

Headaches caused by alcohol usually get better within 24 hours after the person stops drinking. But for some people, it takes up to 3 days to feel better. Over-the-counter pain relievers, such as aspirin or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), may help relieve headaches. Avoid acetaminophen (Tylenol), because it may cause liver damage if you drink alcohol regularly. If avoiding alcohol does not come easily, substance use treatment may be advisable.

A new daily persistent headache can have a short or long course. People with the short-course type are sometimes free of headaches after 3 months and about 75% have the headaches for 2 years or less. But some people have these headaches for several years and do not find relief from treatment.

New daily persistent headache may be triggered by surgery or by a flu-like illness or viral infection, such as Epstein-Barr virus. Stressful life events have also been identified as a possible trigger. About 50% of people with these headaches have no obvious trigger.

Thoracic outlet syndrome can cause headaches and neck pain. The pain may also affect the ear, face, or back of the head. The headaches can be disabling and may occur with certain arm positions, such as reaching overhead.
People with heavy lead exposure and poor hygiene may have a blue-black line on their gums. This sign of lead poisoning used to be common, but is now rare.

Up to 50% of people with intracranial masses have seizures. The seizures may affect a limited part of the brain or can be more widespread. Seizures that affect a small area may become more widespread over time. While seizures can be a first sign of an intracranial tumor or mass, most seizures have other causes.
Treatment for mild lead poisoning involves finding the source of the lead and avoiding it. Often, no other treatment is needed and symptoms go away on their own.
The eye pain of scleritis may radiate to the temples or jaw. Headaches are sometimes the most prominent symptom in people with scleritis.
Some people may find relief by identifying and avoiding foods that trigger headaches. Keeping a diary of symptoms and possible triggers may be helpful.

Lead poisoning is rare today due to better workplace safety and public health measures. But people can still be exposed to lead in some settings. People who work in mining, smelting, welding, and manufacturing may be exposed. Those who do metal sculpting, glass staining, and jewelry making may also come into contact with lead.

People with a subarachnoid hemorrhage may pass out or have a seizure. Other symptoms include trouble speaking, weakness in part of their body, or partial paralysis (not being able to move part of their body). Sometimes, double vision or a drooping eyelid may occur.

Some people with these headaches have other symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light or sound, or a pulsing headache. They may also have certain symptoms that signal that a headache is coming (an aura).
People with headaches caused by eyestrain can get relief by avoiding prolonged visual tasks and resting their eyes. Prescription eyeglasses may also clear up the problem.
Cervicogenic headaches can be caused by diseases and conditions that affect the cervical spine. These include tumors, infections, rheumatoid arthritis, injuries, and fractures.

Carbon monoxide is a gas given off by burning wood or fuel, such as oil, kerosene, or coal. The gas cannot be seen and has no odor. It poisons the body by preventing oxygen from reaching cells. It can also damage the heart and brain. Poisoning usually happens when a fuel-burning device is not working properly.

Acute sinusitis can cause pain and pressure around or behind the eyes, or in the forehead or cheeks. The pain is often on one side of the head or face. Bending over often makes it worse. Headache or face pain usually occurs along with other symptoms, such as a stuffy nose.
--- Rheumatologist (joint and autoimmune diseases)

Pituitary apoplexy is a medical emergency and should be treated by a neurosurgeon to reduce the risk of blindness or nervous system problems. Intravenous (IV) steroids, such as hydrocortisone or dexamethasone, may be given to reduce swelling and pressure and prevent adrenal crisis. If the condition causes vision problems, people often need emergency surgery to reduce pressure on their eye nerves. If the condition is mild, close monitoring may be used instead of surgery.
African sleeping sickness often causes headaches, which may be severe.

Other symptoms include speaking problems, nausea, vomiting, loss of sensation on the face or other parts of the body, paralysis or weakness on one side of the body, and loss of consciousness. Some people have ringing in their ears, called tinnitus. They may also have a drooping eyelid, decreased pupil size, and decreased sweating, a condition called Horner syndrome. A headache may occur with a cerebellar stroke. It is usually sudden, severe, and persistent.

Physical therapy and exercise may help. Manipulation may be effective, but it carries a small risk of stroke, especially with rapid manipulation. If these do not help, injections of steroids or nerve blocks may be tried. A procedure called neurotomy uses radio waves to generate heat in specific nerves to temporarily block pain. In some cases, surgery may be needed.
--- Otolaryngologist (ear, nose, and throat)

The diagnosis of pre-eclampsia is made by finding increased protein levels in the urine of a woman who has developed high blood pressure after the 20th week of pregnancy. Protein in the urine can be detected in the doctor's office with a urine dipstick test. Urine is then collected for 24 hours and the total amount of protein is measured. Protein levels greater than 0.3 mg over 24 hours confirms the diagnosis of pre-eclampsia.

POTS is diagnosed based on a person's medical history and physical exam. Doctors use a tilt table to see if the person's heart rate speeds up when they sit up. An electrocardiogram (ECG) can be done to confirm the type of heart rate problem. Other tests can support the diagnosis. These include tests for norepinephrine levels in the blood, autonomic function tests, and a blood volume assessment.
Many people diagnosed with pituitary apoplexy have risk factors for the condition such as head injury, high blood pressure, diabetes, or sickle cell anemia.
Giant cell arteritis may also cause fever, loss of appetite, weight loss, sweats, and muscle or joint pain.
The diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome is based on a person's medical history and a physical exam. Imaging tests and nerve conduction studies can help confirm the diagnosis.

Acromegaly is a rare condition that causes an excess of growth hormone. This leads to an enlargement of the head, face, hands, feet, and internal organs. It is usually caused by a tumor in the pituitary gland. This noncancerous tumor releases too much growth hormone, which causes the body to overproduce another growth-promoting hormone, called insulin-like growth factor. Symptoms are subtle and develop slowly, often delaying diagnosis for many years.
--- Orthopedic surgeon (bones and joints)
--- Obstetrician or gynecologist (pregnancy and women's health)
Neck stiffness is a common sign of meningitis. Sometimes this occurs only when the neck is gently bent forward. People may also have neck pain and have a hard time bending their neck.
--- Obstetrician (pregnancy)

Pre-eclampsia and eclampsia are serious problems. Any woman with signs or symptoms should see her obstetrician. Complications can include preterm delivery of a low birthweight infant, kidney or liver damage, fluid in the lungs or lung failure, visual disturbances, organ failure, stroke, and death of the baby or mother.

A CT angiogram and Doppler ultrasound can detect compression of an artery within the thoracic outlet. It can be helpful to compare a view of the arm in a neutral position to one in which the arm position causes symptoms.

Encephalitis is suspected based on a person's medical history and physical exam. The diagnosis is confirmed by checking the spinal fluid with a lumbar puncture. This may also help doctors find the cause of infection. Sometimes, an EEG, CT scan, or MRI is done first to support the diagnosis or rule out other causes. If no cause is found and symptoms continue, a brain biopsy may be needed.
An x-ray, MRI, or CT scan can be used to detect anatomic problems that can cause thoracic outlet syndrome. An MRI provides good detail of the structures in the thoracic outlet.

People with this condition can have nervous system problems, called focal neurological findings. They may have speech problems, movement problems, nausea, and vomiting. People may also have vision problems, sensitivity to light or sound, or confusion. Some have symptoms of cerebellar or brainstem dysfunction, such as dizziness, vertigo, or clumsiness.
--- Neurologist (brain and nervous system)

Thoracic outlet syndrome is caused by the compression of nerves or blood vessels in the thoracic outlet, the space between the first rib and the collarbone. This can cause pain, numbness, and tingling in any part of the hand or arm. Most people with thoracic outlet syndrome have nerve compression. In up to 15% of people, an artery is also affected.

During this early phase of the disease, people may also have joint pain, weight loss, weakness, headaches, fatigue, and an increased heart rate. Some people develop a skin rash on the torso, shoulders, buttocks, or thighs. The rash consists of reddened areas, 2 to 4 inches in diameter, with clear centers.
Headaches caused by fasting will usually clear up fairly soon after returning to a normal eating pattern.

Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) is a problem with the way the nervous system controls blood pressure and heart rate. When people with POTS stand up, their heart rate speeds up, often by 30 or more beats per minute. They may feel light-headed or faint.
--- Nephrologist (kidney diseases)
Headaches can start right after exposure, or up to 12 hours later. The type of headache depends on the exact toxin. But it is often a dull, moderate-to-severe pain that affects the whole head.

An intracranial mass is suspected based on a person's medical history and neurological exam. Depending on the signs and symptoms, a CT scan or MRI (or both) is usually needed to confirm the diagnosis, locate the mass, and find its cause. A biopsy may be needed to find the exact cell type if a tumor is found.

A bruit is a sound that doctors can hear through a stethoscope. It is the sound of turbulent blood flow, and it is common in people with an AVM or DAVF. Doctors may hear the bruit when they place the stethoscope on the person's neck (over the carotid artery), near the ear (over the mastoid process), or around the eye.

Lyme disease is an infection with Borrelia bacteria. It is carried by certain ticks. In the US, small hard ticks of the genus Ixodes carry it. They can be as small as a poppy or sesame seed. Lyme disease occurs in many parts of the US. It is especially common in the northeast, north central, and Midatlantic regions, including all New England states, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, Minnesota, and Wisconsin.
Excessive sweating is a common early sign of acromegaly. People sometimes have oily skin with an unpleasant odor.

The treatment for medication overuse headache is to stop the overused medication immediately. Doctors often prescribe a different medication for pain relief or headache prevention during the withdrawal period. Often, the purpose of the new medication is to treat the underlying headache disorder.
--- Hematologist (blood diseases)
Ehrlichiosis is treated with the antibiotic doxycycline (for example, Monodox, Vibramycin). It should be started as soon as the infection is suspected.

Talk with your doctor if you believe a drug, supplement, or substance is causing your symptoms. Your doctor may suggest stopping or tapering off the medication. Symptoms should improve within a few days. Do not stop taking prescribed medication without talking to your doctor first. Sometimes, the problem is a short-term side effect. Your doctor may ask you to wait for the symptoms to pass.

Other symptoms include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and an enlarged, tender liver. Nervous system symptoms can include trouble speaking, vision problems, a spinning sensation (vertigo), increased reflexes, paralysis, and psychosis.
TTP can cause confusion, memory problems, vision problems, weak muscles, paralysis, or seizures. Easy bruising, nosebleeds, blood in urine, and poor kidney function can also occur.

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is a blood clotting disorder. It is caused by loss of an enzyme in the blood clotting system, called ADAMTS13. The enzyme is lost when it is attacked by the body's own immune system. When blood clots form, they can block small blood vessels and cut off blood supply to part of the body. TTP usually affects the brain, kidneys, and digestive tract, and sometimes runs in families.
--- Gastroenterologist (digestive diseases)
People with POTS sometimes develop a mottled, bluish color on their feet when they are standing.

People with POTS may have headaches, including migraines with nausea and sensitivity to light. Headaches are more common in the morning and when people sit or stand up. Lying down may relieve the headache.
--- Endocrinologist (hormones and metabolism)

During pregnancy, the preferred medications for migraines include acetaminophen (Tylenol), or acetaminophen and codeine (Tylenol with Codeine). These drugs are also used for tension headaches during pregnancy. Other narcotics and magnesium may also be given. Narcotics should not be used for long periods of time.

About one week after the bite of an infected tsetse fly, a red, painful skin sore appears where the person was bitten. It usually heals in about three weeks and leaves a scar. This is followed by periods of high fever that last for several days. During this time, people also have swollen lymph nodes. They may also have swelling or itching. An enlarged liver and spleen are also common.
--- Neurosurgeon (brain and nervous system)
Thoracic outlet syndrome may cause arm pain that is worse when reaching overhead.

Migraine medications not usually recommended for pregnant women include butalbital, isometheptene, caffeine, aspirin, naproxen, ibuprofen, and triptan drugs (such as sumatriptan). Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) should not be used for long periods of time. Pregnant women should not use these drugs at all in the third trimester.
--- Maternal and fetal medicine specialist

Pregnant women with disabling migraines may be given medications to help prevent the headaches. These include beta blockers, low-dose tricyclic antidepressants, calcium channel blockers, magnesium, riboflavin (vitamin B2), and topiramate (Topamax).

Joint and muscle pain that comes and goes in different parts of the body are common symptoms of Lyme disease and can occur a few days to weeks after the tick bite. About 60% of people with untreated Lyme disease have joint pain, swelling, and warmth. This condition is called Lyme arthritis. It may not begin until months after the infection. Lyme arthritis usually affects the larger joints, especially the knees.
Non-medication treatments such as rest, massage, heat, and ice may also offer some relief.

Ultrasound and a high-resolution MRI can show changes in the affected arteries to support the diagnosis. MR and CT angiography can also be helpful. These tests involve injecting contrast dye into a vein before taking an image, to give doctors a better view of the blood vessels.

The diagnosis of toxic shock syndrome is based on a person's medical history and physical exam. Other tests, such as blood or tissue cultures, can help doctors identify the bacteria causing the illness.

People with toxic shock syndrome often develop a red rash that may look like severe sunburn. It is usually widespread over the body. People may also have peeling skin 1 to 2 weeks after the rash started.

The sinuses are hollow pockets in the skull, near the nasal passages. Acute sinusitis is sudden inflammation of the sinuses, usually caused by a viral or bacterial infection. It usually affects the sinuses under the cheekbones (maxillary sinuses). But it can occur in other sinuses.

A thunderclap headache is a severe headache that begins suddenly and reaches its maximum intensity within 60 seconds. The headache can last from an hour to several days. Thunderclap headaches can be caused by several serious medical conditions, such as a subarachnoid hemorrhage or a stroke. A person with a thunderclap headache should see a doctor immediately.

Sinusitis is usually diagnosed based on a person's symptoms and physical exam. It may be difficult to tell if sinusitis is caused by a virus or bacteria. Sinus x-rays and CT scans are not recommended unless symptoms last more than 10 days or do not get better with treatment. People who have symptoms for less than 10 days are likely to have viral sinusitis.

Substance use treatment involves a combination of methods. These may include detoxification, behavioral counseling, medications, treatment of depression or anxiety, relapse prevention, and recovery support systems. Detoxification to rid the body of the substance is usually the first step. But most people do not recover without further types of treatment. Medications are frequently used to manage withdrawal symptoms, prevent relapse, and treat related conditions.

Treatments for tension-type headaches include pain relievers, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol), aspirin, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin). To avoid medication overuse headaches, pain relievers should not be taken every day.

Treatment of meningitis depends on the cause. Bacterial meningitis is treated with intravenous (IV) antibiotics, which should be started as soon as possible. A steroid medication called dexamethasone is also sometimes given to lower the risk of complications from the infection. Viral meningitis is usually a less serious disease. It can often be treated outside of the hospital. Antiviral medications may be recommended.

Symptoms of meningitis can also be treated with medications to relieve pain, nausea, vomiting, and fever. It is also important to balance the body's fluids and electrolytes to prevent over- or under-hydration.

People with encephalitis may need intensive care in the hospital, so they can be watched closely. They may also need breathing support. Depending on their symptoms and test results, people may be given antiviral drugs or antibiotics. Some people may need to start these medications before their test results are in. Other medications may be needed for fever and seizures. Autoimmune encephalitis can be reversed with immunotherapy.

Treatments for whiplash injuries include over-the-counter medications, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol) and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin). Sometimes, narcotic pain relievers or muscle relaxants may be needed. Gentle stretching and posture adjustment can aid recovery. A soft, cervical collar may be used when needed for pain, but should not be worn for long periods of time. Physical therapy can also be helpful.

Treatment usually involves surgery to remove the tumor. This may be done by inserting instruments through small incisions in the skin (laparoscopy). Before surgery, medication may be given to reduce the effects of hormones produced by the tumor. Examples include phenoxybenzamine (Dibenzyline), prazosin (Minipress), phentolamine (Regitine), and propranolol (Inderal). Other medications may be used to control blood pressure and heart rate near the time of surgery.
After surgery, people usually have regular checkups to measure hormone levels and check for return of the tumor. If the tumor has spread, treatment may also include radiation and chemotherapy.

The diagnosis of primary thunderclap headache is based on a person's medical history and physical exam. There is no test to confirm the condition. But imaging tests and other procedures are needed to rule out serious causes of the headache, before the diagnosis can be made.
Scleritis can affect one or both eyes. The visible part of the sclera (anterior sclera) is usually involved. But sometimes only the back part (posterior sclera) is affected.

The first symptoms of Takayasu arteritis are usually fever, muscle aches, joint pain, night sweats, loss of appetite, or weight loss. As the disease gets worse, people have little or no pulse. Their arms or legs may tire easily. They may also have high blood pressure and different blood pressure readings in each arm.

People with Takayasu arteritis may have headaches. These are caused by reduced blood flow to the brain caused by a narrowing of the arteries. Headaches are especially common as an early sign of Takayasu arteritis in children.

People who have been to an area where scrub typhus is common and have flu-like symptoms and a black, scabbed skin sore may have scrub typhus. Scrub typhus occurs mainly in Japan, China, India, Australia, the South Pacific, and eastern or southeast Asia. People are at risk if they travel to or have recently lived in these parts of the world, especially if they were in rural areas.

A headache caused by diving is usually not serious and should go away within 3 days after the dive ends or quickly with oxygen. If it doesn't or if there are other symptoms such as problems breathing, confusion, or incoordination, you should seek medical attention immediately. These may be a sign of a more serious condition such as decompression sickness.

A hypnic headache is a dull and sometimes throbbing headache that awakens one from sleep. It usually occurs at the same time each night, often between 1 AM and 3 AM. It rarely occurs during daytime sleeping. Hypnic headaches are usually at the front of the head, and less often in the back of the head or neck.
Many people with cardiac headaches have other symptoms that are associated with a heart problem, like chest pain.

Cluster headaches occur in sets of severe headaches separated by periods with no headaches. Cluster headaches often occur with other symptoms, such as eye watering, pupil constriction, or runny or stuffy nose. These symptoms may be due to irritation of a cranial nerve.

Long-term, excessive intake of caffeine can cause headaches that are similar to tension-type headaches. Suddenly stopping or reducing regular caffeine use can cause headaches. A headache usually develops within 24 hours of the last caffeine intake. Headaches caused by caffeine withdrawal (for example, if a person quits drinking coffee) usually clear up in about a week without treatment.

Sarcoidosis that affects the nervous system is called neurosarcoidosis. It occurs in less than 10% of people with sarcoidosis. It can cause headaches. People may also have seizures, signs of brain and nerve problems, and weakness.

Symptoms, such as dizziness, vertigo, coordination problems, or fainting, can be signs of a condition in the posterior fossa region, near the bottom of the skull. If head pain occurs with other symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, bloodshot eyes, excessive tearing, or a runny, stuffy nose, it may be caused by another condition.

About 40% of people, have an underlying condition that causes the cough headache. Conditions include structural malformations or intracranial masses, often in the posterior fossa region, near the bottom of the skull. The rest have no specific cause of the headache.
Headaches, fatigue, and dizziness are common early symptoms of hyperviscosity syndrome.

Symptoms of scleritis develop over several weeks. They include eye pain, an eyeball that is tender to the touch, red eyes, sensitivity to light, blurry vision, and excess tears. Eye pain may be severe and it can spread to the sinuses, jaw, temple, or front or side of the head.

The CSF or blood can be cultured for bacteria, fungi, or viruses. CSF cultures are positive in 80% of people with bacterial meningitis. Other tests, including Gram stains, PCR, and special rapid tests, may be used to check for specific organisms in the CSF or blood. They may help provide a quicker diagnosis. But cultures are still needed to determine which antibiotics will be best, if there is a bacterial infection.

Treatment is often needed for 6 months to several years. The headache is usually treated with the drug indomethacin (Indocin, Tivorbex). Other treatments that have been successful in small studies of adults are topiramate (Topamax), acetazolamide (Diamox), or lumbar puncture.

Often, preventing the trigger will prevent a cough headache. Triggers of cough, such as a lung disease, should be diagnosed and treated. People who take medications that cause cough, such as an ace inhibitor, should talk to their doctor about switching to another medication. If an MRI shows that the headache is caused by another condition, treating it often resolves the problem.

People with this condition may not have a headache every time they have sex. For some people it only happens a few times, but up to 40% of people have repeat headaches for a year or more. This type of headache can occur in any sexually active person, regardless of age or gender. But it is slightly more common in men. Experts are not sure why sexual activity triggers headaches in some people, but not in others.

Besides headaches, the most common symptoms are confusion and nervous system problems. These can include partial paralysis on one side of the body, uncoordinated walking or limb movements, seizures or difficulty speaking. People sometimes have signs of increased intracranial pressure such as vision loss.

There is no single test to confirm Behcet's disease. It is diagnosed based on a person's medical history and physical exam. It is suspected when people have some combination of mouth sores, skin symptoms, blood vessel disease, genital sores, and eye disease. Several sets of diagnostic criteria have been proposed to help doctors diagnose Behcet's disease. But some people with Behcet's disease do not fit the criteria.

To confirm that the pain is being caused by a cervical problem, doctors inject anesthetic into the cervical nerves in the neck. If this stops the pain, it means the pain was being caused by a cervical problem.

Ringing or other noise in one or both ears is called tinnitus. It can be a symptom of a DAVF and AVM. It may occur in only one ear and seem to throb along with a person's pulse. The sounds are caused by turbulent blood flow near the inner ear.
The headache is often triggered by physical exertion, sexual activity, stress, sneezing, bathing, showering, swimming, or straining (as with a bowel movement or coughing).
The headache may be so severe that the person is agitated or confused, screams, cries, or collapses.

A DAVF is an abnormal connection between an artery and a vein in the membrane that covers the brain (dura). Symptoms of this often develop slowly over months or a year, but can develop more quickly. Most DAVF have no known cause, but sometimes they can be caused by a brain injury, infection, or blocked vein. DAVFs are most common in adults in their 50s and 60s.

Tension-type headaches are the most common type of headache. Almost everyone has at least one at some time in their life. Many people never seek treatment from a doctor. But some who have frequent or constant headaches that affect their activities or quality of life may seek medical care. This type of headache was once thought to be caused by psychological stress, but it is now believed to be related to the nervous system.

The diagnosis of scleritis is considered based on a person's medical history and an eye exam, including a slit-lamp exam. A slit-lamp exam involves shining a bright light into the eye in a thin beam. Doctors also use special eye drops to identify episcleritis from scleritis. Other tests may be needed to find the cause of scleritis.

When no serious cause can be found for this headache, it is called a primary thunderclap headache. A primary thunderclap headache is extremely painful, but is not a life-threatening condition. This diagnosis is not made until after a doctor has ruled out all other serious causes.

People with a primary thunderclap headache may have nausea and vomiting, but this can also be a sign of a more serious problem. Other symptoms that suggest a serious problem that needs emergency care include fever, neck pain or stiffness, eyes that are sensitive to light, loss of vision or sensation, weakness, numbness, tingling, confusion, changes in speech or thinking, or trouble swallowing.

Up to 15% of people with AVMs have headaches. Often, AVM headaches do not have any special symptoms. So they may be hard to tell from regular headaches. The pain may affect one or both sides of the head, and may feel throbbing or migraine-like. Some people have widespread head pain. DAVFs may also cause headaches.

Damage to the nerves that control eye movement can cause eye pain and trouble moving the eye. The condition is called painful ophthalmoplegia. This damage can occur in a number of syndromes including cavernous sinus syndrome and Tolosa-Hunt syndrome.

If there is a known trigger for the headaches, such as sexual activity, taking a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) such as indomethacin (Indocin) beforehand may prevent the headaches. Another treatment is gabapentin (Neurontin), which is used to treat nerve pain. If the headaches are frequent, a blood pressure medication may help. Vasoconstricting drugs, such as ergots or triptans, that are used to treat other types of headaches should be avoided.
Some people with exercise headache have migraine-like symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light or sound. Other common symptoms include double vision and a stiff neck.

Jaw problems are called temporomandibular disorders (TMD). These are a set of problems that affect the muscles and bones of the jaw, including the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). This joint is located just in front of and below the ear.

Dental problems affect the teeth, gums, and other parts of the mouth. The most common dental problem is tooth decay. Decay is caused by the breakdown of tooth enamel from sugary or acidic foods and drinks. Other dental problems are caused by injury or infection.

Other options include an injection of dihydroergotamine or lidocaine given in a nasal spray. These have been shown to be effective in some people with cluster headaches. Other medications, including verapamil, prednisone, anti-seizure medication, or lithium may be used at the start of a cluster headache attack to keep it from getting worse.
Some people with giant cell arteritis have scalp tenderness. This can make it hard to brush or comb their hair. Even resting their head on a pillow might be painful.

Dental-related headaches are often diagnosed based on a person's medical history and a physical exam. Standard x-rays of the teeth can confirm decay, infection, or fracture of a tooth. MRI or a CT scan can reveal hard or soft tissue abnormalities related to TMD, but may be reserved for more serious cases.

In the early stage of HIV, the body does not yet have HIV antibodies that can be found with blood tests. But doctors can now do a blood test to look for antigens (usually the p-24 antigen) and antibodies at the same time. These tests can find the virus within 3 weeks of infection, which is earlier than an antibody test alone. These tests are recommended when the risk of recent infection is high. If the first test is positive for HIV, it must be confirmed with a second test.

In people with hyperviscosity syndrome, an eye exam called funduscopic evaluation may show swelling of the optic disk (papilledema), abnormal bleeding of the blood vessels in the retina (retinal hemorrhage), and retinal veins that appear dilated and segmented with a link-sausage appearance.

Many people with primary exercise headache have a history of migraine headaches or a family member with migraines. Up to 40% of people with sexual activity-related headache also have a headache with other exertional activities.

Hyperviscosity syndrome is a group of symptoms caused by abnormally thick blood. It can occur in people with diseases that cause high levels of one or more parts of the blood, such as serum proteins, red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets. People with hyperviscosity syndrome often have a mix of bleeding symptoms, eye or vision problems, and nervous system signs. Hyperviscosity syndrome can be a life-threatening medical emergency.

Pseudomigraine is a rare condition. It involves migraine-like headaches along with nervous system symptoms and an increased number of cells in the cerebrospinal fluid. People have no headaches between episodes. The episodes usually stop after about 3 months, but can return. About one-third of people with pseudomigraine have had a viral-like illness with fatigue, coughing, diarrhea, runny nose, or fever up to 3 weeks before. The cause of this condition is unknown.

People with meningitis often have nausea, vomiting, eye sensitivity to light, and pain with eye movement. Viral meningitis can cause muscle aches, loss of appetite, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Up to 40% of people with bacterial meningitis have seizures. Some people have low body temperatures, called hypothermia. Other symptoms depend on the cause of meningitis. For example, meningococcal meningitis, which is caused by bacteria, can cause a skin rash.

The decision to treat an unruptured intracranial aneurysm depends on several factors, including the risk of a life-threatening rupture, the size and location of the aneurysm, and a person's age and health history. Usually unruptured aneurysms that are causing symptoms or are larger than 7mm are treated. Treatment includes either brain surgery to clip the aneurysm or an endovascular method called coil embolization to block and destroy the aneurysm.

A bone marrow sample may be taken with a needle or biopsy to help diagnose primary polycythemia. Bone marrow or blood samples may show the JAK2 mutation, which is present in up to 95% of people with primary polycythemia. Sometimes doctors will also look for secondary causes of polycythemia, such as heart or lung disease or kidney tumors.

A person suspected of having a stroke should get emergency medical help immediately. For a bleeding stroke, doctors may give medication to stabilize blood pressure, help the blood clot, or prevent pressure on the brain. Surgery or other methods may be needed to stop bleeding and remove blood that has collected from the brain.

For a stroke caused by a blockage, doctors may give a medication called tissue plasminogen activator to break up the clot. Some people also need surgery to relieve pressure in the brain or remove the blockage. Aspirin is sometimes given to prevent new clots. Other emergency treatments may be needed to lower blood pressure, prevent swelling in the brain, or control blood sugar.
After emergency treatment, people may need medication to control their blood pressure and cholesterol. They may also need physical, occupational, and speech therapy.

People with a suspected TIA also need emergency medical help immediately. Treatment often depends on the person's risk for another TIA or stroke. An anti-platelet drug, such as aspirin, may be given. Treatment may also include blood-thinning drugs for atrial fibrillation, and drugs to lower blood pressure and cholesterol. Smokers who have had a stroke or TIA are advised to quit smoking.

People with brucellosis may have a loss of appetite, weight loss, or constipation. Other symptoms include foul-smelling sweat, headaches, fatigue, and a cough. People may have neurologic symptoms, but this is not common. Doctors may find swollen lymph nodes, an enlarged liver or spleen, or scrotal swelling in men during a physical exam.

Some people with giant cell arteritis have jaw pain when they chew. This is caused by poor blood flow to the muscles used for chewing. Some people also have tongue pain that comes and goes, or pain with swallowing.
Other symptoms of a hangover include tiredness, concentration problems, dizziness, thirst, nausea, vomiting, and dehydration.

Migraine is a condition of recurring headaches. Migraine headaches can be disabling. About 15% of women have these headaches. Women who have migraines often have them around the time of their menstrual period. Migraine that occurs between 2 days before and 3 days after the start of menses (the menstrual "window") is called menstrual migraine. Menstrual migraine is caused by a drop in estrogen levels.

One theory to explain why some people get sick in response to indoor air pollutants is that genetics and the environment both play a role in causing the symptom pattern referred to as sick building syndrome. A small number of people may have genes that increase their risk of an exaggerated immune response to particular airborne irritants or triggers. This so-called autoimmune response causes inflammation in different parts of the body that cause the symptoms.

Most cases of whiplash injury are associated with rear-end motor vehicle collisions. Whiplash can be caused by other injuries, such as sports-related injuries. Other neck problems, such as cervical ligament rupture or an intervertebral disk injury, can occur at the same time.

A subarachnoid hemorrhage is life-threatening, so prompt diagnosis and treatment are very important. People with this condition are admitted to an intensive care unit (ICU) so doctors can closely monitor their brain, heart, lungs, blood vessels, and other factors. The drug nimodipine (Nymalize) is usually given to prevent blood vessel spasms. Drugs may also be needed to lower blood pressure, if it is too high.
Mineral supplements, such as iron, calcium, magnesium, and zinc, are prescribed for some people. These may help reduce symptoms and slow lead absorption.

Brucellosis is an infection with Brucella bacteria that people get from animals. These are usually farm animals, such as cows, pigs, sheep, or goats. People can also get brucellosis from unpasteurized dairy products. Symptoms start several days to 4 weeks after exposure. They include fever, night sweats, and joint pain. Many people also have vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain.

Hyperviscosity syndrome is suspected based on a person's medical history and physical exam. Hyperviscosity can be diagnosed by measuring the thickness (viscosity) of the blood. A level over 4 cP is likely to cause symptoms, but this can vary from person to person.
If an aneurysm is the cause of the bleeding, prompt treatment is needed to repair the artery and reduce the risk of new bleeding. This is usually done with surgery.

If giant cell arteritis is suspected, a blood test is used to measure inflammation in the body. This can be done with an ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) or CRP (C-reactive protein) test. Both tests measure proteins in the body, called acute phase reactants. A low or normal level of these proteins makes the disease less likely, but does not rule it out completely. A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis.
A low level of hemoglobin in the blood is a sign of anemia (a low red blood cell count). Hemolytic anemia, the abnormal breakdown of red blood cells, is one of the main signs of TTP.
Painful ophthalmoplegia typically causes a severe headache around one eye with decreased, painful eye movements.

Other symptoms can include vision problems, an enlarged pupil, a reduced corneal reflex, drooping eyelid. Some people experience a loss of sensation in the distribution of the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve. This includes the eyes, nose, eyelids, eyebrows, and forehead.

Nummular headaches have been treated with pain relievers, such as NSAIDs, tricyclic antidepressants, gabapentin (Gralise, Horizant, Neurontin), and indomethacin (Indocin, Tivorbex). Some doctors may prescribe medications when there is no pain to prevent the headaches. Some studies show botulinum toxin (Botox) injections and transcutaneous nerve stimulation (TENS) may also be effective.

A stroke is a potentially life-threatening brain injury caused by a loss of blood supply. Strokes are often due to a disease that affects the blood vessels in the brain. They can be caused by a buildup of fatty deposits in the arteries, called atherosclerosis, or by a blood clot that travels to the brain and blocks the blood vessels. A blood vessel can also rupture and cause bleeding into the brain.

Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS) is a condition in which narrowing of arteries in the brain causes sudden and severe headaches. The condition is temporary and usually lasts from 1 to 3 months. The cause is not known.
Sexual activity headaches can be prevented by taking medication 30 minutes before sex. Doctors usually prescribe the drug indomethacin (Indocin, Tivorbex). Triptans may also be given.

People with certain genetic disorders have a higher risk of pheochromocytoma. This includes people with multiple endocrine neoplasia, von Hippel-Lindau disease, and neurofibromatosis. People with a family history of pheochromocytoma also have a higher risk.

The diagnosis of RCVS requires the detection of many areas of constriction in the large or medium-sized arteries in the brain. Imaging tests that show blood flow in the arteries in the brain can support the diagnosis. These can include a conventional imaging test, or an MR or CT angiogram.

Diagnosis is based on a person's medical history and a physical exam. Imaging with a CT scan or MRI can help rule out other causes of the symptoms. Certain imaging findings and a relief of symptoms in response to steroid medications also support the diagnosis.

A hypertensive emergency occurs when very high blood pressure begins to harm organs such as the brain, heart, kidneys, and eyes. This can happen when the blood pressure is higher than 180/120 mm Hg. High blood pressure from any cause can lead to a hypertensive emergency.
Most people will have continuing problems with their pituitary function and usually require adrenal, thyroid, or reproductive hormone replacement therapy.

Vision and eye movement problems, such as double vision or partial loss of vision, are common symptoms. When these occur with a sudden severe headache, pituitary apoplexy should be considered as a diagnosis.

Primary stabbing headaches do not usually start until the 4th decade of life and are rarely found in children. They are more common in people with migraine headaches and usually affect the same part of the head as the migraines.

A primary stabbing headache is so short there is usually not enough time to take a medication to relieve it. If it is happening frequently, it is usually treated with the preventive drug indomethacin (Indocin, Tivorbex). Other medications that have been tried include celecoxib (Celebrex), gabapentin (Neurontin) and melatonin.

Long-term use of some medicines can cause intracranial hypertension and headache. These include anabolic steroids, amiodarone, lithium carbonate, nalidixic acid, thyroid hormone replacement therapy, tetracycline and minocycline.

Dental problems often cause head and jaw pain that ranges from a lasting, dull ache to sudden, severe shocks. Headaches can also be caused by teeth grinding (bruxism), teeth clenching, and nail biting.

Bleeding may also occur in the digestive, genital, or urinary tract. Other symptoms may include hearing loss, ringing in the ears, dizziness, a spinning sensation (vertigo), lack of coordination, mental changes, confusion, heart failure, and stroke.

Hyperviscosity syndrome is usually a complication of a known blood disease, such as leukemia, multiple myeloma, or Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia. Rarely, it is a complication of an autoimmune disease, such as lupus, Sjogren syndrome, or rheumatoid arthritis.
Dental infection is often caused by an untreated cavity or other tooth damage. Symptoms of a dental infection include toothache, headache, tenderness, bad breath, abscess, and facial swelling.
TMD can be caused by teeth grinding, injury, or stress. The disorder is more common in women than in men, and is rare in children.
Many people with celiac disease have severe mouth sores that come and go. This condition is called aphthous stomatitis.
--- Dentist

TMD often causes pain, limited movement, and locking of the jaw. Most people with TMD have frequent headaches and can hear a clicking or popping in the jaw. Symptoms can begin suddenly, or they can develop slowly over time.
Long or high-level exposures can cause chest pain, weakness, low blood pressure, abnormal heart rhythms, and shortness of breath.

The headaches of pseudomigraine are moderate to severe and throbbing. They are usually felt on both sides of the head, but sometimes occur on the side opposite the nervous system symptoms. Some people have headaches with no other symptoms. The average headache lasts from 6 to 19 hours, but it can last for days. Most people with pseudomigraine do not have a history of migraine headaches.

Jaw problems can also cause tooth sensitivity, eye pain, ear pain, ringing in the ears, dizziness, and neck pain or neck stiffness. Some people may also have swelling, numbness, weakness, bleeding, drainage, or tooth loss.

Headaches are common when a stroke is caused by bleeding into the brain. At the same time, people usually have other signs or symptoms of brain injury, such as weakness, confusion, or vision problems.

Some people with RCVS have nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light, and agitation. They may have temporary high blood pressure. Nervous system symptoms may also be temporary. They can include vision problems, difficulty speaking or swallowing, sensation or movement problems on one side of the body, and seizures.

Diets high in sugary foods and drinks, poor oral hygiene, and lack of dental care can increase the risk of tooth decay and other dental problems in children and adults. Medications that cause dry mouth may also cause dental problems.

Cavities are usually treated by cleaning out tooth decay and repairing the tooth with a filling. Deeper tooth infections may need root canal therapy, or the tooth may need to be removed. Other oral infections may need to be drained of pus or treated with antibiotics.
Some people with RCVS develop serious complications, such as subarachnoid hemorrhage, intracerebral hemorrhage, TIAs (transient ischemic attacks), and stroke.

Early treatment of TMD may include rest, education about avoiding habits that trigger symptoms, and relaxation training. Pain may be treated with short-term nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) or naproxen (Aleve). Some adults may be given a short course of muscle relaxants. If pain continues, adults may be given tricyclic antidepressant medications, such as amitriptyline and nortriptyline (Pamelor).

The sudden onset of a very severe headache (thunderclap headache), especially if it is associated with other nervous system symptoms, could indicate an aneurysm that is increasing in size or has ruptured. Otherwise, the headache associated with an intracranial aneurysm lacks distinctive features. It can be acute or chronic, localized or widespread, or felt on one or both sides of the head. Sometimes it throbs with the pulse or is felt as pain behind or above the eyes.
Physical therapy or a mouth guard may also help with pain. Surgery for TMD is not usually recommended.

Most people with acute retroviral syndrome get better from the flu-like illness in several weeks. They may have no other HIV symptoms for months or years. Antiretroviral treatment (ART) can prevent, postpone, or reduce immune system damage that occurs over time without treatment. ART also lowers the risk of spreading HIV to others. Doctors can help people decide when to start ART.

People with somatization disorder usually experience multiple physical symptoms before the age of 30. Besides headache, other common symptoms include pain in the abdomen, chest, back, joints, arms, or legs, diarrhea, vomiting, nausea, shortness of breath, dizziness, tiredness, weakness, and sleep problems. Women may have menstrual problems and men may have erection problems. These symptoms are often very distressing to the person and may cause problems with daily functioning.

Concussions are diagnosed based on a person's medical history, along with a neurological and mental status exam. Imaging tests of the brain do not usually show any changes in brain function. But some people may need a skull x-ray, or an MRI or CT scan of their brain to check for other disorders.

A concussion is a minor head injury that temporarily affects the brain. Concussions can happen during sports or car wrecks, or any other accident that causes the head to hit something or jars it violently, such as with whiplash. People can briefly lose consciousness and have memory loss right after the injury. People with symptoms after a head injury should get medical care.
The diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder is based on a pattern of symptoms and physical exams over years to exclude more serious causes of headache.

Most subarachnoid hemorrhages can be found with a CT scan, or if needed, an MRI. When the hemorrhage involves only a small amount of blood, it may not be detectable with imaging. The doctor may do a spinal tap to detect blood in the spinal fluid. A CT angiogram is often done to find the source of the bleeding and guide surgical decisions.

People with subdural or epidural hematomas can have nervous system problems, called focal neurological findings. Depending on where their injury is, people may have weakness or loss of feeling in parts of their head or body. They may also have trouble with speech, writing, or other brain activities. A hematoma can cause an enlarged pupil, overactive reflexes, and swallowing problems. These signs can be subtle and go unnoticed without a careful exam by a doctor.

Parrots and parakeets are a common source of psittacosis infection. But other birds can spread the disease, including ducks and turkeys. In recent years, this disease has usually affected workers at poultry processing plants or in people with pet birds.

Subdural and epidural hematomas can cause thinking problems and changes in mental state. Symptoms include feeling or acting less alert, attention problems, loss of interest, drowsiness, confusion, and personality changes. Changes in mental state may begin as soon as an injury occurs, but can also occur hours or days later.
Subdural and epidural hematomas are pockets of blood in the skull that can put pressure on the brain and cause serious problems. They result from bleeding in the skull, often from a head injury.

Triptans, such as rizatriptan (Maxalt) and sumatriptan (Imitrex), are the most effective medications for treating menstrual migraine attacks. Magnesium, estrogen, and dihydroergotamine (DHE) have also been effective. These medications work best when taken early in the attack.
RCVS is associated with migraines, marijuana, decongestants, antidepressants, childbirth, exercise or straining, stress, and sex.

Primary CNS angiitis is diagnosed by finding blood vessel abnormalities on brain or vascular imaging or with a brain biopsy. Before the diagnosis of primary central nervous system angiitis can be made, other diseases may need to be ruled out.

Epidural hematomas occur between the skull and the lining of the brain. They are often caused by bleeding from an artery. Symptoms usually appear within hours after a blow to the head. Some people may not have symptoms at first, but their brain function usually gets worse within hours as the hematoma expands.
--- Neurosurgeon (brain and nervous system surgeon)

Low CSF pressure can cause neck pain or stiffness, pain between the shoulder blades, and nausea or vomiting. Some people have nervous system symptoms, such as double vision, blurred vision, a sensitivity to light, or hearing problems. They may have dizziness, arm or hand numbness, uncoordinated movement, an unsteady walk, problems with bladder or bowel control, or problems with mental function. Sometimes the symptoms come and go.

Subdural hematomas occur between the inner and outer linings of the brain. They are usually caused by bleeding from a vein. Veins bleed more slowly than arteries, so symptoms can take days or weeks to appear. Coma or death can occur if the injury is not treated quickly. Sometimes, epidural and subdural hematomas occur without a head injury. This is less common, but can be caused by bleeding from a tumor, infection, or blood clotting problems.

One study found that more than 25% of all psychoactive substance users reported headaches with use. Users of benzodiazepines, methylamphetamine, cocaine, heroin, or volatile solvents were more likely than others to get headaches. Most users never sought help from doctors for their headaches.

People with severe lead poisoning need a treatment called chelation as soon as possible to prevent more serious damage. This is an oral or intravenous (IV) treatment that removes lead from the blood. Chelation is used for children with a blood lead level of 45 mcg/dL or higher. Chelation may be recommended for adults with BLL over 70 mcg/dL. If symptoms are severe enough, chelation may be used at lower blood lead levels.

The diagnosis of pseudomigraine is based mainly on a person's medical history and a physical exam. It can be supported with testing. Pseudomigraines are preceded by symptoms of brain or nerve dysfunction. Testing of spinal fluid often reveals increased pressure around the brain and spinal cord and white blood cells (mostly lymphocytes) in the fluid. An EEG, a recording of brain waves from electrodes on the scalp, often shows abnormalities that support the diagnosis.

Subdural and epidural hematomas can occur in people who do not recall having a head injury. This is more common in older people, people who take medication to thin their blood (anticoagulants ), and people who abuse alcohol.
Subdural and epidural hematomas often cause headaches that become steadily worse.

Subdural and epidural hematomas are medical emergencies. If pressure in the brain is high enough, doctors may drill one or more small holes in the skull to relieve the pressure. For large hematomas, a surgery called a craniotomy is used to remove blood clots through a larger opening in the skull. Sometimes, the bleeding blood vessel can be found and repaired.

People with an intracranial mass may have nervous system problems, called focal neurological findings. They may have weakness or loss of sensation in areas of the head or body. They can also have trouble with speech, writing, or other brain activities. These signs can be subtle and go unnoticed without a careful examination by a doctor.

Lyme disease can cause severe headaches within days or weeks of a tick bite. The headaches may begin after the rash or as part of the flu-like illness. Some people develop an inflammation of the brain or membranes around the brain and spinal cord, called encephalitis and meningitis. This can also cause severe headaches, several weeks or months after the rash.

Blood tests are available to detect antibodies to strains of the Borrelia spirochete. The antibodies may not be found during the first few days of illness. Repeat antibody testing is often done in 1 to 2 weeks. A higher antibody level on repeat testing confirms recent or active infection. A high antibody level in a single blood sample also confirms the diagnosis.

Most people with relapsing fever have headaches, muscle aches, joint pain, chills, nausea, or vomiting along with fever. They may also have abdominal pain, confusion, a dry cough, eye pain, diarrhea, dizziness, eye sensitivity to light, or neck pain. Less common signs include skin rash, painful urination, yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice), and an enlarged liver or spleen.
Many people with sarcoidosis have eye problems. The most common is uveitis, which causes eye pain, tearing, blurry vision, or sensitivity to light.
Bleeding from the nose, mouth, skin, or digestive tract can occur. Some people may bruise easily.

The diagnosis of relapsing fever is made by detecting or isolating spirochetes in the blood. This is best done during a fever episode, when the number of organisms in the blood is the highest. Spirochetes may be seen with a thin smear or thick drop of blood stained with Wright or Giemsa stain. The use of fluorescent stains with specialized microscopes may also help make the organism more visible.

About 20% of people are diagnosed due to non-life threatening symptoms from blood clots or bleeding in small blood vessels. Some have poor blood circulation in their brain that causes nervous system symptoms. A few people have a major event, such as a stroke, a blood clot in a major artery or vein, or a heart attack. Sometimes, the condition turns into leukemia and is found during testing for that condition.

People with non-life-threatening symptoms are usually treated with low-dose aspirin therapy, which often improves symptoms within a few days. People with no symptoms do not usually need treatment. But they should be aware of their risk for serious problems due to blood clots or bleeding.

Some people with acromegaly have headaches. The headaches are often dull and last all day. They are the result of pressure inside the skull from the pituitary tumor, as well as the effects of the growth hormone excess. Some people have eye symptoms along with the headache, depending on the size and location of the tumor.

People with life-threatening blood clots are treated immediately with plasmapheresis and chemotherapy. Plasmapheresis removes blood from the body and replaces it with treated or replacement blood and fluids. Chemotherapy stops overproduction of platelets. People with a high risk of complications may also be given chemotherapy to reduce their risk.

A recent study argues that there is no strong link between frequent medication use and frequent headache, and that few people benefit from discontinuing headache medication. It may be that people with poorly controlled headaches simply take more medication without benefit, not that taking the medication causes or worsens headaches.

Along with fatigue, symptoms include headaches, concentration and memory problems, sore throat, tender lymph nodes, muscle aches, joint aches, sleep problems, and extreme fatigue after activity. Other signs include depression, anxiety, allergies, feverishness, and abdominal cramps.

The diagnosis of cerebral venous thrombosis is made with an MRI or CT scan of the brain. A contrast dye is often injected into a vein, so that brain structures will show up better on an MRI or CT scan. This is called a MR or CT angiogram. Sometimes, an angiogram is done with an x-ray.

There is no test to confirm chronic fatigue syndrome. The diagnosis is based on a person's medical history and physical exam. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention defines this condition as having severe fatigue for at least 6 months. Other conditions that cause fatigue must be ruled out.

Brucellosis can be diagnosed by culturing the bacteria from a person's blood, body fluid, or tissue. Newer culture systems can detect the bacteria within 3 days of infection. Blood tests are also available to detect antibodies to Brucella organisms. Repeat testing for antibodies may be needed. Higher levels of antibodies on repeat testing confirms a recent infection. PCR testing is also available in some labs and can be useful when other tests are negative.

Some people with celiac disease develop an itchy skin rash called dermatitis herpetiformis. This is a rash of small, raised bumps and blisters. They may be found on the arms and legs, as well as the torso, scalp, and neck. Most people with celiac disease do not have the rash. But people with this rash usually do have celiac disease.

Celiac disease often causes indigestion, diarrhea, constipation, nausea, and vomiting. Some people have weight loss, arthritis, loss of tooth enamel, loss of muscle tone, coordination problems, absence of menstrual periods, and depression. A lab test may show anemia (low red blood cell count).

Other symptoms of toxic shock syndrome include dizziness, fainting, rapid heartbeat, sore throat, and cough. People may also have swelling in the ankles, legs, or genitals, or numbness and tingling. They may have sensitivity to bright light. A physical exam may reveal an enlarged liver or lung crackles. Women may have redness of the vagina or cervix and may experience discomfort during a pelvic exam.

Celiac disease is more common in people with an autoimmune condition. These include lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, type 1 diabetes, myasthenia gravis, Graves' disease, Addison's disease, and Sjogren's syndrome. It is also more common in people who have a parent or sibling with celiac disease.

People with encephalitis may have a reduced level of consciousness. This can range from drowsiness or lethargy to a coma. Other possible symptoms include confusion, behavior or personality changes, agitation, hallucinations, or psychosis.

Toxic shock syndrome is a medical emergency that requires immediate treatment. Most people are in shock by the time they seek treatment or within 4 to 6 hours of going to the emergency room. People are usually admitted to an intensive care unit (ICU) where they are closely monitored and treated with therapies to stabilize them. At first, treatment may include intravenous (IV) fluids and breathing support.
Headaches typically associated with sleep disorders are those that awaken one from sleep or are present in the morning upon awakening.

The cause of the infection also needs immediate treatment. Foreign materials that may be causing the infection, such as tampons or nasal packing, are removed. Surgery may be needed to drain abscesses or to remove infected or dead tissue.

Antibiotics for the infection are usually started as soon as possible, without waiting for test results. Often, antibiotics are started in the emergency room. Other people in the infected person's household may also need antibiotic treatment.

Hyperviscosity is a medical emergency that is treated in the hospital with plasmapheresis. During this process, blood is removed from the body, treated, and then returned to the body. Plasma (the fluid part of blood) may be replaced with albumin or saline. This treatment can reverse vision and retinal problems quickly. The problem that is causing hyperviscosity also needs to be treated to prevent the condition from happening again.
If an aneurysm ruptures, people may also have nausea, vomiting, neck pain, lethargy, and sensitivity to light.
Eye or vision problems are common in people with hyperviscosity syndrome. These symptoms include blurry vision, double vision, and involuntary eye movements.

The common cold can be diagnosed by a person's medical history and physical exam. Testing can detect specific viruses, but this is rarely needed. Some serious conditions have early symptoms similar to those of a cold, so people should see a doctor if symptoms do not improve.
Intracranial aneurysms can place pressure on facial sensory nerves, causing facial pain or pain behind the eye.

People with RCVS usually have a severe headache that begins suddenly, called a thunderclap headache. The headache is usually widespread on both sides or at the back of the head. It can last for just a few minutes or for more than 24 hours. People tend to have many, recurrent headaches. People who also have a history of migraine or cluster headaches say that an RCVS headache is quite different.

The common cold is a mild infection of the upper airways and nose caused by a virus. Over 50% of colds in adults are caused by a rhinovirus. Other viruses include coronavirus, parainfluenza virus, respiratory syncytial virus, influenza virus, and adenovirus. Adults usually have 2 to 4 colds a year. Colds are common because many different viruses can cause them.

Illness begins 12 to 72 hours after exposure to a cold virus. It can last from 1 to 2 weeks. A runny or stuffy nose, sore throat, and sneezing are usually the first symptoms. These symptoms peak on the second or third day. A cough may also begin within the first few days. Often, it will continue or get worse after the runny, stuffy nose has improved.

Polycythemia occurs when a person's bone marrow makes too many red blood cells. This makes the blood thicker and causes various symptoms. When this condition is caused by a genetic problem, it is called primary polycythemia. The most common type of primary polycythemia is polycythemia vera.

The excess in growth hormones also raises a person's risk of heart disease, diabetes, high blood pressure, and colon cancer. It also raises the risk of sleep apnea, a condition in which breathing stops briefly during sleep. As a result, people with acromegaly often have a shortened life span.

Polycythemia can also be caused by heart or lung problems that reduce oxygen in the blood, some tumors, and the athletic performance drug erythropoietin. When the condition is due to these causes, it is called secondary polycythemia.
People with a common cold may have headaches, mild muscle aches, or a low fever. They also often feel tired and weak. People with high fever and severe muscle aches are more likely to have the flu.
Osteomyelitis of the skull can cause persistent pain on one side of the head.

No drug is available to kill the viruses that cause the common cold, so treatment is aimed at relieving symptoms. A stuffy nose is treated with decongestant drugs. These include pseudoephedrine, which can be taken as a pill or nasal spray. It is important to know that decongestants can raise blood pressure. Nasal sprays should not be used for more than 3 days in a row.

Antihistamines can help relieve runny noses and sneezing. Older antihistamines, such as brompheniramine, can make people feel sleepy. But they may be more effective than newer drugs, such as loratadine (Claritin) or fexofenadine (Allegra).

Coughs can be relieved with cough suppressants, such as codeine. Drugs that break up mucus, such as guaifenesin (Mucinex), can also ease coughing. Vitamin C, zinc, and Echinacea have been used to treat cold symptoms. But there is no clear proof that they are effective.
Skull osteomyelitis is usually diagnosed when bone destruction is confirmed with CT, MRI, or bone scan of the skull.
A high number of red blood cells makes the blood thick, leading to slow blood flow. Slow blood flow to the brain reduces the amount of oxygen that gets to the brain, which can cause headaches.

People with polycythemia usually have a red complexion. They may also have dizziness, ringing in their ears, or bleeding from their nose, gums, or digestive tract. They sometimes have high blood pressure, joint pain, gout, and a swollen liver or spleen. They also have a higher risk of a stroke. Thicker blood tends to clot more easily, which can lead to blood clots in the deep leg veins (deep vein thrombosis or DVT) or lungs (pulmonary embolism).

Shingles may cause pain and a rash of small blisters across one side of the face. The ear or eye may also be involved. The virus can affect the cranial nerves, which control the face, head, and senses in the head. This can cause facial weakness, hearing loss, dizziness, or ringing in the ears. The pain may be mistaken for a migraine.
Headaches are one of the first and most common nervous system symptoms caused by neurotoxins. Others include blurry or double vision, confusion, drowsiness, anxiety, seizures, shaking, and weakness.

People who have a rash near their eye should see their eye doctor or go to the emergency room immediately. The rash needs to be checked by a doctor the same day it appears to prevent long-term eye damage. Topical steroids can be given to reduce eye inflammation.
If the skin blisters break open, they may be treated with an astringent solution (for example, Domeboro). This helps reduce weeping and crusting.

People with shingles often need prescription pain medication. If pain is severe, this may include opioids or steroids. Some people also develop a condition called postherpetic neuralgia (PHN). PHN is a chronic irritation of the nerve that can last months or years. It causes very severe pain even after the infection is no longer active.

People with PHN usually need other medication. This often includes drugs used for seizures or depression, which can also treat pain. Some people find relief with topical patches of lidocaine (Lidoderm) or high-dose capsaicin (Qutenza).

Erythema nodosum is a type of skin inflammation. It causes small, painful red nodules. These usually occur on the legs in people with Behcet disease. But they can occur on the buttocks, arms, neck, or face. The nodules usually go away in 10 to 14 days, but they can come back.

Up to 30% of people with Behcet disease have nervous system symptoms. They may have headaches, confusion, or memory problems that come on suddenly. These symptoms may clear up after several weeks, come and go, or be ongoing. A few people develop confusion and dementia gradually, which may get worse over time. Other nervous system symptoms include coordination and strength problems. Some people have loss of movement and feeling in their arms, legs, or face.

Hours to days before an attack, many people with migraines notice they feel irritable, depressed, elated, drowsy, unusually hungry, or having cravings for specific foods. This is called the prodrome. It is often followed by an aura, just before an attack. The aura may include vision changes, hallucinatory smells, hearing problems, or odd skin sensations, such as numbness, tingling, or burning.

Some people with idiopathic intracranial hypertension have severe headaches with no other clear symptoms, but others have several symptoms. These may include vision problems that may be subtle. People may also lose their sense of smell or hearing. Other symptoms include numbness on one side of the face, balance problems, or neck and shoulder pain. Although they are alert and awake, people may feel dizzy or drowsy. Sometimes, spinal fluid may leak from their nose.
Neurosyphilis is treated with penicillin. The antibiotic is given through an intravenous (IV) tube for 2 weeks, or by injection.

Depression and anxiety are common in people with idiopathic intracranial hypertension. It is not clear if the depression is caused by pressure on the brain, or if it is a side effect caused by the stress of being ill. Rarely, depression may be the first symptom of intracranial hypertension.

Going without food for too long can cause a headache, especially in people who get headaches often. This type of headache usually affects the front of the head on both sides and is widespread. It may be mild to moderate, and usually does not throb. A fasting headache can occur in the absence of low blood sugar.
People with idiopathic intracranial hypertension often have ringing or noise in their ears. Sounds may be heard in one or both ears, and they may vary with the person's pulse.
Most people with tension-type headaches have pain on both sides of the head. However, the location of the pain can change during the headache.

Swelling of the optic nerve in the eye due to high pressure is called papilledema. In most people with intracranial hypertension, the swollen nerve can be seen with a lighted instrument called an ophthalmoscope.

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension can cause severe headaches. People describe the pain as a dull feeling of pressure. The headaches may throb with the person's pulse. They may be worse in the morning or when the person moves their eyes.

About 50% of people with Behcet disease have arthritis and joint pain that comes and goes. At first, the pain may affect just one joint or a few at a time. Most often, the knees, ankles, hands, or wrists are affected. The joint inflammation does not damage the joints and usually stops after a few weeks.

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension can also develop slowly without warning or symptoms and last for weeks or months. This can also cause brain damage, including vision loss. Anyone can develop idiopathic intracranial hypertension, but it is more common in overweight women of child-bearing age. It can also be triggered by medications, hormones, or sleep apnea.

Pressure in the skull is called intracranial hypertension. It occurs when spinal fluid builds up between the brain and the skull bone. Many things can cause this, such as tumors, head injury, infection, and problems with blood vessels in the brain. When the cause is not known, the condition is called idiopathic intracranial hypertension, or pseudotumor cerebri. Rapid buildup of pressure can damage the brain and is a medical emergency.
An eye exam can also be done to look for vision problems. If fluid is leaking from the nose, it can be tested to confirm it is spinal fluid. A CT scan can also help doctors find a spinal fluid leak.

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension is diagnosed when a person has symptoms of high pressure in their skull, without a clear cause. An MRI or CT scan can help rule out other causes, and high pressure can then be confirmed and measured with a lumbar puncture. This involves passing a thin needle between the bones of the lower spine, into the space around the spinal cord.

People with idiopathic intracranial hypertension have vision problems, such as blurry or double vision. They may also have short black-outs or their vision may dim, especially when a headache is most intense.

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension can cause severe headaches. People describe the pain as a dull feeling of pressure. The headaches may throb with the person's pulse. They may be worse in the morning or when the person moves their eyes.

Children and older adults are more prone to heat illness. They tend to sweat less and their bodies take longer to adapt to hot, humid environments. They often don't drink enough to prevent dehydration. Heat-related illness is a leading cause of death in high school athletes in the US.
People with heat exhaustion may have muscle cramps, fatigue, dizziness, headache, nausea, vomiting, or fainting.

Nervous system problems are common with heat stroke and may be a sign of a medical emergency. Symptoms can include confusion, anxiety, irritability, agitation, bizarre behavior, hallucinations, tremor, seizure, and coma.

Different people have different thresholds of the amount of a food trigger needed to cause headaches. Headaches are more likely to occur when the trigger food or drink is consumed on an empty stomach.

Tyramine is formed when foods high in protein age and their protein breaks down. This occurs in purposely aged cheese and meats, and in foods high in protein that are not kept cold. The warmer the storage temperature, the faster tyramine builds up. Because tyramine occurs naturally and is not an additive, it is not listed on food labels. This makes it difficult to pinpoint as a headache trigger.

People may be at higher risk of heat exhaustion when they are unfamiliar with the environment and have too much sun exposure or wear too much clothing. Other risk factors include some medications, alcohol intoxication, obesity, and chronic disease.

Sunburn and heat exhaustion can often be treated at home. Cooling methods usually provide relief. These include drinking cool nonalcoholic beverages, seeking air-conditioning or another cool environment, taking cool showers or baths, and wearing lightweight clothing. People with severe symptoms or symptoms that do not get better with cooling methods should see a doctor.

Heat stroke is a life-threatening emergency. People with heat stroke should see a doctor or call 911 and be taken to the hospital right away. The main treatment for heat stroke is to cool the person down.

When this type of headache is not caused by another medical condition, it is called a primary stabbing headache. Before this diagnosis is made, more serious causes are ruled out.
