Examples of serious causes are meningioma, pituitary tumors, temporal arteritis, a stroke, a head or eye injury, herpes zoster, and pressure in the skull.

There is typically a tightening or pressing feeling on both sides of the head, sometimes described as like being in a vise. There may be throbbing pain, tenderness of the head and neck muscles, shoulder pain, or sensitivity to both light and sound. Tension-type headaches are not associated with nausea or vomiting.
About 20% of concussions are severe enough to harm the brain, even if there is no skull fracture. Repeat head injuries raise a person's risk of permanent brain damage.

When concussion symptoms last more than a few weeks, it is called post-concussion syndrome. People may have trouble concentrating, dizziness, sleep problems, anxiety, or depression. After the initial concussion, symptoms slowly get better over a few months, but sometimes last a year or longer.

After a head injury, people may be dazed or confused. They may vomit and have a headache. A more severe concussion may cause loss of consciousness, slurred speech, seizures, fainting, lack of coordination, or emotional problems.

Treatment of a concussion usually involves monitoring a person's symptoms and avoiding contact sports that could lead to further head injury. People can slowly return to full activity as their symptoms go away.
People with Behcet disease often have painful sores in their mouth or throat. These can come and go. They heal in a few weeks and leave no scars.
Behcet disease may cause abdominal pain, diarrhea, and intestinal bleeding. People may also have an acne-like rash or a severe, deep ulcer, called pyoderma gangrenosum.

Migraine headaches are diagnosed based on the person's pattern of symptoms and a physical exam to rule out more serious causes of headaches. Having an aura before the headache is a sign that it is a migraine headache.

Behcet disease causes chronic inflammation in blood vessels and other parts of the body. Arteries and veins of any size can be affected. Inflammation leads to skin and eye problems, as well as mouth and genital sores. Skin damage or sores can occur after only a minor injury.
People with Behcet disease may have painful sores on or near the genitals. These are less common than sores in the mouth, but they last longer and may leave a scar.

It is important to identify a cause for anemia once the diagnosis has been made. A source of bleeding should be explored. If bleeding is not suspected, other tests that may provide clues to the cause for anemia include a peripheral blood smear, mean corpuscular volume, and red cell distribution width. It may be useful to determine blood levels of iron, vitamin B12, folate, and ferritin.
Other symptoms of carotid artery dissection include ringing in the ears, short-term blindness, changes in taste, problems with tongue movement, and double vision.

Memory and thinking problems of post-concussion syndrome usually get better over 6 to 12 months. People may need repeat mental tests to track their progress. Doctors may also recommend behavioral therapy, mental exercises, or avoiding activities that are mentally challenging.

About 70% of people with Behcet disease develop eye problems. Inflammation of the middle layers of the eyeball, called uveitis, usually doesn't develop until 3 to 4 years after chronic mouth sores. But for 20% of people with Behcet disease, vision problems from uveitis are the first symptom. At first, only one eye may be affected. People may also have eye pain, redness, and sensitivity to light.

Some medications can help ease other symptoms after a brain injury. This includes acetaminophen (Tylenol) for headaches or promethazine for dizziness. Other drugs can help prevent seizures and reduce agitation, depression, or other behavioral changes. People with more severe injuries may need speech, physical, or occupational therapy.

Headaches can occur minutes after a concussion and usually continue for several days afterward. The headache may be on one or both sides of the head. The headaches are described as throbbing or aching.

Mastocytosis is best treated by doctors who are familiar with the disorder. Treatment is tailored to each person. There is no cure, but many symptoms can be managed by taking antihistamine medication and avoiding triggers. First and second-generation H1 antihistamines, such as cetirizine (Zyrtec), fexofenadine (Allegra), or hydroxyzine (Vistaril), may be given for skin, gastrointestinal, and nerve symptoms.
Most adults will be given an epinephrine auto-injector (for example, Auvi-Q or EpiPen) to use in case of life-threatening allergic reaction (anaphylaxis). Other medications may also be needed.

People with POTS should avoid triggers, including certain medications, dehydration, and extreme heat. These triggers can make symptoms worse. No treatment or medication has been proven effective for POTS. But some doctors recommend compression garments to improve blood flow in the legs. Most people with POTS take medication to lower their heart rate, such as low-dose propranolol (Inderal). Other medications may be useful if propranolol does not work.
The diagnosis of paroxysmal hemicrania is based on signs and symptoms of the disease. The diagnosis is supported when the nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug indomethacin prevents further episodes.

If the headaches are frequent, long-lasting, or disabling, preventive treatments may be appropriate. These may include the antidepressant drug amitriptyline, relaxation, cognitive behavioral therapy, biofeedback, acupuncture, massage therapy, or physical therapy.

Exercise also helps control some symptoms of POTS and is usually recommended. But many people with POTS feel exhausted by exercise. People should slowly start a long-term exercise program. They may have fatigue until they get used to the new activity level.

Acromegaly may cause headaches, vision problems, muscle weakness, joint pain, deepening of the voice, and skin tags. Some people have high blood pressure. The hands and feet may also be enlarged. Others develop sleep apnea, a condition in which breathing stops briefly during sleep. Women may have excess facial or body hair. They may also have menstrual problems or trouble getting pregnant. Men may have erection problems. About 25% of people with acromegaly develop diabetes.

An aneurysm is a bulge in an artery, caused by weakness in the vessel wall. If they enlarge, aneurysms can put pressure on surrounding tissues and cause symptoms. They can also rupture and bleed into surrounding tissues. Aneurysms can occur in arteries that supply the brain.

Treatment of acromegaly depends on the cause of the excess growth hormone. Because most people have a pituitary tumor, surgery is usually done to remove the tumor. Success of surgery often depends on the tumor size and location. When successful, growth hormone levels immediately drop and recurrence is uncommon.
If symptoms continue after surgery, or surgery is not possible, medications may be given to help ease symptoms. Radiation therapy may be recommended if any tumor tissue remains after surgery.

Diagnosing toxin exposure as the cause of a headache can be difficult, unless there is known contact with a toxin. Examples of this include chemical spills or accidents, or working with chemicals regularly. When a toxin is suspected, doctors ask a series of questions about the possible exposure. They also do a physical exam to check for signs of nervous system damage. Blood or urine tests may also be needed.

A finding of elevated alkaline phosphatase supports the diagnosis of Paget disease, but other disorders can also cause high serum levels. The lab can be asked to measure a bone-specific form of alkaline phosphatase. The level may be normal if the disease hasn't spread very far.

Bipolar disorder is a mental health disorder that causes extreme mood swings. Often, the first sign is an episode of depression. Over time, periods of severe depression may alternate with periods of excitement and high energy (mania). During manic episodes, people can feel either elated or irritable. They may take risks or have suicidal behavior. Determining if a person has bipolar disorder or major depression is very important for treatment decisions.

Some people with vertebral artery dissection have a pattern of symptoms called Wallenberg syndrome. This includes nausea, vomiting, dizziness, hiccups, and balance and walking problems. People may also have signs and symptoms in their arms and legs or torso, on the side that is opposite the dissection. This can include weakness, numbness, and loss of temperature or pain sensation.

The headache caused by carotid artery dissection is usually on one side of the head. It may be similar to a migraine, a cluster headache, or another kind of headache. It usually lasts 1 week or less. The headache caused by vertebral artery dissection can be on one side of the head, the top of the head, or on both sides and front. It can last up to 5 weeks.

A few people with cervical artery dissection have another disorder, such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, fibromuscular dysplasia, Marfan syndrome, polycystic kidney disease, or osteogenesis imperfecta. Also, about 5% have a family member who had a dissection of the aorta or one of its main branches.

Most people with mild symptoms get better quickly when they are no longer exposed to the toxin. But people with serious or persistent symptoms, such as breathing problems, coughing, wheezing, weakness, or fainting, should get emergency medical care or dial 9-1-1.
Persistent headaches that do not respond to treatment may be due to depression.

Depression is also called major depressive disorder. People with this mental health problem have ongoing feelings of sadness, low self-esteem, and loss of interest or enjoyment in life. These symptoms can be severe enough to affect work, school, relationships, or general health. Depression appears to be caused by a combination of genetic, social, and environmental factors. Many people have this kind of depression at least once in their lives.
People with acromegaly can have abnormal bone growth that gradually changes the way the jaws come together. This can cause an overbite, a protruding chin, and separation of the teeth.

Other symptoms also depend on the exact toxin. They may include sweating, blurry vision, stomach aches, and diarrhea. People may also feel anxious, even if they only have mild symptoms. Once exposure is stopped, mild symptoms usually go away quickly.

The symptoms of pituitary apoplexy develop rapidly over 1 to 2 days with headache as the most common symptom and often the earliest. The headache of pituitary apoplexy usually begins suddenly and is severe. It is typically felt at the front of the head, behind the eyes, or low on the back of the head. Headache may be the only symptom in some people.

Sometimes there are signs of irritation of the meninges (membranes that cover the brain), such as stiff neck, light sensitivity, fever, lethargy, and impaired consciousness. Nausea, vomiting, and other nonspecific symptoms may also occur.

TTP can be a serious condition if it is not treated promptly in the hospital. People with TTP need a treatment called plasmapheresis. It involves drawing blood, separating the blood into plasma and cells, and transfusing the cells, along with fresh plasma, back into the bloodstream. Plasmapheresis replaces ADAMTS13 and removes harmful antibodies from the blood.

CT or MRI can show mass or bleeding in the pituitary. MRI provides a more detailed view of a pituitary mass and its impact on adjacent brain structures, and is better to exclude other causes such as an aneurysm. When the diagnosis is suspected, blood samples should be obtained for measurement of all pituitary hormone levels. People with pituitary apoplexy often develop problems with thyroid and adrenal function, and may have changes in sexual or menstrual function.
Most people with pituitary apoplexy have pituitary hormone insufficiency at diagnosis. This can include adrenal insufficiency, hypothyroidism, or hypogonadism.
People with allergic rhinitis often have eye symptoms, such as redness, itching, or excess tears.
The diagnosis of allergic rhinitis is based on a person's medical history and physical exam. A history of a stuffy, runny nose that occurs around known allergens suggests the diagnosis.
Paroxysmal hemicrania is sometimes related to another medical condition, such as a pituitary tumor, blood vessel disease, or stroke.

Allergy skin testing is usually not needed, but it can be helpful for choosing the best treatment. Testing is done by injecting a small amount of a known or suspected allergen under the skin to see if it causes swelling.

Symptoms of a hypertensive emergency may include nausea, vomiting, headaches, confusion, vision loss, seizures, kidney problems, or a coma. An eye exam may reveal retinal bleeding or swelling of the optic nerve.

Allergic rhinitis, also called nasal allergies, is inflammation of the nasal passages. It is caused by an allergen, such as pollen, dust, or animal dander. The symptoms may be seasonal, occurring at the same time as seasonal pollens. If the allergen is present year-round, such as pet dander or cockroaches, the symptoms may be worse during times of year when people spend more time indoors. Often, the specific allergen is never identified.

People may first notice allergic rhinitis when they are an adult. It is usually easier to identify seasonal allergies in parts of the world where pollen and mold seasons are well-defined. In these places, spring symptoms are usually due to tree pollens, summer symptoms are due to grass and mold, and fall symptoms are due to weeds and molds.

Hemicrania continua is a related headache disorder that causes a constant, mild or moderate one-sided headache. People with this disorder have periods when the headache becomes severe. They may have other nervous system symptoms at these times. The episodes last longer than those of paroxysmal hemicrania, often lasting for several hours.
Aneurysms at the base of the brain, in the posterior communicating artery, can put pressure on the oculomotor nerves. This causes problems with eye movements.

People with an unruptured intracranial aneurysm are often asymptomatic but can have a wide range of signs and symptoms, depending on the size and location of the aneurysm. Symptoms may come and go for years. Possible features include cranial nerve palsy, dilated pupils, difficulty speaking, arm weakness, tingling or numbness, weakness or partial paralysis on one side of the face or body, uncoordinated gait, brief loss of consciousness, and seizures.

An MRI or CT scan of the brain can show a brain aneurysm. A contrast dye is often injected into a vein so that brain structures will show up better during the MRI or CT scan. This is called a MR or CT angiogram. Sometimes, a cerebral angiogram is done which shows the best detail. This is an x-ray taken after contrast dye is injected directly into the brain's blood vessels through a thin tube.
A runny, stuffy nose (rhinitis) is one of the most common signs of an allergy. People usually have eye symptoms, as well. These can include redness, itching, and excess tears.
--- Allergist or immunologist

Other signs and symptoms of allergic rhinitis include sneezing, coughing, post nasal drip, allergic shiners (dark circles under the eyes), and nasal creasing (a crease in the skin of the nose due to constantly rubbing an itchy nose). The inside of the nose is often bluish-white, pale, and swollen.

The diagnosis of tick-borne relapsing fever depends on finding signs of Borrelia bacteria in a person's blood. The bacteria can sometimes be seen by viewing blood under a microscope during an episode of fever. PCR testing detects Borrelia DNA. Blood tests are also available for detecting antibodies to the bacteria.

People with tick-borne relapsing fever usually have a fever that begins suddenly along with other symptoms. People can get the illness from the bite of an infected soft tick. They often don't realize they have been bitten, because these ticks have a painless bite. The ticks feed at night and detach themselves immediately after a short feeding. People can be infected when they visit or live in rural areas where there are many rodents for the ticks to live on.
People with allergic rhinitis often have asthma, too. Both conditions may be caused by the allergy.
Treatment for menstrual migraine consists of treating an attack, preventive treatment right before the menstrual window, and long-term ongoing prevention.

Staying away from the cause of the allergy, such as pollen, animals, or insects, can help ease symptoms of allergic rhinitis. Spending less time outside on high pollen days can help outdoor allergies. Placing dust mite covers on beds and using a vacuum with a HEPA filter can help indoor allergies.

Brucellosis is rare in the US and Canada. These countries have animal disease control programs. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) lists high risk areas as Mediterranean countries, such as Portugal, Spain, southern France, Italy, Greece, and Turkey. Other high risk areas include Mexico, South and Central America, eastern Europe, Asia, Africa, the Caribbean, and the Middle East.

Allergic rhinitis is often treated with antihistamines and corticosteroids, alone or combined. They come in pills, nasal sprays, liquids, and eye drops. Newer types of antihistamines do not cause drowsiness in most people, when taken as directed. A doctor can prescribe a short-term decongestant for a stuffy nose. Decongestants should be used with caution in young children and older adults. People with severe or daily allergies may need a series of allergy shots.

Celiac disease is diagnosed with blood tests and a biopsy of the small intestine. Blood is tested for two antibodies that are present in 90% of people with celiac disease: IgA endomysial and IgA tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies. Some people who have these antibodies do not have celiac disease.

People with allergic rhinitis usually have other head and eye symptoms, as well. Long-term nose congestion can cause feelings of pressure in the face, eye, or head. Headaches may be the most noticeable symptom for some people.
Some people with brucellosis have headaches along with other symptoms.

Spinal fluid or blood can be cultured for bacteria, fungi, or viruses. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing may provide a faster diagnosis for some types of encephalitis. Blood may be tested for ammonia to find out if liver problems are causing the symptoms. If autoimmune encephalitis is suspected, doctors may also look for certain antibodies in the spinal fluid and blood.

Angle-closure glaucoma must be treated immediately. People who think they have this condition should see an ophthalmologist right away. Medicated eye drops, such as beta blockers and pilocarpine, are often given to lower pressure in the eye until it is treated by an ophthalmologist. Oral glaucoma medicine, such as acetazolamide, is sometimes recommended.

It is very important that the medications be taken exactly as prescribed for as long as prescribed to completely cure the infection. People with infection of prosthetic heart valves or joints may need to take antibiotics longer and may also need surgery. People with neurologic disease may need treatment for 3 to 6 months.

Rocky Mountain spotted fever is treated with antibiotics, usually doxycycline (for example, Monodox, Vibramycin). Pregnant women and people allergic to doxycycline may be treated with chloramphenicol. Because the disease can be serious and it can take a few weeks to get the test results, people often need to start treatment before the diagnosis is confirmed.
Taking birth control pills or using vaginal rings continuously may be the best option for women with irregular periods and those who do not respond to the treatments above.

Malaria is treated with antimalaria medication. The specific medication given depends on the type of malaria, the person's age, whether they are pregnant, and whether the malaria is drug-resistant. Chloroquine (Aralen) is the most common treatment for non-falciparum malaria. Falciparum malaria is treated with a combination of medications called artemisinin-based combinations (ACTs). Severe malaria is treated with artesunate given by intravenous or intramuscular injection.
Women with migraine often have nausea or vomiting and increased sensitivity to light or sound during the headaches.

Typhoid fever is treated with antibiotics, usually ciprofloxacin (Cipro). Other antibiotics, such as azithromycin (Zithromax, Zmax) or injected third-generation cephalosporins, are being used more often because drug-resistant strains of the bacteria are becoming more common. Antibiotics should be taken as long as prescribed, because people can carry the disease and pass it to others until the bacteria has been cleared from the body.

A nucleic acid amplification (NAAT) test or an antigen test may be used to confirm infection with COVID-19 when you have symptoms. The doctor may swab your nose or throat and send the sample to a lab or conduct the antigen test in the office or clinic. Laboratory-based tests provide results within several days while antigen test results may be available in minutes. If you have a negative result on an antigen test, you may need a follow-up NAAT test to confirm your result.

Fever is the main symptom of typhoid fever. It is usually mild and comes and goes at first. But by the second week of illness, it becomes constant and may be as high as 104F. The fever can last up to 4 weeks if the infection is not treated. A person's heart rate may be slow at the peak of the fever.

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension is treated with drugs or surgery to relieve pressure in the skull. Medications may be needed to treat severe headaches. It is also important to protect the person's eyesight. Lowering pressure in the skull can take pressure off the optic nerve, which can prevent nerve damage and vision loss. If drugs do not lower the pressure, surgery on the optic nerve or shunts that drain fluid from the brain are used.
If a person is overweight, weight loss may help reduce pressure in their skull.

Trichinellosis is treated with antiparasitic medications that kill the adult worms, usually albendazole (Albenza) or mebendazole. These medications are not approved for pregnant women or children under age 2. People with severe infections may also need steroids in addition to antiparasitic medication.

Tick-borne relapsing fever is found throughout the world. Infected ticks are very common in the western US, southern British Columbia, Mexico, Central America, South America, the Mediterranean, Central Asia, and Africa. In the US, exposure to infected ticks often occurs in forested areas near mountains and lakes and in rodent-infested cabins. Exposure can also occur in limestone caves in central Texas.
Most people with relapsing fever have headaches during the fever episodes.

Leptospirosis is treated with antibiotics, usually doxycycline (for example, Monodox, Vibramycin). Intravenous (IV) penicillin is given to people with severe disease. Treatment should begin as soon as leptospirosis is suspected.

Tick-borne relapsing fever is treated with antibiotics, usually penicillin or tetracycline. Erythromycin is used as a second choice. People should be monitored while penicillin or tetracycline is given, because there is a chance of a Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction. This is a serious condition that causes fever, shaking chills, and low blood pressure within 2 to 3 hours after the antibiotics are started.

When thoracic outlet syndrome only affects the nerves, it is treated with physical therapy. People should avoid activities that cause pain. If the condition is caused by clots in the blood vessels, doctors may also recommend medications to destroy the clots. These medications may need to be given through a catheter, directly into the subclavian vein. Rarely, surgery is needed.

Treatment of a brainstem malformation depends on how severe the symptoms are and the type of defect in the brain. If symptoms are very mild and not getting worse, no immediate treatment may be needed. Doctors may suggest pain medications, such as anti-inflammatory drugs, to relieve headaches. Monitoring is also needed to check the progress of symptoms. People who have more serious symptoms, symptoms that get worse, or nervous system problems may need surgery.

Extremely high blood pressure is a medical emergency, particularly if there are signs of brain or heart damage. Medications must be given as soon as possible to lower the blood pressure. Care may be given in an intensive care setting so blood pressure can be closely monitored. The doctor will also treat the underlying cause of the high blood pressure as soon as it is known.

Stroke symptoms depend on what part of the brain is affected. People may have weakness, numbness, or paralysis on one side of the body. They may have facial weakness, often seen as an uneven smile. Some people have problems with walking or coordination.

Treatment for giant cell arteritis is aimed at easing symptoms and preventing vision loss, stroke, and TIAs. Most people are treated with glucocorticoid drugs, such as prednisone. This is usually taken at a fixed dose for about 1 month, then slowly tapered. Symptoms may return when the drug is reduced. So the dose may need to be increased again. The use of medicines called interleukin-6 inhibitors can shorten the duration of steroid treatment.
Neck pain over the site of the dissection is a common symptom. The pain is usually on one side only.

There is no specific treatment for dengue fever. Acetaminophen (Tylenol) should be used to control fever. People should avoid aspirin and ibuprofen, because they can make people more prone to bleeding. People with vomiting and diarrhea should stay hydrated with fluids containing electrolytes. People with severe disease need to be monitored in a hospital. People with dengue hemorrhagic fever may need blood transfusions.

People with pheochromocytoma often have headaches, excessive sweating, and heart palpitations (a rapid, strong, or irregular heartbeat). Having all three together makes the diagnosis more likely. Some people will have only one or two of these symptoms.
Low levels of carbon monoxide exposure can cause mild nausea. Higher levels can cause severe nausea and vomiting.

A head injury is when the head is bumped or shaken. It can occur due to a direct hit or an indirect force, such as a sudden stop or other violent movement. Head injuries can be caused by falls, car crashes, or sport-related activities. Soldiers in combat settings may experience head injuries from blasts. Head injuries can be mild, moderate, or severe. Most head injuries are minor, and range from mild concussions to bruises or cuts on the scalp.

Carbon monoxide poisoning can cause problems with vision, coordination, or judgment. Long or high-level exposures can cause confusion and loss of consciousness. Confusion that clears up when the person leaves an area of possible exposure suggests carbon monoxide exposure.

Severe head injuries include severe concussions, bleeding in the skull, traumatic brain injury, and skull fractures. (These topics are discussed separately in this consultation.) If the person passes out, or has a seizure, ongoing nausea or vomiting, any new symptoms, or a lasting headache, they should get medical help right away.

Shingles is usually treated with drugs that stop the viral infection. These include acyclovir (Zovirax), famciclovir (Famvir), and valacyclovir (Valtrex). These drugs work best when taken in the first 3 days of the illness. These drugs also reduce pain from the infection. People with very weak immune systems or severe complications may be given antiviral drugs in the hospital. If pain does not go away after the rash heals, more pain medication may be needed.
People often have a headache after a head injury. The nature of the headache, and whether it gets better or worse, can help doctors assess the severity of the head injury.

A person with a head injury may have a cut, swelling, or bruise on their scalp or face. They may also have nausea, vomiting, poor concentration, confusion, seizures, or amnesia, and they may pass out. Some people have very subtle symptoms, such as a vacant stare, slight confusion, poor coordination, being easily agitated, or having trouble choosing words correctly.

Relapsing fever is an uncommon illness caused by infection with Borrelia bacteria. It is spread to people through the bite of an infected soft-bodied tick or human body louse. Episodes of fever and flu-like symptoms last 3 to 5 days, separated by symptom-free periods that last about a week. Each episode becomes milder and shorter. Most people have about three fever episodes, but some may have up to 10.

When a person has had a recent blow to the head, the severity of the head injury must be assessed. Doctors will check for amnesia, confusion, poor coordination, and other signs of brain injury. People with minor injuries may need only questioning and a physical exam. Depending on the exam, the doctor may choose to observe the person for a few hours in the emergency room.

Rocky Mountain spotted fever is an infection with Rickettsia bacteria. Early diagnosis is important because infection can be life-threatening. The bacteria are transmitted by the bite of an American dog tick or the Rocky Mountain wood tick. People are more likely to be infected if they are bitten by a tick in a state where the disease is common. US cases occur most often in Arkansas, Missouri, N. Carolina, Oklahoma, and Tennessee, but have been reported in almost every state.

If a person might have a more severe injury, doctors may order a CT scan or MRI of the head. Other tests may also be needed to look for other injuries. Lab tests are usually needed only for severe injuries.
People with neurosyphilis often have changes in their mental abilities, personality, or behavior.

A person with neurosyphilis may develop symptoms of meningitis. These include headaches, vomiting, stiff neck, and changes in mental status. Later on, a stroke-like syndrome may occur. This can also cause headaches and dizziness.

Neurosyphilis is a brain and spinal cord infection. It is caused by the bacteria Treponema pallidum. The bacteria first causes syphilis, a genital infection that is spread during sex with someone who is carrying the bacteria. People may not know they are infected. Up to 40% of people with untreated syphilis develop neurosyphilis. This may take a few months or many years.

Treatment depends on the severity and cause of the head injury. (Treatment for concussions, bleeding in the skull, subarachnoid hemorrhage, and skull fractures are discussed separately in this consultation.) Most people with minor head injuries can go home after a reasonable period of observation at the doctor's office or emergency room. If the person has a concussion, their activity must be strictly limited and they must be closely monitored.
Fractures, bleeding in the skull, and brain injuries need more intensive treatment, which may include surgery.

The ophthalmologist may do eye surgery immediately to lower eye pressure. Laser iridotomy is often done to create a tiny hole near the rim of the iris, the colored part of the eye. This prevents future fluid buildup and eye pressure.

Treatment of sick building syndrome is aimed at relieving symptoms and avoiding potential triggers when possible. This may involve removing or reducing exposure to certain things in the environment. Some people with sick building syndrome are able to find potential triggers by talking to others in the same building. Potential causes should be reported to a manager or landlord. Employers have a responsibility to look into these problems.

Lead is a toxic metal that builds up in the body after being swallowed, inhaled, or absorbed through the skin. Poisoning can take place over a long period of time. This is called chronic lead poisoning, and the symptoms can be subtle. People may have only vague symptoms, such as fatigue or headaches. But they may also have muscle, joint, and digestive symptoms.

Hypercapnia is treated with positive pressure ventilation. This is pressurized air delivered through a nasal mask, face mask, or nasal plugs. People with severe hypercapnia often need a tube placed down their throat and attached to a ventilator. Some people also need supplemental oxygen. If hypercapnia is caused by a drug, an antidote may be needed. Doctors will also treat any related health problems, such as heart failure or infection.

Early symptoms of anaplasmosis include fever, headaches, chills, and muscle aches. Some people also have nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Older adults and people with weak immune systems may have more severe symptoms. Some people develop a rash, but this is not common and may be a sign that they also have another tickborne disease (such as Lyme disease or Rocky Mountain Spotted fever).

Lead poisoning is confirmed by measuring blood lead levels. Levels over 10 mcg/dL in adults or over 5 mcg/dL in children are considered high in the US, and need follow-up care. Another blood test, called zinc protoporphyrin level, can be used to measure average lead levels over several months in adults and teens.

Whiplash injury occurs with rapid, forceful back and forth motion of the head and neck. It is most often caused by rear-impact car accidents. Other causes include sport accidents, physical abuse, and other trauma. Symptoms start within 24 hours to about 7 days. About 50% of people still have symptoms more than one year after the injury.

People who have scleritis with only mild eye redness, no vision problems, and no inflammation of the cornea or uvea (a layer of tissue under the sclera) may not need treatment. But they should be watched closely by a doctor. Oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as indomethacin (Indocin, Tivorbex) and piroxicam (Feldene), are often recommended for mild to moderate scleritis.

Leptospirosis is diagnosed by growing the bacteria from cultures of a person's blood, urine, or spinal fluid. Cultures are done before treatment with an antibiotic begins, if possible. The diagnosis can also be made by finding antibodies to the leptospira bacteria in blood samples. But this test is not available in all labs.

Brainstem malformations are brain or bone deformities near the back of the head. These can put pressure on the base of the brain (cerebellum) and the nerves of the spinal cord. Most are obvious soon after birth, but some, such as Chiari malformations, have no visible signs and cause no symptoms until the teen or adult years.

People with more severe scleritis often need oral corticosteroid drugs, such as prednisone. They may need to take the steroid for 6 months to 1 year, or longer. If it does not help or cannot be taken, doctors may prescribe drugs to suppress the immune system. These drugs are sometimes used long-term. Eye drops do not help scleritis. Surgery is rarely recommended.

Anti-epileptic drugs are the first choices in treating trigeminal neuralgia. These drugs include carbamazepine (Tegretol) and oxcarbazepine (Trileptal). More than two-thirds of people with trigeminal neuralgia respond to carbamazepine. Doctors often recommend keeping a pain diary to help decide which drug and dose is best for each person.

People who swim, kayak, or windsurf in fresh water and those exposed to flood waters are at risk for leptospirosis. Risk is also higher for people who work with animals, such as veterinarians, butchers, farmers, and hunters.

People with leptospirosis have a flu-like illness that lasts about a week, then gets better. Some people have a relapse later that is more severe. This happens when antibodies to Leptospira cause a severe immune system reaction. It can last up to a month and may lead to swelling around the brain, bleeding, and liver, kidney, heart, or lung problems.
Leptospirosis begins with a high fever and often an intense headache. People may have chills, abdominal pain, vomiting, cough, muscle aches, and eye redness.

Leptospira bacteria are passed in the urine of infected animals and survive well in water, soil, and mud. The bacteria may enter a person's body through cuts or scratches. They can also enter through mucous membranes, especially in the eyes, mouth, or nose. Drinking contaminated water can also cause infection.

Surgery may be an option if drug side effects are a problem or if drug therapy becomes less effective over time. Microvascular decompression surgery seems to provide long-lasting relief. Less invasive surgical procedures may cause facial numbness and may not prevent the pain from returning.

Left untreated, African sleeping sickness is fatal. Treatment is complex and specific to the stage of the disease and the organism causing it. For treatment in the US, antiparasitic and enzyme inhibitor drugs are available at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Other treatments may be needed for related central nervous system disease, drug-resistant infections, drug side effects, and other health problems.

Occipital neuralgia symptoms may be relieved with warm compresses, massage, physical therapy, rest, anti-inflammatory drugs, or muscle relaxants. Tricyclic antidepressant drugs and anti-epileptic drugs may reduce the number and intensity of the headaches. These drugs include carbamazepine (Carbatrol, Epitol, Tegretol), gabapentin (Gralise, Horizant, Neurontin), and pregabalin (Lyrica).

If these don't help, a nerve block injection is usually given. The injection includes a numbing drug and a glucocorticoid steroid together. Doctors sometimes recommend pulsed radiofrequency and occipital nerve stimulation.
People with visual signs or symptoms should be treated immediately, without waiting for biopsy results. Early treatment can prevent further vision loss.

Low-dose (81 mg) aspirin can also help. People with vision loss may need a short course of another steroid, called intravenous methylprednisolone (Depo-Medrol). Overall, treatment can last up to 2 years.

Treatment of paroxysmal hemicrania is aimed at preventing future attacks. Doctors often prescribe indomethacin (Indocin, Tivorbex) to be taken 3 times a day. The headaches themselves are too brief to be helped by oral pain-relief medicine. Some people find relief during an attack by breathing pure oxygen for 15 to 30 minutes. Sumatriptan nasal spray or injection (Imitrex) or zolmitriptan nasal spray (Zomig) can be helpful.

Some people with cysticercosis have no symptoms until months or years after they are infected. Signs and symptoms depend which part of the brain is affected. Up to 70% of people with cysticercosis have seizures. Increased pressure in the skull can cause nausea, vomiting, swelling of the optic disc, dizziness, and poor coordination.

The tapeworm that causes cysticercosis is found in Latin America, sub-Saharan Africa, China, southern and Southeast Asia, and Eastern Europe. A person who has not left the US can become infected through contact with someone who is carrying the tapeworm, but this is rare.

Primary CNS angiitis is usually treated with a combination of 2 drugs, a high-dose glucocorticoid and cyclophosphamide (Cytoxan). These drugs suppress the immune system. Some people recover with prednisone alone. A few people have been successfully treated with intravenous (IV) immunoglobulin and rituximab (Rituxan).

The pain of trigeminal neuralgia is severe and sharp or shock-like. It usually lasts only a few seconds. Pain episodes can occur many times a day, but some people don't have them very often. People are usually free of pain in the periods between these episodes, but they sometimes have a dull burning pain. About 25% of people have some sensory loss. The signs and symptoms of trigeminal neuralgia are usually the same from one episode to another for each person.

A CST can be a life-threatening emergency and needs immediate medical attention. Treatment usually includes a blood thinner, also called an anticoagulant, to break up the clot. Corticosteroid drugs can help reduce inflammation.
People usually get trichinellosis from eating undercooked pork. Undercooked game animals can also be a source of infection.

Trichinellosis is diagnosed by blood testing or a muscle biopsy. People may have high numbers of immune system cells, called eosinophils, in their blood. They may also have high blood levels of muscle enzymes called lactate dehydrogenase and creatinine kinase.

Doctors will also test for and treat metabolic acidosis, a condition that makes the blood too acidic. Some people may also need treatment for sepsis, a life-threatening blood infection that can occur with CST.

A cardiac headache gets better when the heart starts getting enough blood again. Treatment to restore blood flow may include medications or surgery. Medications include beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, ACE inhibitors, and nitrates. If surgery is needed, it involves repairing, unblocking, bypassing, or putting a stent in the affected artery.

Cerebral venous thrombosis is usually treated with anticoagulants, starting with heparin. This can prevent the clot from growing, but does not remove it. In time, blood flow may return to normal. If the condition is severe, a drug called a tissue plasminogen activator or a similar drug may be used to break up the clot. This may be done by injection or through a catheter placed in the vein. Antibiotics are given if there is an infection.

Medication overuse headache is diagnosed if a person with chronic daily headache uses headache medication more than 2 or 3 days a week. This diagnosis is supported if increasing a medication results in more headaches or if withdrawing a medication results in fewer headaches.

Blood vessel disorders in the brain are diagnosed with an MRI or CT scan of the head. Contrast dye is often injected into a vein to enhance the images in the scans. A magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) is usually done to provide detailed pictures of blood vessels in the brain. This involves taking images while inserting a thin tube into an artery and guiding it into the brain.

Anaplasmosis is an infection caused by the bacteria Anaplasma phagocytophilum. It is spread through the bite of an infected deer tick. The infection causes flu-like symptoms 1 to 3 weeks after the bite. It is most common in the Northeast and upper Midwest parts of the US. In the US, 90% of cases occur in New York, Vermont, Maine, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Minnesota, and Wisconsin.

People with TTP can have nervous system problems, called focal neurological findings. They may have weakness or loss of sensation in areas of the head or body. They can also have trouble with speech, writing, or other brain activities. These signs can be subtle and go unnoticed without a careful examination by a doctor.

Lithium carbonate (Lithobid) taken at bedtime is often helpful for a hypnic headache. But it may not be safe for some people. Other drugs that may help include verapamil (Calan, Covera, Verelan), caffeine (or 1 to 2 cups of regular coffee), indomethacin (Indocin), and topiramate (Topamax).
Pseudomigraine will go away on its own with no lasting health problems. No treatment is known to shorten or prevent the headaches. But pain relievers may help until the headaches get better.

People with migraine symptoms may be given treatments to prevent migraine headaches. These include certain heart medications, antidepressants, and seizure medications. Avoiding headache triggers (such as caffeine and alcohol), getting regular exercise and sleep, and reducing stress may also help. If the headaches are not like migraine headaches, treatment is often more challenging.

Blood tests are available to detect Trichinella proteins or antibodies. These tests may not be positive until a month after infection. Repeat antibody testing is often done 1 to 2 weeks later. Higher antibody levels on repeat testing confirms the infection.
People with Tolosa-Hunt syndrome are treated with steroids, such as prednisone. Left untreated, pain can last 3 weeks. With steroids, pain usually gets better in 1 to 3 days.

Pre-eclampsia and eclampsia get better after delivery, which should happen as soon as is safely possible. Until then, mother and fetus should be watched closely, and the mother should limit activity. This can be done at home if the condition is mild and blood pressure is measured often. There should also be someone to help at home, and medical care should be nearby. Headaches usually improve when blood pressure is under control.

There is no cure for RCVS. The headaches usually go away on their own over several weeks. Treatment is aimed at relieving pain and managing complications. A drug called nimodipine may help some people. It is a calcium channel blocker.

Spinal headache often gets better on its own. Pain relievers can be used in the meantime. These include acetaminophen (Tylenol), nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) or naproxen (Aleve), or opioids. If pain persists, an epidural blood patch can be created by injecting whole blood into the area. An antiemetic drug can be taken for nausea and vomiting.

SUNA attacks are too brief to treat symptoms during an attack. But lidocaine (Xylocaine), topiramate (Topamax), gabapentin (Neurontin), carbamazepine (Tegretol), or lamotrigine (Lamictal) may reduce future attacks. Injecting a nerve block to numb the occipital nerves in the head may bring some relief. An implant to stimulate the occipital nerve may also be an option, but this is usually done only when other treatments do not work. Other surgeries rarely help and are risky.
People with somatic symptom disorder may also find it helpful to learn more about the psychological aspects of their condition. Some people find antidepressant medications helpful.

If new clots occur even with medication, doctors may recommend endovascular therapy. This includes balloon angioplasty or placing a stent in the artery to lower the risk of a stroke. People with other signs or symptoms that put them at risk for another stroke or TIA may also need a stent. Rarely, surgery is needed to repair the dissection.

People with active Takayasu arteritis usually take corticosteroids, such as prednisone, to reduce inflammation and blood vessel damage. They may also take other medications that suppress or regulate the immune system. These medications can relieve symptoms and slow the disease, but they do not cure it.
Another condition called polymyalgia rheumatica occurs in about 50% of people with giant cell arteritis. It causes aching and morning stiffness in the neck, shoulders, upper arms, and hips.

Shingles can occur at any age, but it usually affects older adults. 20% to 30% of people will get it at some point in their lives. Half of people who live to age 85 will get it. People with weak immune systems also have a high risk.
Some people with angle-closure glaucoma have a headache that is more obvious than the eye symptoms.
Physical injuries, surgery, radiation therapy, steroids, tuberculosis, and syphilis can sometimes trigger shingles.

A CST may also cause the eyeball to stick out more than usual. People may also have trouble moving their eye. During an exam, doctors may see a reduced cornea reflex, dilated veins in the retina, and swelling of the eye's optic nerve (papilledema).

Pain behind the eye, double vision, and a drooping or swollen eyelid are common early signs of a CST. Many people have swelling and redness in the white part of their eye, called chemosis. Most people also have a headache. Symptoms usually start in one eye, but can spread to both eyes.

Infections are treated with antibiotics. Some people may have a sinus infection due to a mold called Mucor. This is treated with the antifungal drug amphotericin B (AmBisome, Amphotec). Some people need surgery to remove infected tissue and drain the sinuses.
The CDC recommends malaria testing for anyone with a fever or flu-like symptoms who has traveled to a developing country in the past year.

A milder condition, called episcleritis, can also occur. It only affects the tissue between the sclera and the clear, outer covering of the eye, called the conjunctiva. Episcleritis is less likely to be caused by another more serious disease.
Episcleritis is less painful than scleritis. It often causes only mild discomfort or irritation. It usually gets better on its own in a few days and does not cause lasting eye damage.

There is no single test to diagnose sarcoidosis. The diagnosis is based on a person's medical history and physical exam. Imaging tests, lab tests, and biopsy findings can support the diagnosis. Doctors may use an x-ray or CT scan to find out if a person's lungs are affected. An MRI can help doctors find the disease in a person's brain or heart. Biopsy samples of the affected eye, skin, or other organs may also be needed.

People with eye symptoms need to see an eye doctor (ophthalmologist). A slit-lamp exam and a funduscopy can help determine the extent of the eye problem. A funduscopy involves dilating the pupil with eye drops, and then shining a light into the eye to check the back and other parts. Biopsies of the conjunctiva, tear gland, or eye fluid (vitreous fluid) may also help diagnose sarcoidosis.

About 70% of people with sarcoidosis have fatigue. Sarcoidosis may lead to high levels of calcium in the blood, which can cause a variety of symptoms. These include digestive problems, kidney stones, or poor kidney function.

Sarcoidosis should be treated by doctors familiar with the condition. Treatment depends on the severity of symptoms. People with eye symptoms should see an ophthalmologist. Corticosteroid eye drops or injections in or around the eye are the main treatment for uveitis. Ongoing monitoring of the pressure inside the eye is needed during treatment.
Angle-closure glaucoma occurs more often in people with certain risk factors. These include being over age 60, of Chinese ancestry, female, or having a family history of the disease.

People with severe or multi-organ disease are usually treated with oral corticosteroids. Methotrexate (Trexall) or leflunomide (Arava) may be given instead. People with severe skin, lung, or eye symptoms may need infliximab (Remicade) or adalimumab (Humira).

Treatment for polycythemia depends on the cause and a person's risk of blood clots. If a secondary cause is found, it is usually treated at the same time as the polycythemia. Treatment for polycythemia always includes phlebotomy. This involves drawing blood to lower the number of blood cells in a person's bloodstream. Most people also need low-dose aspirin therapy.

People with a high risk of blood clots often need a medication called hydroxyurea. The drug interferon alpha may also be recommended. It affects the immune system and causes the bone marrow to make fewer red blood cells.
People with psittacosis often have headaches. This can be very painful and is often the reason people go to the doctor.

Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) is a disease that mainly affects the lungs and breathing. You usually get it from close contact (within 6 feet or less) with an infected person, even if they have no symptoms. The virus is in the respiratory droplets of an infected person's saliva. It can spread during coughing, sneezing, singing, or just talking. Less often, the virus particles can linger in the air and spread to people who are further away or people who enter the space later.

The most common early symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, cough, fatigue, shortness of breath, chills, muscle pain, headache, sore throat, and loss of smell or taste. People may have a runny or stuffy nose and general aches. Although less common, some people have digestive problems like abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting as their first symptoms. Other less common symptoms are conjunctivitis (pink eye) and skin rashes.

Signs of pneumonia include coughing up mucus or blood, persistent chest pain, and chills with fever. About 14% of people develop more serious illness and have extreme difficulty breathing and often need treatment in a hospital and oxygen support. About 5% of people must be admitted to an intensive care unit.

Symptoms can begin from 2 to 14 days after exposure. Some people who have COVID-19 have no symptoms or only a mild illness. Others can become very sick and can develop pneumonia, multiorgan failure, and even death. Some people are more likely than others to have serious disease. They are people over 60 and people who have certain preexisting conditions, including high blood pressure, heart disease, diabetes, and COPD.

Angle-closure glaucoma can cause extremely severe eye pain. Sensitivity to light and other vision problems, including blurry vision, vision loss, and seeing colored halos, may occur. The affected pupil may be dilated and sluggish or may not react to light. The eyes may appear red or bloodshot.

People who have a parent, brother, or sister with migraines are at risk for migraines. Migraine headaches can be triggered by bright lights, sounds, stress, physical exertion, hormone changes, alcohol, specific foods, skipping meals, not drinking enough fluids, poor sleep habits, or changes in the weather.

Call your doctor if you think you have been exposed to the virus due to contact with an infected person or travel to significantly impacted areas. Any time you have fever and respiratory symptoms that seem severe enough to need hospitalization, call your doctor.

COVID-19 is infecting people around the world. Certain areas of the country and the world have higher rates of infection, but few are risk-free. Living and traveling in areas where there are a lot of cases increases your risk, especially if you gather in close contact (less than 6 feet apart) with other people. Being indoors with little or no ventilation, also increases the risk, compared to being outdoors.

The most effective way to prevent COVID-19 is to be vaccinated. People 5 years of age and older can receive the COVID-19 vaccine. Other ways to lower your risk of infection include keeping a distance of 6 feet away from other people outside of your household and routine handwashing. Wearing a face mask whenever you are in public is recommended, especially if you are not vaccinated. Avoid contact with anyone who is sick, whenever possible.

There is no proven cure for COVID-19 at present. Treatment focuses on relieving symptoms, preventing complications, and shortening time to recovery. Most people who get sick from COVID-19 get better on their own. Some people who get very sick and have problems breathing may need hospitalization. Steroid therapy and antiviral treatment have been shown to lower the risk of death and shorten the length of illness in some people who are hospitalized with COVID-19.

Malaria is an infection with Plasmodium parasites that are carried by mosquitos. Malaria occurs mostly in tropical and developing countries. In the US, it mostly occurs in immigrants and in people who travel to areas where malaria is present. Five species of Plasmodium cause malaria, with P falciparum causing the most serious infections.

The diagnosis of typhoid fever is confirmed by growing S typhi or S paratyphi from cultures of blood, stool, urine, bone marrow, skin, or body fluids. Blood cultures will detect 90% of typhoid infections during the first week of illness, but decrease to 50% by the third week. Stool cultures are often negative during the first week of infection.

About 30% of people with typhoid fever have a skin condition called rose spots. Pale pink spots appear by the end of the first week of illness, usually on the torso. They tend to clear up after 2 to 5 days.

Sometimes your doctor will recommend you take an antiviral medication or monoclonal antibodies, even if your symptoms are mild. Monoclonal antibodies are proteins made in a laboratory that behave like antibodies in your immune system. Monoclonal antibodies are given to prevent severe disease. Monoclonal antibodies or antivirals may be recommended early in the course of COVID-19 infection for people who are at risk of severe illness.

Up to 50% of people with typhoid fever have diarrhea, which may contain blood. Diarrhea can start a few days before the fever. It may stop when the fever starts, but sometimes it continues throughout the illness. During the third week, the diarrhea may be green and look like pea soup.

Antiparasitic drugs are often used to treat cysticercosis. These include albendazole (Albenza) and praziquantel (Biltricide). Corticosteroid drugs are also given to help control inflammation that occurs when the parasites die.
When cysts form in the brain or cerebral spinal fluid, they can increase pressure inside the skull. This can cause symptoms such as confusion, headaches, and vision problems.

Some people with this infection need treatment to control or prevent seizures. This may be done by taking anti-epileptic drugs for up to 2 years. Surgery may also be needed to reduce the buildup of cerebrospinal fluid and pressure in the brain.

People with Rocky Mountain spotted fever usually have a skin rash that appears 2 to 5 days after the fever begins. Small, pink spots first appear on the wrists and ankles, and may then spread to the rest of the arms, legs, and torso. The rash does not itch.
Rocky Mountain spotted fever causes flu-like symptoms about 1 week after the bite of an infected tick.
Some people with Rocky Mountain spotted fever get a dark red or purple rash under their skin called petechiae. This may happen later in the course of the disease.

The headache pain of SUNA is almost always on one side of the head only. It is greatest around the eye, the temple, or forehead, but can include other parts of the head on the same side. The pain is excruciating and is described as stabbing, sharp, burning, or shock-like. The attacks usually occur on the same side of the head, but they can alternate from one side to the other.

Cervical artery dissection may be caused by a neck injury, whiplash, or sudden movements of the head. These can be small movements that involve quickly bending, extending, or rotating the neck. These small movements can occur during sports activities or while coughing. Chiropractic manipulation of the head or neck has also been linked with artery dissection. For some people, no specific cause can be found.

People with SUNA headaches can have a single stabbing pain that lasts for a few minutes, groups of stabbing pains, or recurring rapid stabs on top of a continuous ache. Nearly 50% of people have a dull headache between attacks.

People with SUNA have an average of about 60 headache attacks a day. Some people have just one a day, but others have hundreds. SUNA attacks occur in groups called bouts, separated by pain-free periods.

Typhoid fever is an infection with Salmonella typhi bacteria. People are infected by consuming contaminated food or water. A high fever starts within 1 to 2 weeks. People can also have a sore throat, headaches, coughing, muscle aches, abdominal pain, or diarrhea. The infection can be severe and is sometimes fatal. Typhoid fever is rare in the US. It mostly affects travelers who are returning from developing countries.
SUNA attacks can occur without warning or explanation. They can also be triggered by stimulation or movement of the face. This can occur when chewing, washing the face, or brushing the teeth.
Some people may feel overwhelming fatigue and lack the energy for everyday activities. Nighttime insomnia and excess daytime sleeping is common.

Pheochromocytomas are usually diagnosed based on a person's history and physical exam. Sometimes tumors are found when imaging is done for another purpose. In people with symptoms, blood or urine tests can confirm a high level of adrenal hormones, and a CT scan or MRI may confirm the tumor. Ideally, urine testing is started at the beginning of a symptom episode and collected for 24 hours. Rarely, other imaging tests may be needed, if tumors are not found with a CT or MRI.

The goal of early treatment for acute sinusitis is to relieve symptoms. This may include a saline nasal wash, decongestant, intranasal steroid, or pain medication. If bacterial sinusitis is suspected, antibiotics may be given. Doctors may suspect a bacterial infection if symptoms are severe (such as a high fever) or do not get better on their own within 10 days.

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) affects the immune system. A weak immune system raises a person's risk for other infections and cancer. Some people develop a flu-like illness, called acute retroviral syndrome, within weeks of being infected with HIV. Without treatment, most people with HIV develop AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome).
Most people with typhoid fever have a headache during the first week of illness. This is often a dull ache in the front of the head.

People with typhoid fever may have dizziness, weakness, or excessive sweating. Some people have rose spots on the torso. Confusion or bizarre behavior may also be symptoms of typhoid fever. Bleeding in the intestines can also occur.
A tension-type headache is described as tightness, pressure, or a feeling as though there is a band or belt around the head.
More than 50% of people with SUNA feel restless or agitated during an attack. Symptoms associated with migraines are rare. These include nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light, sound, or smell.

Takayasu arteritis is inflammation of the large arteries. It often affects the main artery in the body (aorta) and its main branches. Inflammation causes the arteries to become narrow or blocked. The disease usually affects teen girls and young women. It is more common in Asia.

People are diagnosed with depression when they have a depressed mood that does not go away. People with depression often say they feel hopeless and have lost interest and satisfaction in things they used to enjoy. Many people have brief feelings of depression. The diagnosis is not made unless symptoms last for weeks and have a significant effect on a person's daily life.

Strokes are detected with a CT or MRI scan of the brain. An MRI scan can show whether a person has had mini-strokes. An MRI is also the best test for finding very recent strokes (less than 4 hours ago). A CT scan is less expensive and gives faster results.

Anaplasmosis is usually diagnosed based on a person's medical history and physical exam. An early form of the bacteria, called a morula, can sometimes be seen in white blood cells under a microscope. But other tests are still needed to confirm the diagnosis. The diagnosis can be confirmed with a blood test, called a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test. It helps doctors find bacterial DNA in the blood.

Somatization is the tendency to experience stress as physical symptoms. People with somatic symptom disorder have many symptoms. They may involve different body systems and cannot be explained by a medical condition or drugs. The symptoms are real, not imagined or pretended.
Headaches are one of the first symptoms of somatic symptom disorder. They may have features similar to those of a migraine headache.
Up to 85% of people with anaplasmosis have headaches.

Antibodies to the bacteria can also be measured in a blood sample, but they may not show up in the first few days of the illness. So repeat antibody testing is often done in 1 to 2 weeks. Higher antibody levels on repeat testing confirm a recent or active infection. Doctors sometimes start treatment before the diagnosis is confirmed.
Occipital neuralgia may cause eye sensitivity to light, tenderness over the occipital nerves, a persistent aching, or a lack of sensation in the area of the headache pain.

Diagnosis can be confirmed with a skin biopsy if there is a rash or a PCR test of a blood sample. Antibodies to the bacterium can also be measured in a blood sample, but may not be found during the first few days of illness. Repeat antibody testing is often done in 1 to 2 weeks. Higher antibody levels on repeat testing confirm recent or active infection. Your doctor may start treatment before the diagnosis is confirmed.

Other blood tests may also show a loss of red blood cells. This may include high levels of a red blood cell enzyme called lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) or a low level of a protein that recycles hemoglobin, called haptoglobin.

Monosodium glutamate (MSG) is used as a flavoring in some Asian foods, as well as in canned, packaged, and prepared foods. In some people, MSG causes a dull or burning headache in the front of the head within one hour of consuming it.

Many toxic substances at home and work can cause headaches. These are called neurotoxins, and they can damage the nervous system. Severity of the damage and symptoms depends on the exact toxin, how much a person is exposed to, and how long they are exposed. Exposure can occur by breathing, swallowing, or touching the toxin. Common neurotoxins include solvents, pesticides, weed killers, ethylene oxide, metals, and carbon monoxide.
Some substances can cause withdrawal symptoms, such as headaches, when they are stopped after a period of regular use.

Most medications used to treat headaches appear to also cause headaches if used too frequently. Medication overuse headache is defined as headache in a person with chronic daily headache who takes headache medications more than 2 or 3 times a week. Analgesics, combination pain relievers, ergots, opioids, and triptans can cause medication overuse headache. Overuse can also reduce the effectiveness of these medications when they are used to prevent headaches.

Psittacosis is a rare lung infection caused by the bacteria Chlamydophila psittaci. People usually get it from being around infected birds and breathing in the bacteria. Up to 25% of people with the infection do not recall any contact with birds.

Common symptoms include fever, headaches, muscle aches, severe chills, and a cough that does not produce mucus. Other symptoms include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Pneumonia, and heart and nerve problems can also occur.

Doctors may not find Chlamydophila psittaci antibodies in the blood early in the illness. So a second antibody blood test is often done 1 to 2 weeks later. If the second test shows higher antibodies, it confirms the infection. Blood tests that look for IgM specific antibodies can sometimes confirm the infection with just one test.

A small bowel biopsy can confirm the diagnosis. It is also used for people who lack the antibodies, but are still considered likely to have celiac disease. Samples are taken by passing a lighted tube (endoscope) through the mouth and past the stomach to the first part of the small intestine.

The diagnosis of psittacosis can be confirmed with an antibody blood test. Some doctors may also order a culture to confirm the type of bacteria. Sometimes, a PCR (polymerase chain reaction) test is used to detect the bacteria's DNA. Chest x-rays can suggest a lung infection, but they cannot confirm the exact diagnosis.

Migraine pain may be felt around or behind the eye, or in the temple. Many people also have vision changes that start before the headache and may last until the headache is gone. These changes can include blurry or reduced vision, flashing lights, wavy lines, spots, and sensitivity to bright lights. Visual auras can also occur. These are more dramatic changes that usually occur in both eyes and fade away when the headache starts.

Excessive daytime sleepiness is the most common and usually the first-reported symptom of obstructive sleep apnea. People fall asleep and stay asleep in inappropriate settings and at inappropriate times.

The diagnosis of cardiac headache is considered when a headache occurs along with other symptoms that suggest a loss of blood flow to the heart, such as chest pain. An EKG performed both at rest and during physical exertion can be done to support the diagnosis. Blood tests that show heart problems can also be useful. The diagnosis is confirmed if the headache is resolved after treatment for the underlying cardiovascular problem.

Some migraines can be treated with over-the-counter pain relievers, such as ibuprofen (Advil), naproxen (Aleve), acetaminophen (Tylenol), or a combination of acetaminophen, aspirin, and caffeine (Excedrin Migraine). More severe migraines can also be treated with prescription drugs, including triptans and ergotamines. Triptans include sumatriptan (Imitrex) and rizatriptan (Maxalt). Ergotamines include Ergomar and Cafergot.

The diagnosis of occipital neuralgia is based on a history of stabbing pain in the back of the head in the regions affected by the occipital nerves. An anesthetic can be injected into the occipital nerves. If this brings pain relief, it supports the diagnosis.
About 80% of people with a pheochromocytoma have headaches. They may be persistent or occur mainly during symptom episodes. The headaches may be severe and throbbing.
Headaches may be an early symptom of celiac disease. They may be similar to migraine or tension headaches. In some people, headaches stop when a gluten-free diet is started.

Symptoms of the flu are similar to symptoms of a common cold. But fever, fatigue, body aches, joint pain, a sore throat, and a dry cough are more common with the flu. They may also be more severe with the flu. A runny or stuffy nose can sometimes occur with the flu, but is more likely to be caused by a cold. People with the flu usually have a temperature over 100 degrees.

Influenza, often called the flu, is a viral infection of the airways. It is most common in the winter months. Influenza A and influenza B are the viruses that cause the flu in humans. Symptoms can begin suddenly and usually last up to a week. Some people have a lingering cough and may feel ill for more than two weeks. Most adults do not have digestive symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

The flu is often diagnosed based on a person's symptoms and physical exam but can look like other infections circulating in the community. The infection can be confirmed with a nucleic acid amplification (NAAT) test. Rapid and accurate results are often available with NAAT testing allowing for early treatment, when needed. Other rapid tests may not be as accurate. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests must be performed in laboratories. These are accurate, but take longer.
Headaches usually begin suddenly along with other flu symptoms. They usually affect the whole head, but sometimes affect just the forehead.

Most people are not aware of having stopped breathing during sleep. However, about 75% of people with obstructive sleep apnea have bed partners who have noticed episodes of breathing cessation. Gasping, choking, snorting, vocalizations, or brief awakenings usually end the apneas.

Some people develop a headache minutes or hours after eating processed meat or fish that contains nitrates or nitrites. These chemicals are used as food colorings, flavorings, and preservatives in cured meats and fish.
A headache may be the first symptom of CST. It may start suddenly and quickly become severe. This often occurs before fever and eye symptoms.

Some people have nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light, sound, or odor. Some people have an aura, which is an episode of unusual sensations or feelings. Others have problems with speech or movement before the headache starts. Some people feel lethargic or disoriented.

Artery dissection is best diagnosed with an MRI or a magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA). An MRA involves injecting contrast dye into a vein to help blood vessels and brain structures show up better on the MRI scan. Doctors can also use Doppler ultrasound to see blood flow in the neck arteries. But an angiogram is more accurate for diagnosing dissection.
Rocky Mountain spotted fever is usually diagnosed based on a person's medical history and physical exam.

Occipital neuralgia is a nerve disorder that causes episodes of stabbing pain in the back of the head. An occipital nerve may be injured or irritated by infection, gout, diabetes, blood vessel inflammation, or another medical condition. Sometimes the cause cannot be found.

The rapid development of one or more nervous system problems, called focal neurological findings, is a sign of a stroke. Symptoms may include weakness or loss of sensation in areas of the head or body. People can also have trouble with speech, writing, or other brain activities. These signs can be subtle and go unnoticed without a careful exam by a doctor.

About 90% of people with a subarachnoid hemorrhage have a headache that starts suddenly. It is usually severe and is often described as the worst headache ever. Some people have a sudden, severe headache several days or weeks before the hemorrhage. This is called a "sentinel headache."

Up to 66% of people with a subarachnoid hemorrhage have problems with mental function. Symptoms can include fatigue, drowsiness, confusion, or agitation. Trouble with thinking and alertness also occur.

Meningitis is suspected based on a person's medical history and physical exam. It can be confirmed by checking the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) with a lumbar puncture, also called a spinal tap. This can also find the infectious cause. Sometimes, a CT scan or MRI is done first to exclude other possible causes. Blood samples may be taken for culture as well. Because there may be some delay, antibiotics may be started before the cause is clear.

The symptoms of meningitis often develop rapidly over a few hours or days. This pattern can be a sign of acute bacterial meningitis, which is a serious medical emergency. But meningitis can also begin more gradually and linger for weeks or months. The most common symptoms of meningitis are fever, headaches, and a stiff neck. Most people have at least 2 of these symptoms. Many people also have changes in alertness or mental function.

Meningitis is an inflammation of the meninges, the membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord. Meningitis is usually caused by bacteria, viruses, or other organisms. Sometimes it is caused by noninfectious diseases, such as cancer.

The CSF pressure can be measured during the lumbar puncture. This pressure is often high in people with meningitis. The protein level in the CSF is often high, and the glucose level is often low. Viewing the CSF under a microscope will show white blood cells in the fluid and may show bacteria.
Headache can be an early symptom of encephalitis, especially when the person also has meningitis. The head pain is usually widespread and can be severe.

An MRI of the brain can support the diagnosis of low CSF pressure. It may show changes in the brain or in the membranes around the brain. CSF pressure can be measured by passing a needle between the bones of the lower back into the space around the spinal cord. A CSF leak can sometimes be seen on an MRI of the spine or with a CT or MRI myelogram. Myelograms involve injecting a contrast dye in the space around the spinal cord and looking for leaks into the surrounding tissues.

TTP is diagnosed based on a person's medical history and physical exam. Doctors use blood tests to support the diagnosis. A complete blood count (CBC) usually shows a low number of platelets. A smear of blood viewed under a microscope may show damaged red blood cells, called schistocytes.
Headache is a common symptom of TTP.

Two types of headache are related to drinking alcohol: immediate alcohol-induced headache and hangover headache. All alcoholic drinks can cause both types. The amount of alcohol and type of drink that can cause them varies from person to person.

Many people with encephalitis also have meningitis. This is inflammation of the membranes that cover the brain (meninges). A stiff neck is a common sign of meningitis, but may occur only when the neck is bent gently forward. People may also have neck pain and trouble bending their neck.

People who spend time in wooded areas are at highest risk for tick bites. Many people with Ehrlichiosis don't recall a tick-bite, but may report having been outdoors where ticks live, like wooded or recreational areas where there is uncut grass or low brush. Recent activities that raise a person's risk of tick bites include camping, hiking, fishing, hunting, gardening, or golfing or occupational activities, such as forestry work, farming, or landscaping.
People with Paget disease may have bowing of the leg bones. This occurs with osteoarthritis in the hip or knee. The area over the involved bone may be warm and tender.
Exposure to mold has been linked to asthma, asthma-like symptoms, airway irritation, and other breathing problems. Mold may cause or contribute to sick building syndrome.

The diagnosis of tension-type headache is largely based on the features of the headache. It can be difficult to distinguish from migraine. There is no diagnostic test to confirm a tension-type headache. Other headache causes and other types of headache should be ruled out.
Paget disease can affect bone near the inner ear. This may cause ringing in the ear and a spinning sensation of vertigo.

Paget disease usually affects bones of the head, back, pelvis and the thigh bone. However other bony areas can be affected as well. Symptoms may develop in joints near affected bones that are enlarged or deformed. Paget disease that affects the skull may cause headaches. People may have severe facial pain when the trigeminal nerves are affected.

People with sick building syndrome may have eye irritation, nasal irritation or congestion, or a runny nose. Some have throat irritation or a dry cough. Itching, dry skin, nausea, dizziness, fatigue, trouble concentrating, or sensitivity to odors may occur in some people.

Paget disease of bone is a condition of abnormal bone destruction and growth. The new bone growth can be deformed and brittle and can break easily. Most people have no symptoms, but pain can result from secondary arthritis, fractures, or bone compressing on surrounding tissue. The cause of Paget disease is not known. It often runs in families.

When sick building syndrome is suspected, the building may be checked. This includes assessment of the air quality and the heating, ventilation, and air conditioning systems. Also, a check for possible pollutants and contaminants is made. A building walkthrough by industrial hygienists, public health officials, or other experts, and interviews with the occupants can sometimes help identify the source of the problem.
Some people with sick building syndrome have headaches.

Sick building syndrome is a poorly understood illness. It affects people living or working in a specific building. Symptoms occur only when they are in the building and quickly improve after leaving. Potential causes of sick building syndrome include poor ventilation, chemicals, smoke, combustion products, pollutants, bacteria, pollen, and mold. Other possible factors include noise, temperature variation, humidity, lighting, and sources of psychological stress.

Leptospira bacteria are passed in the urine of infected animals and survive well in water, soil, and mud. The bacteria may enter a person's body through cuts or scratches.
