They can also enter through mucous membranes, especially in the eyes, mouth, or nose. Drinking contaminated water can also cause infection.

Ehrlichiosis is usually diagnosed based on a person's medical history and physical exam. An embryonic form of the Ehrlichia organism called a morula can sometimes be seen within white blood cells under a microscope, but further testing is still needed to confirm the diagnosis. The diagnosis can be confirmed using PCR to detect bacterial DNA in blood samples.

Paroxysmal hemicrania episodes are short but frequent. Episodes usually last from 2 to 30 minutes. People can have from 2 to 50 episodes a day. Most people have these pain episodes frequently for a year or more.

85% to 90% of people with cluster headaches have episodic headaches. This means that headache episodes occur in clusters or bouts that last from one to three months. A person may be free from headaches between these periods. Symptom-free periods last at least 3 months. 10% to 15% of people have chronic cluster headache with symptom-free periods lasting less than a month. Some people have no symptom-free periods for a year or more.
The pain of trigeminal neuralgia usually occurs only on one side of the face. It usually affects the cheek, chin, or jaw. It rarely affects the forehead or area around the eye.

Paroxysmal hemicrania is a rare headache disorder. It causes many short headache episodes each day. The episodes consist of a sudden, severe headache on one side of the head, usually around or behind the eye.

Other symptoms frequently include a watery eye, constricted pupil, forehead sweating, facial flushing, or a runny or stuffy nose. Some people with paroxysmal hemicrania have nausea, vomiting, or sensitivity to light, sound, motion, or odor. Agitated or restless behavior is common during an attack.

A paroxysmal hemicrania episode begins and ends suddenly. The headache pain is usually severe and may be throbbing, aching, or claw-like. It is usually felt around the eyes or the sides or front of the head. It can also affect the neck, jaw, or back or top of the head. It can spread to the shoulder or arm.
Most people are restless and are unable to sit still or lie down during a cluster headache attack. They often walk around or sit and rock back and forth.

People with acute retroviral syndrome often have fatigue. They may lose their appetite and lose weight. Other symptoms include headaches, joint and muscle pain, diarrhea, and vomiting. Women may develop a yeast infection in the vagina. A thrush (yeast) infection in the mouth and throat may also occur. Lab tests may show a low white blood cell count and low levels of CD4 helper lymphocytes.

A spinal headache is caused by low pressure in the fluid that surrounds the brain and spinal cord, the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Spinal headaches can follow a lumbar puncture, a test that involves sampling the spinal fluid. It can also follow spinal anesthesia used during surgery or childbirth. CSF leaks also occur in connection with some medical conditions.

Paget disease can cause pain from bone changes or from pressure on a nerve. Muscles may become stretched and painful. Weakened leg bones may hurt when standing. Depending on the bones affected, Paget disease can cause back pain and vertebral compression fractures, an increase in the size of the skull and forehead, facial pain or deformity, headaches, and problems with vision or the sense of smell.

Imaging with plain x-rays of the affected area can detect Paget disease of bone. X-rays can show enlargement, thickening, or bowing of the bone. Bone scans use a radioactive tracer to detect inflammation or abnormal bone metabolism and can also show affected areas. Blood tests often show an elevation of the bone enzyme alkaline phosphatase.

Paget disease may cause hearing loss due to problems with the small bones in the middle ear. This is called conductive hearing loss. It may also cause damage to nerves and tissue, called sensorineural hearing loss.
Subdural and epidural hematomas can be caused by a head injury or forceful movement of the head. But up to 50% of people with subdural hematomas have no known head injury.

A dissection is a tear in an artery wall. It allows blood to leak between the layers of the wall, where it can form a clot, called a hematoma. The hematoma can make the artery narrow. A dissection can also cause a bulge in the artery wall, called an aneurysm. Dissections in the neck are called cervical artery dissections. The neck has 2 major arteries that lead to the brain, the carotid and the vertebral. Dissections in both are rare, but are more common in the carotid.

Cervical artery dissection can affect the nerves that lead from the brain to the face and eye, on the same side as the dissection. This can cause the eyelid to droop (ptosis) and cause the pupil to stay small (miosis) on the same side. Together, these signs are called Horner syndrome. About 60% of people with carotid artery dissection have this problem.

People with altitude sickness may also have fatigue, dizziness, light-headedness, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, and sleeping problems. These symptoms usually last only 24 to 72 hours, as the body gets used to the high altitude. They may last only a few hours after descending to a lower altitude.

Altitude sickness is an illness caused by oxygen deficiency at high altitude. It usually occurs when people travel above 8,200 feet, but can occur at lower altitudes. The likelihood of illness increases with the altitude and speed of ascent. This occurs in more than 30% of mountaineers.

Rarely, altitude sickness gets worse and causes brain swelling. Symptoms include problems with coordination, drowsiness, lethargy, confusion, hallucinations, and declining consciousness. If there is fluid in the lungs, people may have coughing, shortness of breath, weakness, and a rapid heartbeat. This is a life-threatening condition, and the person should be moved to a lower altitude immediately.

Excessive physical effort at high altitude increases the risk of altitude sickness. However, a person's level of physical fitness does not affect the risk. Other factors that increase the risk are a low fluid intake, drinking alcohol, and a history of migraine headaches.

Treatment includes avoiding activities that trigger headaches or changing your exercise regimen. Warming up before exercise may also help. Indomethacin (Indocin, Tivorbex) or naproxen (Aleve) 30 to 60 minutes before exercise may prevent primary exercise headache. Some doctors may also recommend beta-blockers, such as propranolol (Inderal), or other drugs such as phenelzine (Nardil) and ergonovine.

The diagnosis of primary exercise headache is based on a person's medical history. Other causes must be ruled out first. An MRI is usually done to look for problems in the brain. Doctors may also do a magnetic resonance angiogram to get a better view of blood vessels in the brain. A spinal fluid test may also be useful. Spinal fluid is collected through a needle inserted between the bones of the spine.

Leptospirosis can cause an intense, throbbing headache. It is usually felt in the forehead and behind the eyes. This type of headache can occur during the first phase of the disease or during a relapse.

Some dissections heal on their own. But most doctors treat them with medication to break up clots and reduce the risk of a stroke. Once the blood vessel is open and free of clots, people may still need anticoagulants or antiplatelet medication to prevent new clots that could lead to a stroke.

Headache is the most common symptom of meningitis and is often the first symptom. Some people feel pain in the forehead or at the back of the head and neck. The headache may start suddenly. Eye sensitivity to light and eye pain with movement often go with the headache.
This type of headache should get better within an hour of relieving the pressure on the head.

Anemia is a deficiency of red blood cells or hemoglobin, the protein that carries oxygen in the blood. It is usually caused by a lack of iron, which is needed to make hemoglobin. Anemia can also be caused by diseases that destroy red blood cells or impair the ability of the bone marrow to make blood. Mild anemia may cause no symptoms or only fatigue. Severe anemia can be life-threatening.

Sexual activity headache is diagnosed by ruling out other possible causes of the headache, such as bleeding in the brain, a torn artery (arterial dissection), or a condition that affects the back of the brain (lesion of the posterior fossa). Imaging tests of the brain, such as an angiogram or MRI, are often needed.

Early symptoms of ehrlichiosis include fever, headaches, chills, fatigue, and muscle aches. Nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, and weight loss occur later in the course of the disease. About a third of adults with ehrlichiosis have maculopapular skin rash. The rash consists of discolored and raised spots. People with severe disease may develop a cough, diarrhea, confusion, and enlarged lymph nodes. The illness lasts for about 3 weeks.
Ehrlichiosis causes flu-like symptoms 1 to 2 weeks after the bite of an infected tick. People may have fever, headaches, and body or muscle aches.

Antibodies to the bacterium can also be measured in a blood sample, but may not be found during the first few days of illness. Repeat antibody testing is often done in 1 to 2 weeks. Higher antibody levels on repeat testing confirm recent or active infection. Your doctor may start treatment before the diagnosis is confirmed.

Headaches are the most common nervous system symptom of this condition. They are often pulsing and may cause severe pain, similar to a migraine headache. Other nervous system symptoms are dizziness, vertigo, blurry or double vision, other vision problems, numbness or tingling in the hands or feet, and seizures.
About 50% of people with essential thrombocythemia have a gene mutation called JAK2V617F.

Essential thrombocythemia is a cancer of the blood that leads to overproduction of blood platelets. This can cause increased blood clotting and bleeding. It is more common in people over 60 years old, but can occur in children. Most people have no symptoms at the time of diagnosis. The condition is often found during a routine blood test.

The flu can lead to dehydration, sinus and ear infections, pneumonia, or other bacterial infections. It can worsen some other medical conditions, such as asthma, diabetes, and congestive heart failure. Less common complications of the flu include an inflammation of the heart called myocarditis, an inflammation of the brain called encephalitis, and multisystem organ failure.

Head, neck, and face pain are the most common symptoms of cervical artery dissection. They occur in up to 80% of people with this condition. The pain often starts slowly, but becomes severe aching or throbbing. Rarely, the head pain starts after other symptoms or begins suddenly (thunderclap headache). Some people have sharp pain, but this is also unusual.

Shingles usually causes a rash of small blisters. The rash may occur in a band or stripe around the right or left side of the body. The blisters eventually rupture causing weeping and crusting. Rarely, shingles can also cause a more widespread rash similar to chickenpox.

The aura is usually followed by a headache, then a postdrome. During the headache, pain usually gets worse for 1 to 2 hours, then levels off and gets better after 4 to 8 hours. But attacks can last 24 hours or more. Any physical activity, including bending over, can make the pain worse. People often describe the postdrome as feeling like a zombie or hung over.

Medication side effects usually occur soon after you start taking a new medication, but they can also occur later. Sometimes side effects only occur after you stop taking the medication. If you took the medication in the past without side effects or your symptoms began before you started taking the drug, it is likely that your symptoms are caused by something other than the drug.

Cerebral venous thrombosis occurs when a blood clot blocks a vein that carries blood from the brain to the heart. This causes swelling and pressure in the brain, which can lead to brain damage. In turn, people may have a wide range of signs and symptoms. Cerebral venous thrombosis can be a life-threatening condition.

Symptoms of cerebral venous thrombosis vary from person to person. They depend on where the blockage is, and how bad it is. Symptoms usually develop over days or weeks, but can occur suddenly. Any brain function can be affected, including memory, movement, sense of touch, speech, and vision. Memory loss, confusion, and loss of consciousness are more common in older adults with a cerebral venous thrombosis.
Cerebral venous thrombosis can increase pressure in the brain. An eye exam of the retina may show papilledema, a swelling of the optic nerve.

About 80% of people with cerebral venous thrombosis have a headache. It is often the first symptom and is sometimes the only symptom. There is no specific pattern to the headache. It may affect one area of the head or be more widespread. It can be mild or severe. It may come and go, or it can be continuous. Sometimes, the headache begins suddenly and it often worsens over time.

Malaria is diagnosed by identifying the parasite on a Giemsa-stained blood smear. Thin smears can be evaluated more quickly and can identify the specific parasite species. Thick smears can better detect the quantity of parasites in the blood. If the initial smears are negative, smears should be repeated every 12 hours until the diagnosis is ruled out. People may not have detectable parasites until several days after the symptoms begin.

Several rapid diagnostic tests are available for detecting the antigens from the malaria parasites. They are not widely used because of concerns about accuracy and cost, but may be helpful when the diagnosis is uncertain. Positive results from rapid diagnostic tests are usually confirmed by identifying the parasite in a Giemsa-stained smear.

Medications and dietary supplements can cause many symptoms and some serious medical problems. Tell your doctor about all the medications you take regularly or have taken recently. Include prescriptions, over-the-counter remedies, and any prescription medicine you have taken that was not prescribed for you. Also, tell your doctor about any supplements, herbs, or other compounds that you use. Many of these interact with medications, and many have harmful effects.

About 70% of people with cervical artery dissections have a stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA or mini-stroke) soon afterward. Strokes and TIAs are caused by poor blood flow to the brain. They may occur hours or weeks after the tear. Cervical artery dissection is one of the most common causes of stroke in younger adults and children. The average age of people with this condition is 45 years old.
A carotid artery dissection often causes face, eye, or ear pain on one side. The pain can spread to the neck on the same side.

Pituitary apoplexy is an uncommon condition involving the pituitary gland, a hormone-secreting gland in the brain. It is caused by bleeding into the gland, usually due to a pituitary tumor or, more rarely, head trauma. The symptoms are due to rapid enlargement of the gland and its pressure on nearby brain structures, as well as bleeding into the brain and impaired hormonal function. Pituitary apoplexy is a medical emergency.

Headaches are often reported by people with sleep disorders such as insomnia, sleep apnea, and others. However, the nature of the causal relationship is unclear. The headache typically has the features of a tension-type headache.

Heat exhaustion or heat stroke usually occurs in hot, humid environments. Young adults, such as military recruits and athletes, may experience it after strenuous exertion. Very young children, the elderly, and people who are weak or frail may have heat-related illness without exerting themselves.

Headache can be an early symptom of heat exhaustion. Other common symptoms of heat exhaustion include fatigue, vomiting, muscle cramps, sweating too much, rapid breathing or heartbeat, dizziness, or fainting.

A pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor that usually forms in the adrenal gland. The tumor releases excess hormones that raise blood pressure and heart rate. The tumor is not usually cancerous, but it can cause life-threatening damage, especially to the kidneys, heart, and circulation. Symptoms may come and go and may be triggered by medical procedures, medications, exercise, stress, pregnancy, or urinating. Episodes usually last for less than an hour.

Most people with Lyme disease have a red, expanding, ring-like rash called erythema migrans at the site of the tick bite. It usually starts about a week after the bite, within 3 to 30 days. It is often the first sign of infection. The rash expands for several days and may reach 12 inches across. Sometimes, it looks like a bull's eye or target. The rash may be hot or tender to touch. It usually fades within 3 to 4 weeks, even without treatment.

Hypercapnia can cause coordination problems, a tremor with certain body positions, brisk tendon reflexes, and muscle twitching. Some people have facial flushing or swelling of the optic disk in the eye, called papilledema. Severe hypercapnia can cause breathing and heart problems, convulsions, unconsciousness, and coma.

Other symptoms of a pheochromocytoma include a rapid heartbeat, shortness of breath, tremor, paleness, chest pain, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and anxiety or panic attacks. Some people have dizziness or fainting. People may also have cold hands and feet, a fever, constipation, weight loss, blood in the urine, or increased thirst and urination.

People with an infected or inflamed sphenoid sinus may have headache pain behind or around their eyes or nose. The pain may be sudden and severe, and it may spread to the back of the head. Sphenoid sinusitis usually occurs along with inflammation in the other sinuses and nasal passages. This may cause headache pain in more than one part of the head. Sinusitis pain often gets worse if a person bends over, coughs, or sneezes. It may also lead to sleep problems.
When the sphenoid sinus is infected or inflamed, the nose may feel stuffy or blocked. Less often, the nose is runny. The discharge may be clear or contain pus. Some people have postnasal drip.

Sphenoid sinusitis is suspected based on a person's medical history and physical exam. A CT scan or MRI of the sinuses can sometimes confirm the diagnosis. But it is often difficult to see the sphenoid sinus with imaging tests. Doctors may use nasal endoscopy to support the diagnosis and take a tissue sample. This involves using a lighted tube to look inside the nose and sinuses.

Acute sphenoid sinusitis may also cause nausea, vomiting, and fever. If nerves in the head (cranial nerves) are affected, people may have eye or vision problems. This may include temporary vision loss, blurred or double vision, or loss of some fields of vision. People may also have eye movement problems, droopy eyelids, and watery eyes. Face pain or numbness can also occur.

Sphenoid sinusitis is a medical emergency. If the eye, brain, or cavernous sinuses (near the base of the brain) are affected, intravenous (IV) antibiotics and surgery are usually needed to prevent life-threatening problems. The surgery is done to drain pus and remove infected tissue.
About 80% of people with ehrlichiosis have headaches as one of the first symptoms. They may also have flu-like symptoms.

Ehrlichiosis is an infection with the bacteria Ehrlichia. The bacteria is spread by the lone star tick found on deer. The infection occurs throughout most of the US, but mainly in Arkansas, Delaware, Missouri, Oklahoma, Tennessee, and Virginia. It is more common between May and August.

Almost everyone with malaria has headaches. Headaches are often one of the first symptoms, along with other flu-like symptoms. The headaches may be severe, but people usually do not have neck stiffness or sensitivity to light.

People can get malaria in most regions of the developing world. High-risk areas include Central and South America, Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Africa, South Asia, Southeast Asia, the Middle East, and Oceania. Malaria is usually found in tropical and subtropical areas where mosquitoes thrive. But it does not occur in all warm climates. The risk of malaria depends on the season, altitude, living space, and whether a person is taking medication to prevent malaria.

Other signs and symptoms of malaria include fatigue, muscle aches, weakness, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Many people have an enlarged spleen. Some people have severe disease, and sometimes serious organ failure.

The most common sign of malaria is a fever that comes and goes in cycles. People have fever spikes up to 104F, with sweating, followed by periods of chills and shivering. A rapid heart rate may go along with the fever. Some people become delirious. Fever episodes usually last several hours and are followed by extreme fatigue and sleep. Some people with malaria have fever episodes every 48 or 72 hours. Others have fever continuously or at irregular intervals.

People who have had malaria caused by the parasites P vivax or P ovale sometimes have relapses months or years after the original illness. The parasites can remain dormant in the liver. If they become active, they can cause malaria symptoms again. Most relapses occur within 3 years of the first malaria infection. They rarely occur more than 5 years later.

Dengue fever can be diagnosed by blood tests to detect dengue virus or antibodies to the virus. PCR testing is preferred. It can detect small amounts of dengue virus, but the test (RT-PCR) is not available everywhere. IgG and IgM antibodies to the virus can be measured in the blood, but the test may need to be repeated in 1 to 2 weeks to confirm infection. Dengue virus can also be cultured from the blood, especially early in the infection.
A headache in the front part of the head is often one of the first symptoms of dengue fever. The headache may quickly become quite severe. Some people also have pain behind the eyes.

The dengue virus is present in most tropical areas of the world: the Caribbean, Central America, parts of Mexico, South America as far south as northern Argentina, Southeast Asia, Taiwan, India, the Pacific Islands, northeastern Australia, the Red Sea coast in Saudi Arabia, Yemen and Oman, and many countries in Africa. The greatest risk is in urban areas. Infection can be acquired from a single bite by an infected mosquito.

Many people who are infected with dengue virus do not become ill. Of those that do become ill, most only have a flu-like illness. The symptoms start a few days after being bitten by an infected mosquito. People usually have a fever, chills, a severe headache, and pain behind the eyes. Some have joint pain or low back pain. Others, especially children, have a rash. People can also have nosebleeds, bleeding gums, or other mild bleeding of mucous membranes.

Dengue fever is caused by infection with a virus that is spread by the mosquito Aedes aegypti. The infection is common in tropical areas of the world. It usually causes a brief, mild illness, but sometimes leads to a more severe illness called dengue hemorrhagic fever.

There is no known medical treatment for chronic fatigue syndrome. Some people have had good results with cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). Others have had good results with exercise programs that help them slowly return to normal activity (graded exercise therapy).

Chronic fatigue syndrome causes extreme fatigue that does not get better with rest. It is severe enough to limit normal activities, and can last for months or years. Many other symptoms can occur with the fatigue. People may sometimes feel worse than at other times, and symptoms can occur in episodes. Chronic fatigue syndrome sometimes develops after an illness or other stress. The cause is unknown.
People with chronic fatigue syndrome often have headaches.

Brain damage can result from a cerebral venous thrombosis. This can cause nervous system problems, called focal neurological findings. People may have weakness or loss of sensation in areas of the head or body. They can also have trouble with speech, writing, or other brain activities. These signs can be subtle and go unnoticed without a careful examination by a doctor. Up to 75% of people with CVT have some of these symptoms.

A CT scan is often used to diagnose a subdural or epidural hematoma. An MRI scan can detect smaller amounts of bleeding or hematomas more than a few days old. Both imaging tests can be used to see the size of the hematoma and its effects on the brain.

Women who use tampons, especially the superabsorbent type, have the highest risk of developing toxic shock syndrome. Symptoms of illness usually begin between days 2 and 5 of the menstrual period. Toxic shock syndrome may also result from infections of skin or soft tissue, burns, recent surgery, and kidney dialysis.
Toxic shock syndrome usually begins with fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, watery diarrhea, and muscle pain. Some people have drowsiness or confusion.
